questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with severe itching and skin lesions as shown below. On examination, multiple red and yellow crusts are seen. Nikolsky's sign is negative. There is no mucosal involvement. There is no history of allergy to gluten. Immunofluorescence microscopy shows subepidermal split and deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts bullous pemphigoid. 

Bullous pemphigoid is a subepidermal immunobullous disorder. It occurs due to the production of autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes.

The patients are usually elderly and present with itching and tense bullae, mainly on the flexural areas and the abdomen. These blisters might rupture and give rise to hemorrhagic or yellow crusts. Mucosal membrane involvement is rare in this disease. Most of the lesions heal without a scar. Since these bullae are subepidermal, pressure over the lesions does not separate the epidermis from the dermis (Nikolsky sign is negative).

Immunofluorescent microscopy will show the presence of subepidermal split and deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. Histopathology will show the presence of subepidermal bullae with eosinophils.

It is mainly treated with corticosteroids. Other drugs used are azathioprine, dapsone, doxycycline, etc.

The below image shows linear IgG deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction seen in bullous pemphigoid.

Other options:

Option A- Pemphigus vulgaris is an intraepidermal immunobullous disease. It occurs commonly between the 4th to 6th decade. These present with flaccid blisters. Firm pressure over the lesion separates the epidermis from the dermis. Nikolsky's sign is positive. Mucosal involvement will be seen in the form of buccal and palatal erosions.

Option C- Dermatitis herpetiformis typically appears in the 4th decade, and the patients present with itching and rash, most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. The majority of the patients have symptoms related to gluten-sensitive enteropathies, like bloating, diarrhea, and other gastrointestinal complaints. Immunofluorescence microscopy will show the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular or fibrillar pattern. Complement 3 may also be found along with the IgA deposits.

Option D- Impetigo herpetiformis is a type of generalized pustular psoriasis (GPP) occurring in pregnancy. It presents with flexural erythema, pustules, and periumbilical pustulation, and can be associated with fever, tetany, and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 40-year male patient came to the hospital with complaints of dysphagia and chest pain for 1 month. ECG was normal. A barium study was done, which is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the barium study showing the corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm. 

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a hypermotility disorder of the oesophageal body. It is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body. It is more common in women. 

It is characterized by incoordinate movements of the esophagus due to marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles which in turn leads to symptoms like dysphagia and chest pain. These symptoms may be related to eating or exertion and may mimic those of angina. Patients will complain of a squeezing pressure in the chest that may radiate to the jaw, arms, and upper back. The symptoms are often pronounced during times of heightened emotional stress. Regurgitation of esophageal contents and saliva is common.

Investigations:

  • Manometry is the gold-standard diagnostic test.
    • The classic manometry findings in DES are simultaneous multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds).
    • On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (distal contractile integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of DES. There is intermittent normal peristalsis.
  • A corkscrew appearance in the barium swallow. 

Treatment - Temporary symptomatic relief can be provided by calcium channel blockers, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilation. However, in some cases, surgical repair is required to treat dysphagia. 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

questions.text: A young girl is brought with a deformity of the upper limbs. She has a history of multiple fractures and her father has a similar history since his childhood. The image of the patient's eye and the radiographs of the upper limb are shown below. Which of the following is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing the blue sclera and bowing of the upper limbs are suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). It occurs due to the defect in the formation of type 1 collagen.

Osteogenesis imperfecta, also called brittle bone disease, is an autosomal dominant disorder. There are 8 types of osteogenesis imperfecta. It occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. These mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

Since type 1 collagen is mainly present in the bone, ligament, dentin, and sclera, patients will present with repeated fractures, deformities of bone, blue sclera, and dental abnormalities.

The image given below shows different metabolic disorders of the bone.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who had recently been to the desert in the southwestern US presents with fever, cough, severe fatigue, symmetrical joint pain, and pleuritic chest pain.  On examination, erythema nodosum is noted. Tissue culture findings are as shown below. What is the most likely causative agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a flu-like illness, erythema nodosum, symmetrical joint pain, and pleuritic chest pain with a history of travel to south western USA and tissue culture showing spherules points toward the diagnosis of coccidioidomycosis and the causative agent is Coccidioides immitis.

Coccidioides immitis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It occurs as a spherule in tissues and culture at 37°C and as the mycelial form in soil and culture at room temperature. They are endemic to the arid desert regions of the southwestern USA and California. Infection is acquired by inhaling dust containing arthrospores of the fungus.

The infection can be asymptomatic, or patients may present with symptoms like fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. It is also referred to as Valley fever. Some clinical features occur due to an immunologic response. These include toxic erythema, erythema nodosum, and erythema multiforme. Symmetrical arthralgias called desert rheumatism may also be seen. Clinical dissemination of infection outside the thoracic cavity occurs in immunocompromised patients. 

Diagnosis:- Sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage, and biopsy specimens are the samples used for diagnosis. Microscopy shows spherule with endospores. Culture on brain heart infusion agar with 5% blood shows white-coloured colonies and is the most specific for diagnosis. Serology using ELISA, Immunodiffusion assays, and complement fixation assays are also used to detect IgM and IgG antibodies. Delayed hypersensitivity can be demonstrated by a positive skin test with 'coccidiodin' (analogous to the tuberculin test).

Azole drugs such as fluconazole and itraconazole are the mainstay of treatment. Severe cases are managed with intravenous amphotericin B. 

Other options:

Option B: Paracoccidioidis brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis. It is a chronic ulcerative granulomatous disease of the skin and mucosa.

Option C: Blastomyces dermatitidis causes blastomycosis, a systemic pyogranulomatous infection involving primarily the lungs. Infection may resemble tuberculosis, or get disseminated to various parts forming multiple abscesses. A cutaneous form of the disease would present as a papule, with secondary nodules that coalesce and form ulcerative lesions.

Option D: Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis. It is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system that is acquired by inhalation. It causes a pulmonary disease similar to tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding indicators used to measure the various fluid compartment volumes?

choices.text: Tritium oxide for total body water

questions.solution:
125I-albumin is used to measure plasma volume by indicator-dilution method, not total blood volume.

In an indicator-dilution method, an appropriate indicator is first placed in the fluid compartment, whose volume has to be measured. Once the indicator is evenly distributed throughout the fluid in the compartment, analyzing the amount of the indicator that becomes diluted helps assess the volume of the corresponding fluid compartment.

125Iodine-albumin and Evan's blue dye can also be used to measure the plasma volume. Whereas, total blood volume can be measured using an indicator substance like 51Chromium labelled red blood cells.

Total blood volume can also be calculated after measuring hematocrit using the equation:

Total blood volume = Plasma volume / 1- hematocrit

Note- Blood volume refers to the total amount of fluid circulating within the arteries, capillaries, veins, venules, and chambers of the heart at any time and includes RBCs, WBCs, platelets and plasma. Plasma volume is a component of the total blood volume and accounts for around 60% of the total blood volume

questions.text:
A male patient was given anesthesia for a surgical procedure. After a few minutes, the anesthetist noticed there was a masseter muscle spasm in the patient. His vitals are given below. Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition?
  • Pulse rate - 134/min
  • Blood pressure - 150/90 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate - 28/min
  • Temperature - 102ºF
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of masseter muscle spasm with hyperthermia and elevated blood pressure suggests the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia. The least likely drug to cause this condition is atracurium.

Malignant hyperthermia is a hypermetabolic condition, seen on exposure to inhaled anesthetics or succinylcholine. 

The pathophysiology behind the development of malignant hyperthermia is that there is an uncontrolled increase in intracellular calcium in skeletal muscle. This sudden release of calcium can result in sustained muscle contraction by removing the inhibition of troponin. This leads to increased oxygen consumption, and increased CO2 production, producing severe lactic acidosis and hyperthermia. 

Drugs known to trigger this condition include: 

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, ether, methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine.

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant and is not implicated in malignant hyperthermia.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: What type of study is shown below?
questions.solution:
The study shown is a prospective cohort study. 

A cohort study is a type of analytical study, which progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not disease. It is also known as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study. It can be divided into:

  • Prospective cohort studies: Outcome has not occurred at the time of the beginning of the investigation 
  • Retrospective cohort studies: Outcome has occurred before the beginning of the investigation 
  • Combination cohort studies: Both retrospective and prospective elements are combined

A cohort is a group of individuals who share a common experience or characteristic within a defined time period. The cohort groups are selected before the appearance of the disease under investigation. They are divided into study and control cohorts. The study cohorts are exposed to a particular factor thought to be related to the disease occurrence whereas the control cohorts are not exposed to this particular factor.  

Studying the effects of exposure to uranium in causing lung cancer is an example of a cohort study. Uranium miners are taken as the study cohort and other individuals who are not exposed to uranium mining are taken as the control cohort. 

Note: In a nested case-control study, cases of disease that have occurred in a defined cohort are identified. A specified number of matched controls who have not developed the disease are then selected from the cohort. 

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy is brought by his parents in an unconscious state to the emergency room. His mother says she heard him let out a cry while in his room, only for her to arrive and watch him lying on the floor, with continuous jerking of all four limbs for about 30 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

Generalized tonic-clonic seizures are the most common type of seizures resulting from metabolic abnormalities in the body.

The seizure usually begins abruptly without warning, following which there is the tonic contraction of muscles throughout the body. When this affects the muscles of expiration and the larynx, at the onset, a loud moan or an ictal cry is heard. There is a contraction of the muscles of the jaw, which may lead to tongue biting. A marked enhancement of sympathetic tone leads to an increase in heart rate, blood pressure, and pupillary size.

After 10–20 seconds, the tonic phase of the seizure typically evolves into the clonic phase, where there is relaxation of the muscles.

The postictal phase is characterized by unresponsiveness, muscular flaccidity, and excessive salivation. Bladder or bowel incontinence may occur.

Patients gradually regain consciousness over minutes to hours and there is typically a period of postictal confusion. Patients also subsequently complain of headache, fatigue, and muscle ache.

Other options:

Option B: Typical absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control. The seizure typically lasts for only seconds, consciousness returns as suddenly as it was lost, and there is no postictal confusion.

Option C: Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural muscle tone lasting 1–2s with no postictal confusion. A very brief seizure may cause only a quick head drop or nodding movement, whereas a longer seizure will cause the patient to collapse.

Option D: Myoclonic seizures are characterized by bilateral myoclonic jerks that may be single or repetitive. It is most frequent in the morning after awakening and can be provoked by sleep deprivation. Consciousness is preserved unless the myoclonus is especially severe.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with multiple rib fractures after a car accident. On examination, her neck veins are distended, heart sounds are muffled and chest movements are normal. A 2D echocardiography showed the following.  What is the appropriate immediate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the echocardiography showing a swinging heart is suggestive of pericardial effusion with tamponade. The most appropriate immediate treatment is to perform a needle pericardiocentesis.

Pericardiocentesis, also known as pericardial tap, can be performed with sub-xiphoid, parasternal, or apical approaches. The most common approach is a sub-xiphoid approach under echocardiographic guidance.

This patient has multiple rib fractures which likely have pierced the pericardium and/or the heart muscle. This leads to the accumulation of blood in the pericardial space. This space is non-distensible so fluid can compress the heart and impair contraction leading to decreased cardiac output. It also obstructs venous return which further reduces filling. 

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. It will result in the obstruction of the blood flow into the ventricles.

This manifests as Beck's triad, which consists of the following: 

  • Distended neck veins (due to decreased venous return)
  • Muffled heart sounds (fluid accumulation in the pericardial space)
  • Hypotension

The chest wall movements will be normal. Echocardiography may show the swinging heart sign which suggests pericardial effusion with tamponade. An eFAST is reliable and will show fluid in the pericardial space. A chest X-ray will show an enlarged heart shadow.

Cardiac tamponade can also be treated with open surgery procedures like sternotomy or left thoracotomy. This also allows for the heart to be repaired during the procedure. 

Other options: 

Option A: A pericardial window done via the subxiphoid or trans-diaphragmatic approach is the best way to diagnose and treat cardiac tamponade. It allows for drainage of blood and exploration of the area for the damage. It must be done under general anesthesia. This is the definitive management.

Option C: Chest tube insertion is used in massive hemothorax. Here, the accumulation of blood in the cavity severely restricts lung movements leading to inadequate ventilation. An appropriately placed chest tube can rapidly drain large amounts of blood. 

Option D: Analgesia is administered in cases of flail chest. This is because the pain from the rib fractures will further compromise respiratory movements. This patient's chest movements are normal. It is supplemented with oxygen administration and physiotherapy.

questions.text: A researcher studied an epidemic in  Africa. Symptoms of the disease were fever, muscle pain, and bleeding. The virus is shown in the image below. What is the organism?
questions.solution:
The organism is the Ebola virus as the image shows a long thread-like filamentous virus. 

The Ebola virus is an emerging infectious disease seen in Africa which belongs to the Filoviridae family with single-stranded RNA.  Its incubation period is 2 to 21 days.  Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of infected animals like chimpanzees, monkeys, fruit bats, etc. Human to human transmission is through the blood or body fluids of a symptomatic infected person.

Patients with Ebola virus infection present with fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. Treatment is mainly supportive with intensive support and care to reduce mortality. 

Other options: 

Option A: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a global pandemic and it is transmitted sexually, through blood contact, or from mother to child. It is a spherical enveloped virus and belongs to retroviridae family. The clinical features are unexplained diarrhea, fever, fatigue, weight loss, etc.  

Option B: Zika virus is a spherical virus transmitted by Aedes aegypti, and is mainly seen in American countries. The symptoms are fever, skin rashes, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, etc. Association has been reported with microcephaly and Guillain-Barre syndrome. 

Option D: H1N1 is also known as pandemic influenza A or swine flu. It is a spherical virus and was spread throughout the world in 2009. The symptoms are fever, cough, and gastrointestinal diseases in uncomplicated influenza. It involved the respiratory, central nervous system, multiorgan failure and septic shock in complicated influenza.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident had difficulty in breathing and multiple bone fractures. Chest X-Ray revealed a pneumothorax and an emergency needle thoracostomy is performed. The patient was shifted to the operation theatre for management of the fractures. Which of the following inhalational agents would you avoid in this patient?
questions.solution:
The inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient with pneumothorax undergoing surgery is nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide has greater diffusibility across tissue than nitrogen. It has the potential to expand air-containing cavities, specifically nitrogen-containing spaces, and replace nitrogen. Hence, it should be avoided in patients with pneumothorax. 

Due to its greater diffusibility, nitrous oxide is avoided in 

  • arterial air embolism
  • pneumothorax
  • acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distension
  • intracranial air
  • pulmonary air cysts
  • intraocular air bubbles
  • tympanic membrane grafting
  • middle ear surgeries

Nitrous oxide can even diffuse into tracheal tube cuffs, increasing its pressure and hampering mucosal blood circulation. 

The other options are not specifically contraindicated in pneumothorax as they do not worsen the condition. Their effects on the respiratory system are given below:

Option A: Desflurane causes a decrease in tidal volume and an increase in respiratory rate. Due to its pungent nature, it causes airway irritation leading to increased salivation, coughing, and laryngospasm.

Option B: Halothane causes rapid and shallow breathing as it stimulates ventilatory efforts. It is a potent bronchodilator but depresses the clearance of mucus from the respiratory tract. 

Option C: Sevoflurane depresses respiration and reverses bronchospasm similar to isoflurane. 

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings  on the anterior surface of lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The given image and the clinical features of red tender swellings in a patient with Crohn’s disease are suggestive of erythema nodosum.

The most common infectious cause of erythema nodosum is group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus infection.

Aetiological factors in erythema nodosum:

  • Infections: Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus infection, leprosy, Brucella, toxoplasmosis, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, CMV, E. coli, Yersinia, tuberculosis
  • Idiopathic, pregnancy
  • Drugs including oral contraceptives, hormonal replacement therapy, sulphonamides, and penicillin
  • Sarcoidosis, SLE, RA, Reiter's syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, Behcet's disease
  • Malignancy

It is the result of a non-specific cutaneous reaction to various antigens. It is postulated to be a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction to various antigens. The prodromal phase includes fever, joint, and muscle pains, and an alteration in general health. It is followed by the development of painful, tender, nodules on the extensor surfaces of the legs, knees and forearms. It usually resolves spontaneously in about 10 days. Treatment is mostly supportive.

The image below shows erythema nodosum.

Dermatologic manifestations of IBD are as follows:

Option A) Pyoderma gangrenosum: UC > CD, runs a course independent from bowel disease activity. Begins as a pustule, ulcerates circumferentially, is seen commonly on the dorsal surface of feet and legs, and may occur on arms, chest, and face.
Option C) Sweet’s syndrome: acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in UC.
Option D) Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is often seen in immunocompromised patients such as those with neutropenia. It presents as a round/oval lesion, 1 to 15 cm in diameter, with a halo of erythema and a necrotic center.

questions.text: A sample of RBCs collected from an anemic baby for a study showed abnormally low levels of lactate production using a 14C labeled substrate. A deficiency of which one of the following enzymes would be the most likely cause of this patient's anemia?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with reduced lactate production by red blood cells (RBC) is suggestive of pyruvate kinase deficiency. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to hemolytic anemia.

The mature erythrocyte lacks mitochondria and is, therefore, completely dependent on glycolysis for the production of ATP. Decreased lactate production in the erythrocyte indicates a defect in glycolysis. The anemia observed in glycolytic enzyme deficiencies is a consequence of the reduced rate of glycolysis, leading to decreased ATP production.

The resulting alterations in the red blood cell membrane lead to changes in the shape of the cell and later phagocytosis by the cells of the reticuloendothelial system, particularly macrophages of the spleen. The premature death and lysis of the red blood cell result in hemolytic anemia. Pyruvate kinase deficiency is the second most common cause (after glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency) of enzyme deficiency-related hemolytic anemia.

The clinical presentation in the newborn is hemolytic anemia with neonatal jaundice, requiring frequent phototherapy and exchange transfusion. Adults usually present with signs and symptoms of anemia such as weakness, fatigue, shortness of breath, and dizziness.

The severe form of the disease requires regular packed red cell transfusion with iron chelation and folic acid supplementation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who is a chronic smoker with a previous history of coronary artery disease came with complaints of chest pain. Which of the following is not a risk factor regarding the condition?
questions.solution:
Low levels of lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] are not a risk factor for coronary artery disease. 

Lipoprotein A contains the apolipoprotein B-100 portion of LDL linked to apolipoprotein A (apo A). It is an altered form of low-density lipoprotein (LDL). Increased Lp(a) levels are associated with coronary and cerebrovascular disease risk. It is associated with increased atherogenesis, inflammation, and thrombosis. It is independent of total cholesterol or LDL levels.

Atherosclerosis and ischemic heart disease are related to various risk factors, which are classified as modifiable and nonmodifiable. Hypertension (option B) is a modifiable risk factor, while the male gender (option C) is a nonmodifiable risk factor for atherosclerosis. The presence of inflammation (option D) is an additional risk factor.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Atherosclerosis

Nonmodifiable (constitutional):

  • Genetic abnormalities
  • Family history
  • Increasing age
  • Male gender

Modifiable:

  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypertension
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Diabetes

Additional risk factors:

  • Inflammation 
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] 
  • Elevated plasminogen activator inhibitor 1
  • Type A personality

questions.text: On neurologic examination, a patient is not able to recognize the key kept in his hand with his eyes closed. But, immediately recognizes the object once he sees it. Which lobe of the brain is likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of astereognosis. It is seen in lesions involving the superior parietal lobe which is marked as '3' in the given image.

Stereognosis is the ability to identify an object by a perception of the form and nature of an object without looking at it. This ability depends on intact touch, pressure, and proprioceptive impulses. The loss of integration of sensory impulses is called astereognosis. Astereognosis is seen in lesions of the superior parietal lobule and dorsal column pathways.

There are two parietal lobes, the dominant side, and the non-dominant side:

  • The functions of the dominant side of the parietal lobe are calculation, language, planned movement, appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, and homonymous hemianopia.
  • The function of the non-dominant side is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia.

The lesions in the posterior parietal lobe lead to loss of hand-eye coordination. Because neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

Image below shows the marked area as 1,2,3 and 4

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and frequent headaches for the past 1 month. On examination, turbinal mucosa is thick and does not pit on pressure, with little shrinkage on applying vasoconstriction drugs. All of the following are the treatment modalities for this condition except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypertrophic rhinitis. All of the listed options are the treatment modalities for this condition, except nasal irrigation with alkaline solution. It is used in the management of atrophic rhinitis. 

Hypertrophic rhinitis occurs due to recurrent nasal infections, chronic sinusitis and chronic irritation of nasal mucosa and is characterized by thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucous glands, periosteum, and bone.

Nasal obstruction is the predominant symptom. Other symptoms include thick and sticky nasal discharge, headache, heaviness of the head or transient anosmia.

Examination shows hypertrophy of turbinates. Turbinal mucosa is thick and does not pit on pressure. It shows little shrinkage with vasoconstrictor drugs due to the underlying fibrosis. Maximum changes are seen in the inferior turbinate, giving it a mulberry appearance.

Treatment includes removal of the cause and reducing the size of the turbinates by:

  • Linear cauterisation
  • Submucosal diathermy
  • Cryosurgery of turbinates
  • Partial or total turbinectomy
  • Submucosal rejection of turbinate bone
  • Laser therapy

Compensatory hypertrophic rhinitis is seen in cases of marked deviation of the nasal septum to one side. It is characterized by hypertrophy of inferior and middle turbinates on the roomier side to compensate for the effects of drying and crusting in the wider nasal space. Hypertrophic changes are irreversible with the correction of deviation and require reduction of turbinates at the time of septal surgery.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient with a recent history of MI and hypercholesterolemia was started on a hypolipidemic drug after which he developed muscle weakness. Which of the following statements is true regarding the action of the drug?
  • LDL - 125 mg/dl
  • HDL - 33 mg/dl
  • TGL - 270 mg/dl

MI- myocardial infarction
LDL- low-density lipoprotein
HDL- high-density lipoprotein
TGL- triglycerides

choices.text: Increase the activity of lipoprotein lipase
Increase hepatic conversion of cholesterol to bile acids

questions.solution:
The hypolipidemic drug that was prescribed after an episode of myocardial infarction and has resulted in muscular weakness is most probably a statin. The correct statement regarding the action of statin is that it acts by inhibiting cholesterol synthesis. 

Statins are the most commonly used hypolipidemic drugs. Statins act by inhibiting the rate-limiting HMG-CoA reductase enzyme, which in turn inhibits cholesterol synthesis. They decrease low-density lipoproteins (LDL), and triglycerides and increase high-density lipoproteins in plasma.

Examples of statins - Lovastatin, Simvastatin, Atorvastatin, Rosuvastatin, Pravastatin, and Pitavastatin.

Side effects of statins include myopathy and hepatotoxicity which are common with the concurrent use of nicotinic acid, gemfibrozil, or CYP3A4 inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A: Ezetimibe decreases intestinal absorption of cholesterol.

Option B: Fibric acid derivatives increase the activity of lipoprotein lipase and decrease the release of fatty acids from adipose tissue.

Option D: Bile acid sequestrants decrease the absorption of bile acids, increase hepatic conversion of cholesterol to bile acids and decrease LDL receptors on hepatocytes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was admitted to the ICU after major surgery for bowel cancer. Identify the false statement with respect to the test performed on this patient, which is shown below.

choices.text: This test is positive in deep vein thrombosis
The test is positive if there is calf pain on dorsiflexion of foot
It is highly sensitive and specific

questions.solution:
The image shows the method of eliciting Homan’s sign, that is calf pain on forced ankle dorsiflexion seen in deep venous thrombosis (DVT). It is neither sensitive nor specific.

Endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, and stasis of blood are the 3 components of Virchow's triad, which explains the formation of DVT. Postoperative thrombosis is the most common cause.

It presents with pain and swelling of the affected limb. Pitting edema, dilated veins, and low-grade fever are also present. Moses sign—tenderness on gently squeezing the calf—can be elicited. Embolization to the lungs can present as cyanosis, dyspnea, and dilated neck veins.

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of DVT, which shows filling defects and lack of compressibility.

The patient should be started on anticoagulants like heparin/low-molecular-weight heparin or fondaparinux.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with low-grade fever, easy fatiguability, and pain in the right hypochondrium.  A contrast-enhanced CT scan is given below. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and contrast-enhanced CT showing non-enhancing lesions in the liver are suggestive of liver metastasis. Colorectal carcinoma is the most common cause of metastatic lesions in the liver.

The most common site of distant metastasis of colorectal cancer is the liver. These metastases arise from hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. The lung is the next most common site for metastasis.

Metastatic malignancy of the liver is more common than primary hepatic neoplasia. The most common primary sources are the colon, breast, lung, and pancreas. However, primary malignancy from any organ may spread to the liver.

On CT, most metastases are low attenuation on unenhanced images and portal phase images. Features of metastatic lesions:

  • Multiple
  • Variable size
  • Growth in serial imaging

In most cases, multiple nodular metastases may be seen, causing hepatomegaly. The liver weight can exceed several kilograms. In some cases, a solitary metastatic nodule may be present, which can be surgically resected. Massive destruction of hepatocytes or direct obstruction of major bile ducts may cause jaundice.

Resection with a negative surgical margin of 1 cm (R0) has always been considered the gold standard but with chemotherapy, patients with R1 (microscopically negative) resection have similar survival to those with R0 resections.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old obese male patient is being evaluated for abdominal pain after undergoing the procedure shown below. On examination, his vitals are as given below. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
Temperature 101°F
Pulse Rate 125/minute
Blood Pressure 100/70 mm Hg
Respiratory Rate 20/minute
SpO2 95% on Room air

choices.text: Obtain an abdominal CT scan with contrast
Obtain a tagged red cell study
Observe the patient for a few hours

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Roux-en-Y gastric bypass procedure. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an anastomotic leak. The next best step in the management is an abdominal CT scan with contrast. 

Anastomotic leak is one of the common complications of Roux-en-Y bypass surgery. It is more common in gastrojejunostomy. It is one of the important causes of life-threatening complications and death. Patients usually present with fever, unexplained tachycardia and/or hypotension, and abdominal pain. The symptoms depend on the size of the leak, the location of the leak, and the degree of spread.

If an anastomotic leak is suspected, computed tomography should be obtained, which may show indirect evidence of a leak, such as pneumoperitoneum, extraluminal contrast, inflammatory stranding, fluid collections, and/or abscess. Contrast studies, such as an upper gastrointestinal series with gastrografin, may show the leak directly.

Management of the leak:

  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started as soon as the leak is confirmed.
  • Percutaneous drainage can be carried out in a stable patient with contained collections.
  • If non-operative management is unsuccessful at controlling the leak, the patient is hemodynamically unstable, or diffuse intra-abdominal contamination is suspected, the patient has to be shifted to the operating room, and exploration, drainage, and anastomotic revision have to be done.

Other complications of the Roux-en-Y gastric bypass procedure are:

  • Stricture
  • Obstruction
  • Afferent and efferent loop syndrome
  • Internal hernia
  • Marginal ulcer
  • Dumping syndrome
  • Post-vagotomy diarrhea
  • Gastric stasis
  • Alkaline gastritis
  • Gallstones
  • Peptic ulcer

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was referred to a haematologist following symptoms of easy bruising and recurrent epistaxis.  Further workup revealed JAK-2 mutations. Identify the true statement regarding this condition:

choices.text: Hemoglobin level of >16 g/dL in women is diagnostic
Associated with lower risk of thrombotic events
High levels of serum erythropoietin is seen

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with JAK2 mutations on workup, is indicative of polycythemia vera (PV). The true statement regarding this condition is that a haemoglobin level of >16 g/dL in women is diagnostic.

PV is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which phenotypically normal red cells, granulocytes, and platelets accumulate in the absence of a recognisable physiologic stimulus.

It is common among women before the fifth decade of life, and the most common cytogenetic abnormality in PV is the JAK2 mutation. 

Clinical features of polycythemia vera include easy bruising, epistaxis, acid-peptic disease, or gastrointestinal haemorrhage due to vascular stasis or thrombocytosis. Systolic hypertension and neurologic symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, headache, visual disturbances, and transient ischemic attacks (TIA) occur due to erythrocytosis.

In some patients, venous or arterial thrombosis involving cerebral, cardiac, or mesenteric vessels may be seen. Intra-abdominal venous thrombosis is particularly common in young women and maybe catastrophic if a sudden and complete obstruction of the hepatic vein occurs.

Patients also complain of aquagenic pruritus, where they have generalised itching following a warm bath or a shower. On examination, there is splenomegaly and lab reports reveal elevated haemoglobin, hematocrit, and red blood cell counts.

Diagnostic criteria for PV: 

  • Major criteria - 
    • Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men and >16 g/dL in women or hematocrit of >49% in men and 48% in women
    • Bone marrow biopsy - hypercellularity with trilineage growth (panmyelosis), including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation
    • Presence of JAK-2 mutation
  • Minor criterion - subnormal erythropoietin levels

A diagnosis of PV requires all three major criteria or the first two major and one minor criterion.

questions.text: A patient was evaluated for hearing loss. Rinne’s test shows that air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Weber's test lateralizes to the left ear. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the inference of the tuning fork tests is Weber's test lateralized to the left ear and Rinne's test normal. So the diagnosis is sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive (normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC, and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15-20 dB.

 Weber test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • Normal result is achieved when the sound heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worse ear
  • In sensorineural deafness, it is lateralized to the better ear

Other options: 

Option A: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC) and Weber's test lateralized to the right ear. 

Option B: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC)and Weber's test is lateralized towards the left ear.

Option D: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear presents with a positive Rinne's test (AC>BC) and Weber's test is lateralized towards the right ear.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with painless axillary lymphadenopathy. A lymph-node biopsy was done and histopathology revealed the following. Immunophenotyping revealed CD20+, BCL6+ ,CD15-  and CD30-. The findings are suggestive of which of the following subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with immunophenotype positive for CD20 & BCL6 and negative for CD15 and CD30, and the histopathology picture showing lymphohistiocytic variants of Reed Steenberg cell, also called popcorn cell, is characteristic of nodular lymphocyte-predominant subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).

The nodular Lymphocyte predominance subtype is a non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma commonly seen in young males <35 years of age. Common presentations include cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy.

It is characterized by lymphohistiocytic variants with multilobed nuclei. They resemble popcorn kernels and are are positive for CD20 and BCL6 while negative for CD15 and CD30. 

The below histopathology image shows popcorn cells of NLPHL.

Hodgkin's lymphomas are a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising from a single or group of lymph nodes and can spread to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. It usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The distinctive feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

Reed-Stenberg cells are neoplastic cells derived from the germinal center or post–germinal center B cells. They appear as large cells with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes. Each cell contains a large inclusion-like nucleolus and abundant cytoplasm.

WHO classifies Hodgkin's lymphoma into 5 subtypes:

  • Nodular sclerosis: Frequent lacunar cells
  • Mixed cellularity
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion
  • Nodular lymphocyte predominance

The first 4 subtypes are considered classical Hodgkin's lymphoma. The RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+. The lymphocyte predominant type is considered non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma with CD15-, CD30-, CD20+, and EB -. 

Other options: 

Option A: Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype equally affecting young males and females. Histology shows frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic RS cells with the background infiltrate composed of T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, plasma cells, and fibrous bands. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Option B: Lymphocyte-rich is an uncommon subtype seen in older-aged adults with increased occurrence in males. Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells and background infiltrates rich in T lymphocytes are seen. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Option C: Lymphocyte depletion is an uncommon subtype seen in older men. A reticular variant is observed in this subtype with frequent diagnostic RS cells and a small amount of background reactive cells. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complained of low mood, decreased appetite, and loss of weight for the past 2 months. He mentions that he feels worthless and has decreased interest in activities. He also complains of great difficulty falling asleep. He has past history of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs should be preferred for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given clinical scenario has major depression with insomnia, decreased appetite, and weight loss. The preferred drug for this patient is mirtazapine as it is an antidepressant with sedative and appetite-stimulating properties.

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant (a noradrenergic-specific serotonin antagonist). It blocks the presynaptic α2 receptors and postsynaptic 5HT2 and 5HT3 receptors. The antagonism at serotonin receptors helps relieve anxiety and insomnia and stimulates appetite. It has a sedative property as it blocks the H1 receptors. Mirtazapine is used in the treatment of major depression with long-standing insomnia.

Adverse effects include sedation, increased appetite, weight gain, and rarely agranulocytosis. Sexual dysfunction is not a known side-effect of mirtazapine.

Atypical anti-depressants are those that act by unique mechanisms other than those of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), MAO inhibitors, and tricyclic antidepressants. It includes drugs like trazodone, mianserin, bupropion, mirtazapine, and amoxapine.

Other options:

Option A: Fluoxetine is an SSRI used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, and generalized anxiety disorders. It may cause insomnia, and hence, it is avoided in this patient. Other adverse effects include anxiety, irritability, and decreased libido.

Option B: Venlafaxine is an SNRI used in the treatment of major depression, generalized anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. It may cause insomnia, and hence, it is avoided in this patient. Other adverse effects are nausea, sexual dysfunction, and sustained elevation of blood pressure.

Option C: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant used in the treatment of major depression and nocturnal enuresis. Its use should be limited in heart diseases as it has quinidine-like effects on cardiac conduction, and hence, it is avoided in this patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with complaints of cough, fever, dyspnea, and weight loss. On examination, skin lesions and bilateral parotid enlargement are seen. A chest X-ray reveals the finding shown below. Which of the following neurological lesions is unlikely to be seen in her?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing hilar lymphadenopathy are suggestive of sarcoidosis. Bell's palsy is not associated with sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic disease characterised by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. Patients with sarcoidosis typically present with cough, dyspnea, chest pain, fever, weight loss, arthralgias, and erythema nodosum.

Few patients may have neurological involvement which may include:

  • Lymphocytic/ basilar meningitis
  • optic neuritis
  • Cranial nerve involvement - transient facial nerve palsy can be mistaken for Bell's palsy (which is idiopathic)
  • Anterior hypothalamic disease with associated diabetes insipidus

Chest X-Ray findings include:

  • Diffuse reticular parenchymal infiltrates, mostly seen in the upper lobe.
  • Garland triad pattern of lymph node enlargement involving the right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign.

The staging of sarcoidosis is as below-

Stage  1 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4 Pulmonary fibrosis  

Investigations for sarcoidosis include: 

  • Biopsy: Biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. 
  • Gallium-67 scan:
    • Panda sign - it is due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.
    • Lambda sign - it is seen in thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).
  • Elevated serum ACE levels, hypercalcemia, and hypercalciuria which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Increased CD4/CD8 ratio of these increased lymphocytes in the BAL fluid. A ratio of >3.5 is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

The mainstay of treatment is corticosteroids. Systemic therapy is indicated if multiple organs are affected. Immunosuppressants such as mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, and infliximab can be used in patients who are refractory to steroids.

questions.text: During a routine physical examination of a  female patient of Japanese ancestry, you notice the following discoloration. She gives no other significant history. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows blue‐greyish macular discoloration in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves in the acromioclavicular region which is highly suggestive of Nevus of Ito. 

Nevus of Ito is a dermal melanocytosis involving the acromioclavicular region and the upper chest. It is a benign lesion and is also known as naevus fusoceruleus acromiodeltoideus. Q‐switched laser systems are the first-line treatment, as they achieve higher rates of pigment clearing. 

Other options - 

Option A: Mongolian spots are seen in infants. They are bluish-grey pigmented areas, commonly seen over the sacrum. They usually resolve during childhood.

The below image shows Mongolian spots.

Option B: Becker nevus is a hyperpigmented nonlinear lesion commonly present over the upper trunk. It is common in men and appears within the first 2 decades, typically at puberty. The lesion is frequently hypertrichotic.

The below image shows Becker's nevus.

Option D: Nevus of Ota is an extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis. It affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye. It is distributed along with the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve. The below image shows the nevus of Ota.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with painless hematuria. Urine microscopy revealed an egg of Schistosoma haematobium. What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice used in its treatment?

choices.text: Stimulates Ca2+ efflux and causes spastic paralysis
Stimulates Ca2+ efflux and causes flaccid paralysis
Stimulates Ca2+ influx and causes spastic paralysis
Stimulates Ca2+ influx and causes flaccid paralysis

questions.solution:
The drug of choice for Schistosoma infections is praziquantel and the mechanism of action of this drug is to stimulate Ca2+ influx and cause spastic paralysis of the organism.

Praziquantel is an anti-helminth drug. It acts by promoting Ca2+ influx in schistosomes and other praziquantel-sensitive parasites. This results in increased muscular activity and later causes contraction and spastic paralysis of the worm. Praziquantel may also act by generating reactive oxygen species. 

It is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis caused by all Schistosoma species that infect humans. A single oral dose of 40 mg/kg is curative in the majority of cases. It is also preferred in infections by:

  • Cestodes like Hymenolepsis nana, Taenia saginata, Taenia solium, and Diphyllobothrium latum
  • Trematodes like Clonorchis sinensis, Opisthorchis viverrini, Paragonimiasis westermani, Fasciolopsis buski, Heterophyes heterophyes, and Metagonimus yokogawai

Fasciola hepatica is resistant to praziquantel.

The adverse effects include abdominal discomfort, eosinophilia, rashes, arthralgia, and myalgia. Praziquantel is contraindicated in ocular cysticercosis because the host response can cause irreversible damage to the eye. In neurocysticercosis, an inflammatory response to praziquantel can lead to meningismus, seizures, and cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis. Hence, the drug of choice in neurocysticercosis is albendazole.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic. You do a bimanual examination by placing 2 fingers of one hand in the anterior fornix of the vagina and fingers of the other hand, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus. This is called :
questions.solution:
The scenario described in the question is the demonstration of Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign: the examiner performs a bimanual examination. Two fingers of one hand are placed in the anterior fornix of the vagina and fingers of the other hand are placed, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal fingers and the vaginal fingers appear to oppose each other below the body of the uterus. This can be elicited between 6-10 weeks.

This sign is based on the fact that the lower part of the body of the uterus is empty and extremely soft, and the upper part is enlarged by the growing fetus.

Other options :

Option A - Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination. It is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C - Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D - Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents to the outpatient for the first time. He was born by vaginal delivery at home and has not received any vaccines. Which of the following vaccines would be indicated at this visit, as per the National Immunization Schedule?
questions.solution:
BCG (Bacille Calmette-Guerin) vaccine would be indicated in this 3-week-old neonate at this visit as per the national immunization schedule. 

BCG is a live attenuated vaccine that can be given soon after birth until 1 year of age. It is given intradermally at the left upper arm. It provides protection against the central nervous system and disseminated tuberculosis. The liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine are the types available. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine.

After 2-3 weeks of correct vaccine administration a papule develops at the site. Its size increases slowly and breaks into a shallow ulcer covered with a crust. Healing occurs within 6-12 weeks and will leave a permanent tiny round scar, which is a normal reaction. Adverse reactions seen with BCG vaccine administration are pain, swelling, redness, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, etc. 

The image below shows the BCG scar: 

Mission Indradhanush was launched to fully immunize children up to two years of age against seven vaccine-preventable diseases and pregnant women. The vaccines against the following diseases are included in this program diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, tuberculosis, polio, hepatitis B, and measles. It was later modified to the intensified mission indradhanush to further strengthen the immunization coverage.

Other Options:

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine given at birth until the first 24 hours. It is given intramuscularly on the anterolateral side of the mid-thigh. 

Option C: Oral polio vaccine-0 (OPV-0)  is a live attenuated vaccine given at birth until the first 15 days.

Option D: Injectable polio vaccine (IPV) is a killed whole organism vaccine given at 6 and 14 weeks of age.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: The dissection of the inguinal canal reveals the structure marked A. Which of the following is the content of the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A represents the spermatic cord. The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve is the content of the spermatic cord.


The spermatic cord is a structure that passes through the inguinal canal in males. The inguinal canal is a natural passageway between the muscle layers of the anterior abdominal wall in the region of the groin. It transmits the spermatic cord in males, the round ligament of the uterus in females, and the ilioinguinal nerve in both sexes.

The contents of the spermatic cord include:

  • Cremaster muscle fibers
  • Testicular artery and accompanying veins
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Vas deferens
  • Cremasteric vessels
  • Lymphatics
  • Processus vaginalis

Coverings of the spermatic cord from inside to outside are:

  • Internal spermatic fascia from fascia transversalis
  • Cremasteric fascia
  • External spermatic fascia from external oblique aponeurosis 

An injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females.

Other options:

Option A: Iliohypogastric nerve is not the content of the spermatic cord/inguinal canal. It carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area.

Option B: Ilioinguinal nerve is not the content of the spermatic cord but it is the content of the inguinal canal. It supplies somatic sensation to the skin of the upper and medial thigh. In males, it also innervates the root of the penis and upper scrotum. In females, it innervates the mons pubis and labia majora.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is a content of the femoral canal. It carries sensory supply to the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is a component of pantothenic acid?
questions.solution:
The amino acid present in pantothenic acid is beta-alanine.

Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in metabolism. It is a key component of coenzyme A (CoA), which is involved in numerous biochemical reactions, particularly in transferring acyl groups.

Functions of Pantothenic Acid in the Body:

  • Facilitates fatty acid oxidation and synthesis.
  • Involved in the formation of succinyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA, essential intermediates in the Krebs cycle.
  • Precursor to HMG-CoA, which is crucial for cholesterol synthesis.
  • CoA participates in acetylation, which modifies proteins, neurotransmitters, and drugs.

The intestinal gut flora synthesizes vitamin B5, so deficiency is rare. Grierson-Gopalan's burning foot syndrome is a rare disorder caused by pantothenic acid deficiency. Its clinical features include burning pain and paresthesia in the lower extremities, staggering gait due to impaired coordination, and sleep disturbance.

Other Options:

Option B: Tryptophan is a precursor for serotonin, melatonin, and niacin (Vitamin B3).

Option D: Arginine is involved in the urea cycle and nitric oxide (NO) synthesis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was non-compliant with his tuberculosis medication now comes with back pain. You suspect the disease has disseminated to the spine. Which part in the given image of the spine, is most commonly affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient is likely to have developed tuberculosis of the spine. The most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine/ Tb spine is the paradiscal type.

The structures marked in the image:

  1. Posterior spinal elements
  2. Paradiscal area of the vertebra
  3. Anterior vertebral body
  4. Central vertebral body

Tb spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

  • Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.
  • Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbous.
  • Anterior - the anterior part of body is affected and spreads through the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process) is affected.

Image showing various parts and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks gestation, presents to the outpatient department with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. A wet smear with 10% KOH solution shows the following picture and the vaginal pH is found to be <4.5. What will be the best management in this scenario?

choices.text: Metronidazole 200 mg oral TDS for 7 days

questions.solution:
The patient has candidal vaginitis. The best management in a pregnant woman is topical azoles like clotrimazole or miconazole, applied intravaginally for 7 days.

Although the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis involves oral fluconazole 150 mg single dose or topical azole therapy for 7 days in a non-pregnant woman, only topical azoles are recommended during pregnancy. Since the use of fluconazole has been associated with embryotoxicity and increased risk of cardiac malformations, it is recommended to be avoided during the first trimester.

Risk factors for candidal infection include

  • Immunosuppression
  • HIV
  • Pregnancy
  • Steroid therapy
  • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Diabe­tes Mellitus
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Obesity

The clinical symptoms of vaginal candidiasis include curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching with vaginal pH <4.5. The diagnosis can be confirmed by microscopic examination of the smear of vaginal discharge with 10% KOH solution. The smear shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae.

questions.text: The sites of cholesterol synthesis are:
questions.solution:
The sites of cholesterol synthesis are the cytosol and endoplasmic reticulum.

Cholesterol synthesis takes place in all nucleated cells. The important sites are the liver, adrenal cortex, testis, ovaries, and intestine.

Conversion of HMG CoA into mevalonate by the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis. It is a microsomal enzyme present in the endoplasmic reticulum.

Cholesterol is a 27-carbon compound containing 4 rings and a side chain. Cholesterol synthesis is an endergonic pathway (the reaction is carried out with the help of energy released from the hydrolysis of ATP). An imbalance in this pathway leads to increased circulating levels of cholesterol as seen in vascular diseases. 

All carbon atoms in cholesterol are provided by acetyl CoA and reducing equivalents are produced by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH). Initially, two molecules of acetyl-CoA condense to form acetoacetyl-CoA catalyzed by cytosolic thiolase. This acetoacetyl-CoA enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway.

questions.text: A postoperative patient on a ventilator was shifted to the intensive care unit for monitoring. When he woke up, he was unaware of his location, date, and time. He started to move violently on the bed and threw medicines at the nurses. Which of the following drugs having selective α2 agonist property can be used to sedate the patient?
questions.solution:
Dexmedetomidine can be used to sedate this patient.

Dexmedetomidine is a directly acting α2 -selective sympathomimetic drug. Activation of the α2A adrenergic receptor by dexmedetomidine produces both sedation and analgesia.

It is usually used in short-term sedation (<24 hours) of intubated patients and aids in easy awakening from the postoperative state without any respiratory depression. It is administered as an IV infusion. Side effects are hypotension, bradycardia, and dry mouth. 

Sympathomimetics are drugs that mimic the stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system. These are classified as:

  • Direct-acting (adrenergic receptor agonists) -  
    • Non-selective - epinephrine (α1, α2, β1, β2, and β3), noradrenaline (α1, α2, and β1), droxidopa (α and β)
    • Selective - 
      • α1-agonists such as phenylephrine and midodrine
      • α2-agonists such as apraclonidine, brimonidine, clonidine, guanabenz, α-methyl dopa, lofexidine, and tizanidine
      • β2-agonist such as terbutaline 
  • Indirect-acting (release epinephrine or noradrenaline to stimulate adrenergic receptors) - amphetamine, tyramine, etc
  • Mixed-acting - ephedrine

The various uses of α-agonists are:

  • Glaucoma - apraclonidine and brimonidine. They cause CNS depression and apnea in neonates, therefore contraindicated in children <2 years of age
  • Postural hypotension - prodrugs like midodrine and droxidopa 
  • Hypertension - centrally acting anti-hypertensives such as clonidine, guanabenz, and α-methyl dopa 
  • Opioid withdrawal - lofexidine
  • Muscle-relaxant - tizanidine

PHC: Primary health care
questions.solution:
