questions.text: Statistical power (1-β) of a test is the probability of:

choices.text: Accepting the null hypothesis when it is true
Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true
Accepting the null hypothesis when it is false
Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false

questions.solution:
Statistical power (1-β) of a test is the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false.

The power of a study is its ability to avoid or decrease beta errors or type II errors and is represented by 1 – β.

There are two types of errors. They are:

  • Type 1 error: Accepting a false alternative hypothesis. It is also called the alpha error. It is a false positive error. 
  • Type 2 error: Rejecting a true alternative hypothesis or accepting a false null hypothesis. It is also called the beta error. It is a false negative error.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardinal finding in patients who are declared brain dead according to Harvard criteria for brain death?

choices.text: No pupillary changes in response to light
Absent eye movements in response to caloric testing

questions.solution:
Cough response to bronchial suction is indicative of normal cough reflex and is, therefore not a cardinal finding in brain death. 

The 3 cardinal features of brain death include:

  1. Unresponsiveness or coma- demonstrated by an absent motor response to pain in all extremities.
  2. Apnea- impaired brainstem activity indicates damage to the medullary cardio-respiratory centers. This manifests as a loss of centrally controlled breathing.
  3. Absence of brainstem reflexes -
    • Cranial nerve II, III (optic and oculomotor)- absent direct and consensual light reflex. This is associated with dilated pupils measuring about 9 mm. 
    • Cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear)- absent oculocephalic (Doll's eye phenomenon) and oculovestibular (unresponsive to caloric testing) reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve V, VII (trigeminal and facial)- absent corneal and jaw reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve IX, X (glossopharyngeal and vagus)- absent cough and gag reflexes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with an itchy rash along the extensor surface of her elbows, knees, and scalp. Examination reveals pink plaques with overlying silvery scales. She also has new lesions as shown in the image. The phenomenon that causes new lesions over scratched areas is known as?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image describe plaque psoriasis on the dorsum of the hand and isomorphic or Koebner phenomenon that causes new lesions over scratched areas.

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions. The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants, or any treatment procedures. It is commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, lichen sclerosus, pityriasis rubra pilaris, and vitiligo.

Other option:

Option B - Development of lesions seen as a result of the spread of an infective agent (like Molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), is called pseudo-Koebner’s phenomenon.

Option C - If a lesion disappears at the site of injury/trauma, then it is termed as the "reverse Koebner phenomenon". It has been documented in cases of psoriasis and vitiligo.

Option D - The isotopic phenomenon is the occurrence of a new skin disorder at the site of another healed skin condition. For example, the appearance of psoriasis at contact dermatitis or the appearance of granuloma annulare at the site of herpes zoster.

questions.text: A young girl is being evaluated for truncal asymmetry.  An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following braces is not used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray showing lateral curvature of the lower thoracic vertebrae is suggestive of scoliosis. The SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is used in cases of cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. 

Scoliosis is defined as the lateral curvature of the spine in the coronal plane when the patient is upright. A Cobbs angle of >10% is diagnostic of scoliosis.

Cobbs method consists of three steps:

  • Locating the superior-end vertebra of the curve
  • Locating the inferior-end vertebra of the curve
  • Drawing perpendicular lines from the superior surface of the superior-end vertebra and from the inferior surface of the inferior-end vertebra and making them intersect

The angle of deviation of these perpendiculars is the angle of the spinal curve known as Cobb's angle.

Nash and Moe's method and Perdriolle and Vidal method are tools for assessing the vertebral rotation in scoliosis. 

Management of scoliosis includes:

Observation- it is the primary treatment done in scoliosis cases especially when the curve is less than 20 degrees. Radiographic documentation is done for the size and progression of the curves.

Orthotic treatment- is used in skeletally immature patients for curves more than 25 degrees. The following are commonly used for orthotic treatment in scoliosis:

  • Boston brace- it is a type of thoracic-lumbar-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace) and is commonly prescribed for scoliosis.
  • Milwaukee brace- it is the originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO). It is bulkier and older and is not commonly used nowadays.
  • Charleston brace- it is prescribed for nighttime use and is only intended to be used while lying down.

Surgical correction- indications for surgery in scoliosis are:

  • Curves > 50 degrees in skeletally mature patients
  • Curves > 10 degrees with marked rotation
  • Double major curves > 30 degrees

The most common surgical intervention done in idiopathic scoliosis is segmental instrumentation with a multi-back system.

The SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine. It is used in cases of cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with excoriation of anal skin was brought by his mother to the pediatric OPD. She states her son scratches his anal area frequently during nighttime. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. Which of the following is not a feature of the egg of this organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of frequent anal area scratching during nighttime, excoriation of the skin around the anus, and the given life cycle of humans acquiring infection by ingestion of embryonated eggs, which are released by the gravid female over the perianal skin are suggestive of pinworm or Enterobius vermicularis infection. The eggs of pinworms are not bile-stained.

The pinworm eggs have a characteristic plano-convex shape. They are colorless and not bile-stained. They have a thick, double-layered, transparent eggshell. The eggs also float in a saturated salt solution. Inside lies a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo. The eggs are highly infectious, and reinfection should be prevented by regular washing of bed linens, towels, and clothing in hot water.

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. Infection is acquired by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus, crawls around on the perianal and perineal skin, and lays its eggs. This leads to pruritus, and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina, causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

A faecal examination is not useful for diagnosis as the eggs are not usually released in faeces. The eggs can be demonstrated by swabbing the perianal and perineal skin where they are deposited. The adult worms may sometimes be noticed on the surface of stools, can be found crawling out of the anus, or may be detected in stools collected after an enema.

The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) is used to collect specimens for diagnosis. In the NIH swab, the perianal area is swabbed by rolling the cellophane part over it. After detaching the cellophane part, it is spread over a glass slide and examined microscopically. The image given below shows the NIH swab.

Another method is the scotch tape method, where the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. The tape is transferred to a glass slide with the sticky side down. Then, a drop of toluene is added for clearing and examined under the microscope.

Treatment involves a single dose of Pyrantel pamoate 11 mg/kg, albendazole 400mg, or mebendazole 100mg. Piperazine is given once daily for a week.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman was admitted for right knee arthroplasty. On the 7th postoperative day, she developed a fever and cough with purulent, blood-tinged sputum. Her chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would be the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the chest-Xray showing lobar consolidation with bulging fissure sign are suggestive of late-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia most likely caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae.

K. pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. The patient characteristically presents with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission. It can further be classified as:

  • Early-onset HAP, which occurs within 4-5 days of admission and is commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, Escherichia coli, etc.
  • Late-onset HAP occurs >5 days after hospital admission and is usually caused by gram-negative bacteria like Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii.

Pneumonia caused by Klebsiella species shows the following classic chest X-ray findings:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor. 

The following image shows a bulging fissure sign.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be used for treatment and include third-generation cephalosporins and beta-lactam antibiotics with beta-lactamase inhibitors. Nosocomial infection with Klebsiella is difficult to treat in many situations as they produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamase and are resistant to many antibiotics.

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common causative agent of community-acquired pneumonia.

Option C: Legionella pneumophila causes community-acquired pneumonia and early-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia.

Option D: Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of Q-fever.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used in the treatment of overactive urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Tolterodine is commonly used in the treatment of the overactive urinary bladder. It is a muscarinic receptor antagonist. 

In an overactive bladder, there is an overactivity of the detrusor muscle due to the up-regulation of M3 receptors. Drugs that block these receptors such as tolterodine act by improving bladder capacity, reducing the frequency of bladder contractions, and lowering intravesicular pressure.

Anticholinergics are muscarinic receptor antagonists and parasympatholytics. The important uses of various anticholinergics are as follows:

  • Atropine - for AV block, organophosphorus poisoning, and refractive error testing in children (produces cycloplegic mydriasis)
  • Scopolamine/ hyoscine (transdermal patch) - for motion sickness
  • Ipratropium - for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and rhinorrhea 
  • Tolterodine - for childhood enuresis, overactive and neurogenic bladder
  • Pirenzepine (selective M1 receptor antagonist) - for peptic ulcer disease 
  • Benzhexol/ Trihexyphenidyl - for Parkinson's disease and drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms
  • Dicyclomine (direct spasmolytic effect on GI smooth muscle) - for diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome
  • Glycopyrrolate (reduces secretions) - as a pre-anesthetic medication

Adverse effects of muscarinic antagonists include dryness of mouth, decreased sweating, thirst, mydriasis and blurring of vision, palpitations, and urinary retention. CNS effects include restlessness, hallucinations, and delirium.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the given life cycle:
questions.solution:
The life cycle depicted in the above image is of Dracunculus medinensis (Guinea worm).

Humans are the definitive host. They get infected by drinking unfiltered water containing infected cyclops. Larvae come out once cyclops are killed in the stomach and penetrate the wall of the duodenum. They reach the retroperitoneal and subcutaneous connective tissues and develop into adults.

The fertilized female worm grows and migrates within the connective tissues. It reaches a site where it is likely to come into contact with water like the leg (most common). Here, the gravid female worm secretes a toxin that causes a blister formation. The blister ruptures discharging a milky white fluid containing numerous L1 stage larvae.

The larvae survive for about a week in water. They are swallowed by the intermediate host- freshwater cyclops. The larvae penetrate the gut wall of the cyclops and develop into the infective third-stage larvae. The lifecycle continues when humans drink water containing infective cyclops.

Other options:

Option A: Wuchereria bancrofti passes its life cycle partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female Culex mosquitoes, the intermediate hosts. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

 

 

Option B: The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female blackflies, the intermediate host.

 

Option C:  Loa loa completes its life cycle in humans, the definitive host, and in mango flies/day-biting flies of the genus Chrysops, which are the intermediate hosts/vectors.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man from West Bengal presents with recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following skin tests can be used to know the prior exposure to this parasite?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 20-year-old man presenting with fever with chills, progressive weakness, and abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months and the bone marrow aspirate showing Leishman-Donovan bodies are suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. A positive Montenegro skin test indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasite.

Leishmaniasis is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly, which inoculates the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host in developing countries. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

Causative organisms include:

  • Old world leishmaniasis: Leishmania donovani, Leishmania major, and Leishmania tropica
  • New world leishmaniasis: Leishmania mexicana complex and Leishmania braziliensis complex

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

The image below shows Lutzomyia sandfly responsible for the New World cutaneous leishmanisis.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis/ kala-azar
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms:

  • The promastigote develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.  

When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly's saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity. Amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as the Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes, and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast, which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of L. donovani for humans.

Given below is the lifecycle of L. donovanii.

This condition causes fever with rigor and chills associated with splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. It lowers immunity and causes persistent fever, anaemia, leucopenia, and thrombocytopenia, if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

The image below shows amastigotes located intracellularly within macrophages.

Tests to detect leishmaniasis include:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip. This is recommended by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: A skin test, 0.1 ml of killed promastigote suspension is injected intradermally on the dorsoventral aspect of foremarmInduration of 5mm or more is considered positive and indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasite. In active kala azar, this test is negative and becomes positive after 6-8 weeks (delayed hypersensitivity) after a cure from the disease or if the patient developed protective immunity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are

  • Sodium stibogluconate - Drug of choice in countries where strains are sensitive to antimony compounds.
  • Miltefosine - Alternative to sodium stibogluconate and only oral drug used in Kala-azar.
  • Amphotericin B - Drug of choice in India, as 40-60% of strains are resistant to antimony compounds. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/kg IV is the first line of treatment in India, 

Other options:  

Option A: Frenkel's test is done in toxoplasmosis.

Option C: Fairley's test is done in schistosomiasis.

Option D: Bachman intradermal test done in trichinellosis.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

questions.text: You observe a nurse administering an intramuscular injection to a patient in the clinic. Which of the following was likely being administered to the patient?
questions.solution:
Tetanus toxoid is likely to be administered intramuscularly.

The intramuscular route (IM) of drug administration is mostly given in the deltoid, gluteal region, and anterolateral aspect of the thigh where the muscle is bulkier. This route bypasses the first-pass metabolism and reaches systemic circulation quickly. 

This method is suitable for moderate volumes, oily vehicles, and some irritating substances. Absorption of drugs in an aqueous solution after IM injection depends on the rate of blood flow to the injection site and can be relatively rapid. Thus, the injections given in the gluteal region are relatively more slowly absorbed in females than in males. Depot injections may produce slow and prolonged action. 

The Z-track technique is used for intramuscular injections in which the needle is inserted at 90 degrees with a quick darting movement. This prevents skin staining through the tract to the surface of the skin. Pain intensity is also reduced.

 

Intramuscular injections are contraindicated if there is an active infection at the site of administration, coagulation defects, and thrombocytopenia.

Other routes of administration are oral (undergoes first-pass metabolism), intravenous (100% bioavailability and bypasses first-pass metabolism), subcutaneous, inhalational (e.g Metered dose inhaler, rotahaler), topical (including eye and skin preparations), and rectal.

Other options:

Options A and B: Test doses of drugs and BCG vaccines are administered intradermally.

Option D: Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is administered subcutaneously. Heparin can be given through intravenous and subcutaneous routes.

questions.text: A man is brought to the emergency with a head injury following a motorcycle accident.  His wife reports he was unconscious for around 5 minutes and vomited thrice. On examination, he is drowsy with a fixed and dilated pupil. CT scan of the head revealed a lenticular hemorrhage. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a man with a head injury, unconsciousness, vomiting, dilated and fixed pupils, and the CT finding of a lenticular hemorrhage is characteristic of an extradural or epidural hemorrhage. The most likely cause is a rupture of the middle meningeal artery.

Epidural hemorrhage or hematoma is an intracranial hemorrhage in which the hemorrhage is between the dura and the skull. It classically occurs due to a tear of the middle meningeal artery following a fracture of the temporal bone. 

Clinically, patients with an extradural hemorrhage typically present with an initial transient loss of consciousness. A lucid interval is then seen, which may be minutes to hours during which the patient usually presents. Neurological deterioration then occurs following the lucid interval as the hematoma expands. Reduced consciousness, pupillary dilatation, and hemiparesis can be seen. 

CT scan shows a characteristic hyperdense biconvex or lenticular-shaped hematoma. Management is by surgical evacuation of the hematoma or by ligation of the damaged middle meningeal artery. 

Other options:

Option B: Shearing of the bridging veins is seen in chronic subdural hemorrhage (SDH). SDH is a type of intracranial hemorrhage that occurs between the dura and the arachnoid and appears as a crescentic clot on a CT scan. Symptoms like drowsiness, headache, confusion, or mild hemiparesis occur days or weeks after the injury.

Options C and D: Rupture of small cortical arteries or veins due to trauma and the rupture of saccular aneurysms can be seen in subarachnoid hemorrhage. Clinically, patients present with sudden and severe headaches, commonly called thunderclap headaches. It can be associated with seizures, unresponsiveness, and vomiting. The CT scan shows blood in basal cisterns and rounded lesions suggest aneurysms.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A woman has just delivered a baby by spontaneous vaginal delivery. Clinically, after how many weeks of postpartum will the involution of the uterus be complete?
questions.solution:
Involution of the uterus is complete by 4 weeks of postpartum.

Involution of the uterus occurs due to a decrease in the size of muscle fibers. Following delivery, the fundus lies at about 5.5 inches above the symphysis pubis. During the first 24 hours, the level remains constant, after which there is a steady decrease in height by half an inch in 24 hours. By the end of 2nd week, the uterus becomes a pelvic organ. The rate of involution slows down after this. By 4 weeks, involution is complete. The uterus almost becomes normal in size by 6 weeks.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is being evaluated for recurrent febrile urinary tract infections. A micturating cystourethrogram was done as shown. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Surgical repair reverses renal scarring and improves function
Nephrectomy is indicated if affected kidney has poor function
An open ureteral implantation has a high success rate for grades I-IV
Antibiotic prophylaxis is the recommended initial approach

questions.solution:
In the above scenario with a boy with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and the micturating cystourethrogram showing bilaterally dilated ureters is suggestive of bilateral vesicoureteric reflux (VUR). Surgical repair will not reverse renal scarring or cause improvement in renal function. The goal of surgery is to minimize the risk of febrile UTIs from ongoing VUR.

Vesicoureteric or vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a condition in which there is a retrograde urinary flow from the bladder to the kidney and ureter. It is usually a congenital familial disorder with an autosomal dominant transmission.

VUR can cause urinary stasis and lead to urinary tract infection (UTI). It also predisposes to pyelonephritis and which can lead to renal scarring due to parenchymal inflammation. This is known as reflux nephropathy. 

Micturating cystogram is used to confirm the VUR. VUR can be graded based on the appearance of the urinary tract on the micturating cystogram. It is as follows:

Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter.
Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation.
Grade III: VUR into a dilated ureter and/or blunting of the calyceal fornices.
Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated ureter.
Grade V: massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression.

The initial approach to management includes daily antibiotic prophylaxis to reduce the risk of UTIs and subsequent renal scarring.

Surgical repair can be done via open, laparoscopic, and endoscopic methods. Various procedures performed include:

  • Ureteral narrowing using psoas hitch- in cases with a megaureter
  • Nephrectomy or nephroureterectomy- if refluxing kidney function is very poor
  • Ureteral reimplantation- this has a success rate of >95–98% for grades I-IV
  • Endoscopic repair of VUR- non-invasive and used for lower grades of VUR. It involves the injection of a bulking agent through a cystoscope just beneath the ureteral orifice, creating an effective flap-valve

Surgical repair will not reverse renal scarring or cause improvement in renal function.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was started on an anticancer drug for the germ cell tumor of the testes. After 2 months he started developing the following skin lesions. Identify the anticancer drug:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of a germ cell tumor of the testes and the image shows flagellate dermatitis. So, the anticancer drug is bleomycin.

Flagellate dermatitis is bands of pruritic, linear, and erythema maculae over the trunk and extremities. It can be associated with conditions such as dermatomyositis. It can also be seen as an adverse effect a few hours to 6 months after the administration of drugs like bleomycin, and peplomycin.

The rash of flagellate dermatitis heals with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation. These lesions readily respond to topical corticosteroids, but usually, disappear after the stoppage of the drug. 

Bleomycin is DNA cleaving anticancer antibiotic that causes oxidative damage to nucleotides, resulting in single- and double-stranded breaks in DNA. It is used as a component in the treatment regimens of testicular cancer and Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Bleomycin has a little myelosuppression effect. The major adverse events include dose-dependent pulmonary toxicity (irreversible pulmonary fibrosis) and flagellate dermatitis.

Other options: 

Option A: Oxaliplatin is an antineoplastic drug used in the treatment of colorectal cancer. The adverse events include peripheral neuropathy, leukemia, and pulmonary fibrosis. 

Option C: Dacarbazine is a methylating agent used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma, malignant melanoma, and sarcomas. The adverse effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, flu-like syndrome, and alopecia.

Option D: Doxorubicin is an anthracycline antineoplastic drug used in the treatment of malignant lymphomas, Ewing sarcoma, soft-tissue sarcomas, and breast carcinoma. The major adverse effects include myelosuppression, cardiomyopathy, alopecia, and stomatitis.

questions.text: A multiparous woman presented with a bulge protruding from the vagina that increases in size on coughing and sneezing. Which of the following is not a complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of pelvic organ prolapse. Urge incontinence is not a complication of this condition. 

Pelvic organ prolapse is a condition where the pelvic organs herniate into the vagina due to weakness of the supports of the uterus. The patient may present with a feeling of a bulge protruding through the vaginal opening. Prolapse is aggravated by straining so the bulge increases on sneezing and coughing. It reduces on lying down, or by manual reduction. It may be accompanied by micturition disturbances like difficulty in initiating micturition or frequency of micturition. Rectal symptoms and coital difficulties can be present depending on the degree of prolapse.

Complications of prolapse:

  • Kinking of the ureter with resulting renal damage can occur in procidentia and enterocele.
  • Chronic Urinary tract infection due to retention of urine in a cystocele, and can lead to upper renal tract infec­tion and renal damage.
  • Decubitus ulcer due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes.
  • Stress incontinence occurs when the internal urinary meatus and neck of the bladder descend below the level of pelvic floor muscles.
  • Cancer of the vagina can rarely occur over the decubitus ulcer and if the ring pessary is left in over a long period.

questions.text: A 40-year-old coal miner was brought to the casualty with the following wounds. On examination, there are multiple abrasions, contusions, and puncture lacerations. What is the likely cause of injury?

choices.text: Blast injuries due to flying shrapnels and debris
Burn injuries due to contact with electric wire
Gun shot wounds due to close range firing

questions.solution:
The given history is likely suggestive of blast injuries sustained due to flying debris and shrapnel.

T.K.Marshall described the characteristic injuries associated with bomb explosions. It includes:

  • Abrasions
  • Bruises/ contusions
  • Puncture lacerations
Blast injuries are classified as:
  • Primary injuries- effect of transmitted blast waves on gas-containing structures. External injuries are absent and are characterized by internal injuries. The middle ear, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract are the most susceptible to this.
  • Secondary injuries- injuries caused by shrapnel and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion. These injuries may affect any part of the body and sometimes result in penetrating trauma. Most casualties are caused by secondary injuries.
  • Tertiary injuries- are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects.
  • Quaternary injuries- all other injuries caused by explosions are not included in the above three categories. eg, flash burns, crush injuries, respiratory effects due to toxic dust, gas, etc.

 

Other options:

Option B: Burns injuries associated with contact with metal wires would typically show joule burns or electric burn marks. It is associated with lacerations surrounded by contusions.

The image given below shows a Joule burn.

Option C: Animal bite marks show teeth impression arranged in arches. Teeth marks are not seen in this case.

Option D: Gunshot wound would not show so much scattering if fired from close range. It is therefore unlikely in this case.

The image given below shows an entry wound from a revolver with an abrasion collar.

Burns, histotoxicanoxia, and crush injuries
  • The specific pulmonary injury of air blast is known as blast lung.
  • When the explosion is in the water the pressure changes are called underwater blast. Intestinal damage is very common in underwater blast injuries.
  • Solid blast refers to the wave of energy that spreads through the rigid structure when an explosive is detonated near it and people in contact with its structure can be injured.
  • Caecum is most sensitive to intestinal blast injury.

questions.text:
A boy presented with a painful right knee swelling as seen in the image. He has a history of easy bruising and hematoma formation at injection sites. His lab investigation report is given below. Which of the following is the preferred treatment option for this condition?
  • Platelet count - 4,00,000 /μL
  • Bleeding time - Normal
  • PT - Normal
  • aPTT - Prolonged
questions.solution:
The image showing knee joint swelling in a patient with bleeding tendency and prolonged aPTT indicates bleeding into the joint space, i.e. hemarthrosis due to hemophilia. The preferred treatment option among the ones given here is the administration of factor VIII concentrate.

Hemophilia is a coagulation disorder occurring due to a deficiency of clotting factor VIII, leading to hemophilia A, or clotting factor IX, leading to hemophilia B. Hemophilia A and B are clinically indistinguishable and can be differentiated based on clotting factor assay. The disorder is X-linked recessive, meaning males are affected, and females are asymptomatic carriers.

Patients present with bleeding tendencies such as ecchymoses, epistaxis, haematuria, menorrhagia, hemarthrosis, prolonged bleeding after dental or minor surgical procedures, etc. Repeated hemarthrosis causes chronic synovitis and articular cartilage erosion, leading to hemophilic arthritis.

Laboratory findings in hemophilia:

  • Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) - prolonged
  • Platelet count- normal
  • Bleeding time- normal
  • Prothrombin time- normal
  • The mixing of normal plasma with patient plasma results in the correction of the aPTT value.

Based on the percent activity of specific clotting factors, hemophilia is classified into:

Severity The activity of a specific clotting factor
Severe <1%
Moderate 1-5%
Mild >5%


Mild cases of hemophilia are treated by administration of desmopressin acetate. Moderate to severe cases need the replacement of deficient clotting factors. The monoclonal antibody emicizumab can bridge activated factor IX and factor X, thus restoring functional activated factor VIII activity in patients with hemophilia.

Please note that this patient could have either hemophilia A or B. The preferred treatment options for hemophilia are the administration of factor VIII and factor IX for hemophilia A and B, respectively. As factor IX is not given in the options, factor VIII is the best possible answer.

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV-positive lady with a CD4+ count of 35/μL presented with decreased visual acuity and floaters. On fundus examination, the following findings were seen. Which of the following is true regarding this patient's condition?

choices.text: Screening is done yearly if CD4 counts <100/μl
Anti retroviral therapy is the mainstay of treatment
Valganciclovir is used as intravitreal implant

questions.solution:
The clinical description of an AIDS patient with low CD4 counts with vision abnormalities and the fundus image demonstrating a pizza pie appearance suggests a diagnosis of cytomegalovirus retinitis. Anti-retroviral therapy is the mainstay of treatment.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis most commonly occurs in immunocompromised states like AIDS, transplant patients, and cancer patients.

Ocular features include reduced vision due to macular involvement, which carries a poor prognosis (Option A). Floaters signify vitritis. One eye is usually affected initially. 

CMV retinitis shows “pizza pie” or “scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance” or “cottage cheese” on fundus examination. It appears as an arcuate zone of retinitis with hemorrhages and optic disc swelling. Often CMV is confined to the retinal periphery, beyond the view of the direct ophthalmoscope. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA) shows marked vascular sheathing. Cataract is a finding in the late stage of the disease.

Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management, restoring the patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is taken orally and Ganciclovir is used as a slow-release intravitreal implant. (Option D)

Screening is done in patients with low CD4 counts once in 3 months if <50/μL, once in 6 months if 50–100/μL, and once a year, if >100/μL. (Option B)

    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated

questions.text:
A 28-year-old recently married woman committed suicide because of dowry torture by her husband's family. Under which of the following sections is this incident covered?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA
questions.solution:
This incident can be considered a dowry death. Dowry death is defined under section 304B IPC.

According to this, if the husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage; they shall be deemed to have caused her death. The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 7 years, but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 63 (IPC 375) deals with rape.

Option C: Section 72 (IPC 228A) deals with imprisonment for up to 2 years and a fine for disclosure of the identity of a rape victim.

Option D: Section 100 (IPC 299) deals with culpable homicide.

questions.text: A child presented with itchy plaques over the neck, and the bilateral popliteal and cubital fossa. The mother reports a positive family history of asthma. Which of the following is not a part of the criteria used in the diagnosis of the child's condition?

choices.text: No prior history of skin crease involvement
History of a generally dry skin
Personal history of other atopic disease

questions.solution:
UK refinement of Hanifin and Rajka criteria is the criteria used in the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis and no prior history of skin crease involvement is not a part of the diagnostic criteria.

The original Hanifin and Rajka criteria require that patients have at least 3 of the 4 major criteria and 3 of the 23 minor criteria. Consequently, Williams et al. coordinated a UK working party to attempt to refine the criteria of Hanifin and Rajka into a repeatable and validated set of diagnostic criteria for atopic eczema.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: While carrying out a postmortem analysis of a victim, which of the following features will be consistent with an antemortem burn?

choices.text: Dry, hard and yellow blister base
Absent line of redness around wound

questions.solution:
The presence of carboxyhemoglobin in the blood is highly suggestive of death due to antemortem burns. A blood hemoglobin saturation of >10% with carbon monoxide is indicative of antemortem smoke inhalation.

This is in contrast to postmortem burns, wherein carboxyhemoglobin levels are not elevated as it is not possible for the gas to diffuse through the skin or be otherwise absorbed by a dead body.  

Other options:

Option A: Dry, hard, and yellow blister base is seen in postmortem burns. This is in contrast to the inflamed, red base of blisters seen in antemortem burns.

Option B: Absent line of redness around burn wounds is seen in postmortem burns. This vital reaction, termed red flare, is present in antemortem burns.

Option C: Reduced enzymatic activity around the wound is seen in postmortem burns. This is in contrast to the significant increase in enzyme activity (cathepsin, aminopeptidase, alkaline phosphatase) as seen in an antemortem burn.

questions.text: A young man came with complaints of redness and watering of the left eye for 2 days. On examination, he had decreased corneal sensation and the fluorescein staining shows the following finding. What is the most likely causative agent of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of decreased corneal sensation and fluorescein stain showing dendritic ulcer are suggestive of Viral keratitis and the most likely causative agent is the Herpes simplex virus.

Keratitis is the inflammation of the cornea characterized by corneal edema, cellular infiltration, and ciliary congestion. Herpes simplex causes epithelial keratitis and in severe forms, dendritic ulcers develop. Most of the patients present with redness, photophobia, watering, and blurred vision. On examination, visual acuity and corneal sensation are reduced. Follicular conjunctivitis and blepharitis may develop but are usually mild. Clinical reactivation occurs due to multiple stress factors and causes recurrent infections.

The fluorescein-stained image under slit-lamp examination shows dendritic ulcers, a pathognomic feature of epithelial keratitis. They are mostly treated with acyclovir 3% ointment or ganciclovir 0.15% gel.

Other options:

Option A- Aspergillus fumigatus is a common agent of mycotic corneal ulcers. The slough is usually dry on examination, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation. Thick, immobile, hypopyon due to direct invasion of fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber can be seen. Satellite lesions may be present. Below is an image showing a fungal ulcer with a dry feathery border and hypopyon.

Local natamycin, voriconazole, and amphotericin B are effective against aspergillus and fusarium.

Option C: Acanthamoeba keratitis is a protozoal corneal infection seen in soft contact lens users and individuals who swim or bathe in contaminated water. Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion. It presents as a ring lesion or ring stromal infiltrate as shown below. They are treated with topical polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) 0.02% and propamidine isethionate 0.1%.

 

Option D- Staphylococcus aureus is a common gram-positive and coagulase-positive organism causing bacterial keratitis. Stromal edema, folds in the Descemet membrane, and anterior uveitis are often seen.

An image of a bacterial corneal ulcer with hypopyon is shown below.

They are usually treated with antibiotics like cefuroxime, vancomycin, or teicoplanin.

questions.text: A young boy presents with pain in his fingers and toes. On examination there is pallor. Peripheral smear findings are given below. Which of the following structural gene change is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the histopathology image are suggestive of sickle cell disease. A point mutation is the structural gene change responsible for this condition.

A mutation is defined as a permanent change in the DNA. A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. This results in alterations in a triplet of bases and leads to the replacement of one amino acid with another. This may have silent, missense, or nonsense effects.

The image given below shows different types of mutation.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the T-to-A point mutation in the sixth codon of the β-globin gene. This results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

Patients usually present with symptoms of anemia and vaso-occlusive crisis like dactylitis of the bones of the hands and feet, acute chest syndrome, hyposthenuria, aplastic crisis, and asplenia.

Peripheral smear shows the presence of irreversibly sickled red cells and Howell-Jolly bodies due to asplenia.

Other options:

Option A: Deletion occurs when a gene or codon or a single base is completely lost. This is seen in disorders like alpha-thalassemia, hemophilia, and cystic fibrosis.

Option B: Alteration is a broad term used to define the change in genes or codons or base pairs. It may result in various changes in genes like amplification, deletion, translocation, rearrangements, point mutation, and frame-shift mutation. Although gene alteration is seen in sickle cell disease. Point mutation is the more precise structural gene change.

Option C: Rearrangement

questions.text: A 45-year-old man recently diagnosed with lung cancer presents with a worsening headache that is aggravated by stooping forward. On examination, he has facial and upper limb edema. His anterior abdominal wall appears as shown in the image with the arrow depicting the direction of subcutaneous venous flow. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing dilated tortuous superficial abdominal veins is suggestive of superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome seen due to superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction.

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome is a clinical condition caused by the obstruction of the superior vena cava, which leads to impaired venous drainage from the head, neck, upper extremities, and upper torso. The most common cause is malignancy ( lung cancer, lymphomas, particularly non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and metastatic tumors). Non-malignant causes include thrombosis (caused by central venous catheters, pacemakers, or implantable defibrillators), fibrosing mediastinitis (e.g., due to tuberculosis or histoplasmosis), and aortic aneurysm or mediastinal fibrosis.

SVC syndrome is usually diagnosed clinically. Patients present with 

  • Facial puffiness and periorbital edema (worsens in the morning or when bending forward)
  • Jugular venous distension (JVD) and prominent veins on the chest wall
  • Dyspnea, cough, hoarseness, and stridor (if trachea is compressed)
  • Headache, dizziness, and confusion (due to cerebral venous congestion)
  • Edema and cyanosis of the upper limbs

The image below shows the direction of subcutaneous venous flow in various conditions.

A chest X-ray shows the superior mediastinum widening. A CT scan with contrast is the gold standard for identifying an obstruction's location, severity, and cause. Management is supportive and depends on treating the cause.

Other options:

Option A: Inferior vena cava obstruction occurs secondary to deep venous thrombosis, malignancy, pregnancy, and infection. Patients usually present with symptoms of decreased venous return such as fatigue, dizziness, weight loss, abdominal pain, night sweats, anorexia, palpitations, diaphoresis, dizziness, and shortness of breath on exertion. The direction of subcutaneous venous blood flow is from below to above. Inferior vena cava obstruction will not have facial or upper limb edema.

Option C: Cranial metastasis arises from the hematogenous spread and frequently originates from a lung primary or is associated with pulmonary metastases. Patients usually present with symptoms related to direct brain compression from the tumor or from edema. The location of the metastases will determine the focal deficits seen.

Option D: Tumor lysis syndrome is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It is commonly associated with treating lymphomas like Burkitt's lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Patients usually present with symptoms of hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with recurrent respiratory infections. After a series of investigations, the boy was diagnosed with Kartagener syndrome. What are the components of this syndrome?

choices.text: Chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis and situs inversus

questions.solution:
The components of Kartagener syndrome are chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. 

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. When a patient has bronchiectasis, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus triad, he is known to have Kartagener syndrome. It occurs due to the absence of protein dynein in the A tubules of the respiratory mucosa.

The below chest X-ray shows dextrocardia (situs inversus) in Kartagener syndrome.

The disease is usually diagnosed based on the clinical picture and should be evaluated in later stages when a child presents with recurrent lower and upper respiratory tract infections. Other features of primary ciliary dyskinesia include congenital heart diseases and neonatal hydrocephalus. Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).  

Transmission electron microscopy is the gold standard investigation to analyze cilia. There is no specific treatment for this condition and is managed according to the symptoms. 

Option A: Asthma fever and eosinophilia are seen in Churg Strauss syndrome. 

Option C: Chronic rhinitis with polyp is seen in chronic rhinosinusitis. 

Option D: Infertility (azoospermia) and bronchiectasis are seen in Young syndrome.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is rushed to the ER with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation. His erect X-ray abdomen is as shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 64-year-old man with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation along with the radiograph showing the coffee bean sign is likely to be sigmoid volvulus.

It occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon.

A sigmoid volvulus can be differentiated from a cecal volvulus by swirl sign, location of the obstructed loop, and anatomical appendages. The apex of a sigmoid volvulus usually lies high on the left side. The apex of a caecal volvulus may lie on the right side or extend to the left upper quadrant. The swirl sign in with sigmoid volvulus is located at the level of the pelvic brim while the swirl in cecal volvulus is located in the right lower quadrant. 

Other options: 

 Option C: Cecal volvulus is more common in females in the 4th to 5th decade. It is characterized by ischemia. 

Option D: Paralytic ileus occurs secondary to neuromuscular failure, leading to the failure of transmission of peristaltic waves. It mainly occurs following laparotomy. A CT scan is more accurate for differentiating functional from mechanical obstruction. The image given below is an X-ray of the paralytic ileus showing gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels. 

Differences between the small bowel and large bowel obstruction:

Features Small bowel Large bowel
Valvulae conniventes Present in jejunum Absent
No of Loops Many Few
Distribution of loops Central Peripheral
Haustra Absent Present
Diameter 3-5 cm >5 cm
Solid feces Absent Present

 

Option B: Colonic diverticula are almost all false diverticula, i.e., mucosa herniating through a defect in the muscularis layer, typically covered by overlying serosa (where present). The given barium enema study shows a saw-tooth appearance due to barium-filled outpouchings, suggestive of colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a throbbing unilateral headache of severe intensity, which is aggravated by movement and is associated with photophobia. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonists were found to be effective in the management of her headache. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache responsive to CGRP antagonists indicates a diagnosis of migraine headache.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches, after tension headaches. It is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches of moderate to severe intensity. Other features of migraine include deep-seated pain and sensitivity to environmental and sensory stimuli. The headache can be triggered by glares, bright lights, sounds, hunger, stress, physical exertion, hormonal fluctuations during menses, lack of or excess sleep, or alcohol.

Management of migraine includes nonpharmacologic management and pharmacologic measures. Triggers unique to the patient should be avoided. Lifestyle modifications to avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, and to maintain a healthy sleep cycle are necessary. Triptans (Sumatriptan, Zolmitriptan) is used in the treatment of acute attacks. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be useful if taken early after symptom onset. Other drugs include oral dopamine receptor antagonists and opioids. 

Migraine is associated with the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) within the trigeminal nucleus. Hence, newer therapies under evaluation include CGRP antagonists and monoclonal antibodies to CGRP and its receptor. They are considered to be as effective as triptans and are better tolerated. 

Other options:

Option A - Cluster headaches are deep, retro-orbital, unilateral, excruciating headaches. They are characterized by attacks at the same time every day. 

Option B - Temporal arteritis or giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis. It affects medium to large-sized arteries. It is characterized by fever, anemia, high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and headaches in people over the age of 50. 

Option D - Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by excruciating pain in the area of the trigeminal nerve. It lasts for a few seconds to a minute and can recur. 

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: Which of the following passes through the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm. Among the given options, the hemi-azygous vein passes through the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm.

The diaphragm is a domed musculofibrous sheet that separates the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavities.

The image given below shows the inferior view of the diaphragm.

The important openings in the diaphragm and structures that pass through them are given in the table below:

Opening/aperture Structures passing through them 
Aortic hiatus
  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Lymphatic trunks from the lower posterior thoracic wall
  • Azygos and hemi-azygos veins
Oesophageal hiatus  
  • Esophagus
  • Vagal trunks
  • Gastric nerves
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels
  • Lymphatic vessels
Caval opening
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right phrenic nerve
Lesser apertures Greater and lesser splanchnic nerves

The diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve whose root values are C3, C4, and C5. The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain. Diaphragmatic pain is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

Referred pain usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess.

Note: The left phrenic nerve descends anterior to the pericardial sac of the left ventricle and terminates at the central tendon of the diaphragm. The left phrenic nerve innervates the left diaphragmatic dome, and the right phrenic nerve innervates the right diaphragmatic dome, with the majority of nerve branching occurring on the inferior aspect of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the infarct shown in the image?

choices.text: This is an example of coagulative necrosis
Seen in organs which lack an end-arterial circulation
Sepsis is usually absent in this type

questions.solution:
The image shows a splenic infarct that appears white, wedge-shaped, and bland in nature. It is seen in organs with an end-arterial circulation (i.e. organs that lack collateral circulation)

An infarct is an area of localized coagulative necrosis. They may be red (hemorrhagic) or white (anemic) based on color. Based on the presence or absence of infection, they may be septic or bland, respectively. Splenic infarcts are usually white, bland, wedge-shaped, and subcapsular in location.

The spleen is an organ with end-arterial circulation. The occlusion of a major splenic artery or any of its branches causes the infarct. Vascular occlusion leads to an infarct due to the lack of collateral blood supply. Common sites where emboli lodges are the kidney, brain, and spleen.

Splenic infarcts are usually bland unless it occurs in a patient with infectious endocarditis. In such cases, septic infarcts are common. There is suppurative necrosis due to the presence of microbes in the necrotic tissue. The infarct gets converted to an abscess.

Red infarcts are seen

  • with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  • in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
  • in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone
  • in tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
  • when the flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction)

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency room in a comatose state. He weighs around 70 kg. On examination, his serum glucose levels were found to be 500 mg/dL, arterial pH is 7.33, with increased plasma ketone levels. His serum potassium levels are normal. What is the bolus dose of insulin that should be administered immediately to this patient?

choices.text: 7 units of short acting regular insulin intravenously
7 units of short acting insulin subcutaneously
14 units of short acting insulin intravenously
14 units of short acting regular insulin intravenously

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient is likely to have diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The dose of insulin that should be immediately administered to this patient is 0.1 units per kg. Since the patient weighs around 70 Kg he should be administered 7 units intravenously.

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, thirst/polyuria, severe abdominal pain, and shortness of breath. It is precipitated by various events like inadequate insulin administration, infection (pneumonia/UTI/ gastroenteritis/sepsis), infarction (cerebral, coronary, mesenteric, peripheral), drugs (cocaine), and pregnancy.

Clinical signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, rapid breathing)
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath (acetone breath)
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250–600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia - there is a 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis.
  • Osmolality – 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones – positive
  • Metabolic acidosis – increased anion gap (HAGMA)
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L – best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

The algorithm for the management of DKA is shown below.

questions.text: A young woman comes to the Suraksha clinic of the local primary health center. She is examined and the yellow kit is prescribed to her as treatment. Which of the following symptoms did she most likely present with?
questions.solution:
Lower abdominal pain is the most likely presenting symptom in the patient. 

The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) has started the Suraksha clinic to deal with sexually transmitted infections (STI) and reproductive tract infections (RTI). Pre-packed STI/RTI color-coded kits are supplied through STI/RTI clinics free of cost. The kits are obtained centrally and then supplied to all state AIDS control societies. 

Kit Syndrome/s

Kit 1
(Grey)

Urethral discharge

Cervical discharge

Painful scrotal swelling
Kit 2 (Green) Vaginal discharge / Vaginitis
Kit 3 (White) Non-herpetic genital ulcers

Kit 4
(Blue)

Non-herpetic genital ulcers if allergic to penicillin

Kit 5
(Red)

 Herpetic genital ulcers
Kit 6 (Yellow) Lower abdominal pain

Kit 7
(Black)

 Inguinal bubo

Kit 8

(Brown)

 Anorectal discharge syndrome

Other symptoms seen in the patients prescribed with the yellow kit are: 

  • Fever
  • Vaginal Discharge
  • Menstrual irregularities (heavy, irregular vaginal bleeding)
  • Dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia, dysuria and tenesmus
  • Lower backache
  • Cervical motion tenderness

The kit contains cefixime 400 mg tablet to have immediately, metronidazole 400 mg tablet, and doxycycline 100 mg tablet to have twice a day for 14 days. Along with this, the male partner should be treated with kit 1. 

Lower abdominal pain should be followed up on the 3rd, 7rd, and 14th day and a referral should be made if symptoms persist. 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes with complaints of drooping eyelids and double vision in both eyes, The symptoms worsen with repetitive eye movements and resolve after rest. Chest radiography revealed an anterior mediastinal mass. Which of the following is not a feature of her condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of intermittent complaints of ptosis and weakness of extraocular muscles (causing diplopia), which worsen after repetitive eye movements, is suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). Chest radiography showing an anterior mediastinal mass (most likely a thymoma) supports this diagnosis. Deep tendon reflexes are normal in myasthenia gravis, not absent.

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR seems to be mediated by the thymus. There is some thymic abnormality in most patients with MG. Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients. Thymoma is seen as an enlargement of the thymus in the anterior mediastinum on CT chest or chest radiography.

MG usually occurs in females in their 20s and 30s.  Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. Weakness of the muscles of the face (option C), palate and tongue may lead to difficulty in swallowing (option D). When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs (option A) are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. 

The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include:

  • Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay
  • Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response
  • Block and jitter response on single-fiber EMG
  • Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of anticholinesterase such as edrophonium
  • Positive ice-pack test: improvement of ptosis on the application of ice-pack on the affected eye

Patients with generalized MG are started on anticholinesterase drugs such as pyridostigmine. They are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Indications for thymectomy in a patient diagnosed with MG include: 

  • Presence of thymoma
  • Generalized MG with anti-AChR antibodies, even if no thymoma is seen on CT chest

Following thymectomy, immunosuppressive drugs are started based on the clinical status of the patient. 

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: What will be the site of erythropoiesis in a healthy 30-year-old man?
questions.solution:
The site of RBC production (erythropoiesis) in a healthy 30-year-old man would be the sternum.

The marrow of the long bones, except for the proximal portions of the humerus and tibia, becomes quite fatty and produces no more red blood cells after about the age of 20 years. As the man is above 20 years of age, the membranous bones would be the principal site of hematopoiesis, which in this case, is the sternum.

Hematopoiesis refers to the production of the different types of blood cells from multipotent hematopoietic stem cells in the marrow. This includes the production of red blood cells, by a process called erythropoiesis.

The sites of erythropoiesis vary at different stages of life as shown below:

Age Site of erythropoiesis
Early embryonic life Yolk sac
Middle trimester of gestation Liver (main)
Spleen and lymph (to a smaller extent)
From the last month of gestation and at birth to 20 years of age Bone marrow of the axial skeleton and long bones like the femur
Beyond 20 years of age Membranous bones such as the vertebrae, sternum, ribs, and iliac.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. A chest X-ray was done as shown below. Which of the following subtypes of this condition causes maximum pulmonary venous obstruction?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the X-ray showing a snowman appearance of the heart is suggestive of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC). The infracardiac type causes maximum pulmonary venous obstruction.

In the infracardiac variety of TAPVC, the common pulmonary vein drains to the portal vein instead of joining the left atrium. The pulmonary vein gets obstructed as it enters the diaphragm through the esophageal orifice.

TAPVC is a congenital cardiac malformation where pulmonary veins return to the right atrium or systemic venous circulation instead of draining directly to the left atrium.

According to the site of anomalous connection, the TAPVC can be divided into four subtypes:

  1. Supracradiac (Most common)
  2. Cardiac
  3. Infracardiac
  4. Mixed

Percentage of obstruction in different types of TAPVC:

Type of TAPVC  % with significant obstruction 
Infracardiac 95-100
Supracardiac 40-75
Cardiac 5-10
Mixed -

Neonates with severe obstruction to pulmonary venous return (infracardiac group) present with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. Murmurs may be absent on cardiac examination.

Children with mild or no obstruction to pulmonary venous return (supracardiac or cardiac) develops heart failure due to a fall in pulmonary vascular resistance. They are associated with systolic murmurs.

In the supracardiac variety, the anomalous pulmonary veins enter the innominate vein and persistent left super vena cava. As a result, a large supracardiac shadow can be seen with normal cardiac shadow and gives a characteristic pattern of snowman appearance/ figure of 8 in the chest.

The image given below shows x-ray findings seen in the supracardiac variety of TAPVC.


A 2D echocardiography and doppler are used for the diagnosis of TAPVC where it fails to demonstrate draining of pulmonary vein to the left atrium. The right atrium and right ventricle are often enlarged. ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy.

TAPVC is treated by emergent surgical correction. If surgery cannot be performed urgently, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation may be required to maintain oxygenation.
