questions.text: An elderly patient was referred from the medicine OPD with paranoid ideation and suspiciousness. He has also been having inappropriate outbursts of rage for the past 1 year and memory issues for the past 3 months. He is unable to dress by himself or manage his daily activities, such as cooking or cleaning. Imaging was done and the following findings were seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the scan indicating atrophy of frontal and parietal lobes are suggestive of frontotemporal dementia (FTD), one of which is Pick's disease.

Pick's disease presents with early personality changes (frontal lobe involvement) and loss of social restraints initially, followed by memory loss. By contrast, Alzheimer's patients present with memory loss first and then develop personality changes. 

Other features include loss of insight, easy distractibility, reduced concern or empathy for others, emotional lability or withdrawal, impulsiveness, poor self-care, and perseveration.

There is a second type of presentation of FTD, which is characterized by an early and progressive change in language, with problems of expression of language or severe naming difficulty, and problems with word meaning.

The classic imaging findings seen in FTD are preferential atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes with occipitoparietal sparing.

A sagittal section brain MRI is given below.

Histopathology:

  • Pick cells (swollen neurons) in affected areas of the brain
  • Pick bodies (intraneuronal argentophilic inclusions)

In the image below, the arrows point to the pick bodies in the frontal cortex.

questions.text: A patient presents to a surgeon with a complaint of bleeding per rectum. On examination, the following finding was seen. The mass did not reduce spontaneously or manually. This presentation is classified as:
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the image showing a reddish mass protruding out of the anal canal that does not reduce spontaneously or manually is suggestive of grade IV internal hemorrhoids.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, and smooth muscle fibers that are located in the anal canal. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:

  • Internal Hemorrhoids 
  • External Hemorrhoids

Management of internal hemorrhoids:

  • Bleeding from grade 1 and grade 2 hemorrhoids often improves with the addition of dietary fiber, stool softeners, increased fluid intake, and avoidance of straining.
  • Grade 1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.
  • Rubber band ligation involves pulling mucosa located 1 to 2 cm proximal to the dentate line into a rubber band applier. The rubber band strangulates the underlying tissue, causing scarring and sloughing off of the mass in a few days. 
  • Sclerotherapy involves injecting 1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) into the submucosa of internal hemorrhoids.
  • Surgery is indicated in: 
    • Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
    • Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
    • Early-grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures

Surgical procedures used in the removal of internal hemorrhoids are:

1) Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation

2) Open hemorrhoidectomy- artery forceps are applied to the skin-covered external components of the hemorrhoid and traction is given to reveal the internal components. Dissection of the lateral pedicle is performed and finally, the pedicles are transfixed. Mucocutaneous bridges are left intact in this technique. The image below shows the procedure. 

3) Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy- the hemorrhoid is excised with the overlying mucosa. The hemorrhoid is dissected from the underlying sphincter and the mucosal defect is then closed. The image below describes the procedure.

4) Stapled hemorrhoidopexy (Longo operation)- the hemorrhoids are pulled up and a purse-string suture is placed a few centimeters above the dentate line. Then, a circumferential rectal mucosectomy is performed using a circular stapler. This technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence, however, it is quick to perform, less painful, and less traumatic. The image below shows stapled hemorrhoidopexy.

Management of external hemorrhoids: 

External hemorrhoids do not require treatment unless they become thrombosed. Acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoids cause intense pain and perianal mass during the first 24 to 72 hours. Patients who present within 72 hours of thrombosis are treated with excision using an elliptical excision performed under local anesthesia.

If the patient presents to the hospital after 72 hours, then it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed.

questions.text: A young woman who recently got married presented with dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. Diagnostic laparoscopy revealed powder burn lesions as shown in the image. A sample from the lesion was sent for histopathological examination. What does the histology of the lesion represent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the powder burn appearance on diagnostic laparoscopy are suggestive of endometriosis. In endometriotic lesions, histology represents its high estrogen activity.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. The patient usually presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. The presence of puckered spots in the posterior fornix is pathognomonic of endometriosis. It is an estrogen-dependent disease of the childbearing age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary followed by the pouch of Douglas.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/ tattooing, seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas. 

The endometriotic implants histologically show certain differences when compared to the endometria of women without endometriosis. Increased estrogen production by endometriotic stromal cells, due to high levels of the enzyme aromatase, which is absent in normal endometrial stroma.

The image below shows powder burns/ tattooing appearance of endometriosis on diagnostic laparoscopy.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: Identify the nematode in the given muscle biopsy specimen.
questions.solution:
The given skeletal muscle biopsy shows Trichinella spiralis. The given muscle biopsy image shows encysted larvae of Trichinella, which is a tissue nematode and causes trichinosis.

Trichinella spiralis is typically encountered in undercooked pork. Encysted larvae of Trichinella spiralis are present in the striated muscles of its hosts.

The optimum host is the pig. Humans are dead-end hosts for trichinella. The infective form is the encysted form in the striated muscles of pigs and other animals. 

The muscles undergo basophilic degeneration with features of myositis. Patients experience malaise, diarrhea, muscle weakness, myocarditis, and encephalitis. 

Detection of spiral larva in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy. About 1 g of muscle tissue preferably near the tendon insertion is biopsied and stained with safranin. 

Bachman's intradermal test involves the injection of trichinella larval antigen intradermally. An erythematous wheal appears in positive cases within 15-20 minutes. The test remains positive for years after infection.

Treatment depends on the severity of the condition

  • Mild case - Antipyretics and analgesics 
  • Moderate cases - Albendazole or mebendazole
  • Severe cases - Glucocorticosteroids like prednisolone along with albendazole or mebendazole

Other parasites that can be demonstrated in a muscle biopsy are:

  • T. solium
  • T. cruzi (amastigote)

Other options - 

Option A: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, lives in the cecum and appendix. Infection is by ingestion of eggs or autoinfection. Detection of eggs by NIH swabs and cellophane scotch tape method. 

Option B: Trichuris trichiura is also known as whipworm. The infective form is the embryonated egg that contains a rhabditiform larva. Patients are often asymptomatic except when the worm load is heavy where the disease manifests due to mechanical effects or allergic reactions. Fecal smears show barrel-shaped ovum with mucus plug at both ends. Eggs of Trichuris trichiura are brown in color, bile stained, and float in a saturated salt solution. 

Option D: Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode infecting humans. The infective form is the embryonated egg containing rhabditiform larva. Demonstration of egg in stool or adult worm in stool or sputum is helpful in diagnosis.

questions.text: A stool sample of a person suffering from rice-water diarrhea is stained and observed under the microscope, which shows the following image. Which of the following is a selective medium for the growth of the organism shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette consisting of watery stools and the image showing the characteristic fish-in-stream appearance is suggestive of Vibrio cholerae for which Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile-Sucrose agar is the selective medium.

Selective media contain an inhibiting substance that is added to a solid medium. This inhibits the growth of commensals and favors the growth of the required bacterium. 

Vibrio cholerae is aerobic, with scanty slow growth anaerobically. Growth is better in an alkaline medium. NaCl in 0.5–1% concentration is required for optimum growth.

Vibrio colonies can be identified by the string test. A loopful of the growth is mixed with sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. If the test is positive, the suspension loses its turbidity and forms a string when the loop is slowly pulled away from the suspension.

V. cholerae causes a diarrheal disease called cholera. It presents as profuse, painless, watery diarrhea, and vomiting. The pathogenesis involves the production of the cholera toxin which attaches to GM-1 ganglioside receptors on the jejunal epithelium cells.

Option A: Thayer-Martin medium selectively favours the growth of Neisseria gonorrhoeae by inhibiting the growth of gram-positive organisms with vancomycin, gram-negative organisms with colistin, and fungi with nystatin.

The following image shows the Thayer-Martin medium.

Option C: Lowenstein-Jensen medium is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture. The presence of malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein-Jenson medium a selective medium by inhibiting other bacteria. 

The following image shows the Lowenstein-Jenson medium.

Option D: Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan (VR) medium is the transport medium for Vibrio species prepared with crude sea salt and peptone in one liter of distilled water and pH in the range of 8.6 - 8.8. In this medium, vibrios do not multiply but are viable for several weeks.

questions.text: A middle-aged hypertensive man presents with acute onset pain and swelling on his toe over the left foot. Local examination showed a swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot, as shown below. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs can be safely administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with acute onset pain and swelling over the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot suggests the diagnosis of acute gout. Losartan can be safely administered to this patient as it is a uricosuric drug.

Losartan is competitive angiotensin I (AT1) receptor antagonist, which binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. Uses of losartan are:

  • Antihypertensive
  • Renoprotective drug in diabetes mellitus
  • Stroke prophylaxis
  • Portal hypertension in cirrhosis without compromising renal function
  • Anti-aggregant as it is a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor 
  • Uricosuric drug as it inhibits reabsorption and actively secretes uric acid in the proximal convoluted tubule

Adverse effects include fetopathic potential, hypotension, renal insufficiency, and hyperkalemia. 

Other options:

Option B: Atenolol is a beta blocker that has been proven to increase serum uric acid levels; hence, it is avoided.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic; it is not used in patients with gout as it increases the uric acid level.

Option D: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes hyperuricemia due to increased reabsorption of uric acid. It is not used in patients with gout.

questions.text: Your best friend is recently worried that she has a lot of hair fall. Which of the following vitamin capsules if added to her diet can help prevent free radical injury and thus be beneficial for her??
questions.solution:
Vitamin E/ Tocopherol is a potent antioxidant and is helpful in preventing hair fall. It promotes hair growth and prevents hair roots from getting damaged by free radical injury.

Alpha-tocopherol is the active component of vitamin E and it is mainly located within cell membranes, preventing lipid peroxidation and the formation of free radicals.

Deficiency of this can also lead to neurological defects, hemolysis, and posterior column defect.

Treatment includes vitamin E supplementation (25–50 units/day for a week).

Note:

The other vitamins having antioxidant properties are vitamins A, C, and E (vitamin E is the most important).

The other vitamin beneficial in the treatment of hair fall is biotin.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man presented with a firm, non-tender scrotal mass. He was previously treated surgically for undescended testes. Immunohistochemistry was positive for KIT, OCT 3/4, and podoplanin. AFP was negative, and serum androgens were normal. Ultrasound revealed a homogenous, hypoechoic intratesticular mass. What is the histopathological finding likely to be seen?

AFP - alpha feto protein

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
The clinical case and the history of cryptorchidism point to the diagnosis of seminoma. Histopathological finding seen in seminoma is a 'fried egg appearance' of cells.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor peaking in the fourth decade. It is the equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. A history of cryptorchidism increases the risk of developing seminoma.

Generally, it presents as a nodule or painless swelling of the testis. Sometimes, there might be the presence of a dull ache or heavy sensation in the lower abdomen, or scrotum. It can metastasize to many organs like the lymph nodes, lungs, brain, and gastrointestinal tract.

It is evaluated initially by laboratory tests and ultrasound scans. Serum tumor markers including alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), are measured. Placental alkaline phosphatase can also be elevated. AFP is not elevated in pure seminomas. An ultrasound scan shows a homogeneous hypoechoic intratesticular mass. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin while it is negative for cytokeratin.

Grossly, the testis has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis as shown below.

The histological examination shows sheets of uniform cells with clear or watery cytoplasm with varying amounts of glycogen. A large central nucleus, with one or two prominent nucleoli, contributes to the 'fried egg appearance'. These sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa, containing lymphocytic infiltrate. The below image shows the histological picture of a seminoma.

Other options:

Option B: Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors and resemble endodermal sinuses. They resemble glomerulus-like structures in the visceral and parietal layer while the central core consists of capillaries. It is commonly seen in children and infants up to 3 years of age. AFP is positive. The image of Schiller Duval bodies is shown below. 

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells. They are commonly seen in children or adults. Features include testicular swelling and gynecomastia. Serum androgens and estrogens are elevated. The image of Reinke crystals is shown below.

Option D: Teratoma can be seen in infants and children after yolk sac tumors. It consists of derivatives of all three germ layers. It includes islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, etc. Ultrasonography will show a heterogeneous mass with echogenic foci due to the presence of calcification, sebum, and hair.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. The pain is restricted to the site of the fibroid. This was associated with nausea and vomiting. She also developed a fever and her WBC count was 18000/μL. Which of the following is the appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of red degeneration of the fibroid. Red degeneration in pregnancy is managed with bed rest and analgesics.

Red degeneration is a complication of fibroids that often develops during pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of fibroid resulting in ischemia and pain. It is an aseptic condition. Clinical features acute pain abdomen restricted to the site of the fibroid, fever, and vomiting. Investigations reveal an elevated WBC count and a raised ESR. Diagnosis can be made by ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with bed rest and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: Patients with all of the following conditions can develop precocious puberty, except _____.
questions.solution:
The Prader Willi syndrome presents with delayed puberty.

Prader Willi syndrome is caused due to genomic imprinting, where there is the deletion of a part of the paternal chromosome 15. The clinical features include hypotonia, childhood obesity, growth failure, dysmorphic facial features, delayed puberty, and behavioral problems.

Precocious puberty is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in females and 9 years in males.

The causes of complete isosexual precocious puberty, which is GnRH dependent include:

  • Idiopathic true precocious puberty
  • Central nervous system disorders such as hypothalamic hamartomas, encephalitis, and brain abscess.

The causes of incomplete isosexual precocious puberty are:

  • Gonadotropin (GnRH) secreting tumors
  • Increased androgen secretion by adrenal or testis such as in congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Ovarian cysts and estrogen secreting ovarian or adrenal neoplasms
  • McCune Albright syndrome

The causes of contrasexual precocity include feminization in males due to conditions such as adrenal neoplasms and chorioepithelioma, and virilization in females due to conditions such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, virilizing adrenal neoplasms and iatrogenic exposure to androgens.

questions.text: A patient with a history of acute rhinosinusitis develops Pott's puffy tumor as a complication. Identify the correct statement regarding this complication:
questions.solution:
The true statement about Pott's puffy tumor is that it is a subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.

Pott's puffy tumor is a complication of sinusitis. The acute infection of the frontal sinus either directly or through the venous spread can lead to osteomyelitis of the frontal bone. Pus may form externally under the periosteum as soft doughy swelling (Pott’s puffy tumor), or internally as an extradural abscess. It is more often seen in adults. 

Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, abscess drainage, and trephining of the frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, the removal of sequestra and necrotic bone may also be required.

Given below is an image of Pott's puffy tumor.


Other options:

Option B: Mucocele of the frontal sinus is also a complication of sinusitis. The patients present with cystic, non-tender swelling, and egg-shell crackling sign may be elicited. It is usually seen in the superomedial quadrant of the orbit. The clinical features include headache, diplopia, and proptosis. Imaging of the frontal sinus shows loss of scalloping with clouding of the sinus due to the presence of fluid. Treatment includes frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of the frontal sinus into the middle meatus.

Below is a CT image showing the frontal mucocele.


Option C: Orbital abscess is a complication of sinusitis. It usually occurs along the lamina papyracea or the floor of the frontal sinus. The clinical features would include edema of the lids, exophthalmos, chemosis of the conjunctiva, and restricted movements of the eyeball. Diagnosis is made by CT scan or ultrasound. Treatment includes antibiotics and drainage of the abscess.

Below is an image showing an orbital abscess.


Option D: Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is a complication of sinusitis. It is more commonly seen in infants and children than adults due to the presence of the spongy bone in the anterior wall of the maxilla. The clinical features include erythema, swelling of the cheek, edema of the lower eyelid, purulent nasal discharge, and fever. Bone sequestration may occur. Treatment includes antibiotics, drainage of any abscess, and removal of the sequestra.

Related Pearl: Symptoms of Sinusitis

Symptoms of maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain over the upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise and fever
  • Headache in the frontal region
  • Nasal and postnasal discharge
  • Redness and edema of cheeks
  • Tenderness on pressing over the anterior wall of the antrum

Symptoms of frontal sinusitis:

  • Frontal headache/ office headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. starts early morning and gradually increases and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding
  • Tenderness on pressing on the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge
  • Edema of the upper eyelid

Symptoms of ethmoid sinusitis:

  • Pain over the bridge of the nose and deep to the eye that is aggravated by the movements of the eyeball
  • Edema of both eyelids,
  • Nasal discharge

Symptoms of sphenoid sinusitis:

  • Headache localized to occiput or vertex
  • Postnasal discharge

questions.text: A patient was administered a Hib PRP (polyribosyl ribitol phosphate) vaccine. The production of which of the following immunoglobulins is not induced by this vaccine?
questions.solution:
The Hib polyribosyl ribitol phosphate (PRP) vaccine does not induce IgE. IgG, IgA, and IgM are induced by the capsular PRP antigen of Hib. Although the production of IgE immunoglobulins may be induced, they do not play a significant role in the immune response generated by the vaccine.

IgG, IgA, and IgM immunoglobulins are bactericidal, opsonic, and protective and hence, this antigen is employed for immunization.

This capsular antigen is unique as it helps in capsular typing. This is of medical importance as up to 95% of H. influenzae isolates from acute invasive infections such as meningitis belong to type b. 

H.influenza strains that lack a capsule are known as non-typeable strains. Non-typable H. influenza usually causes childhood otitis media, sinusitis, chronic bronchitis, puerperal sepsis, and exacerbations of COPD. Typeable H. influenza causes meningitis.

H. influenza is typed into 6 serotypes (a to f) based on the capsular polysaccharide. H. influenza b accounts for most of the invasive infections.

The differences between typable and non-typeable strains are given in the table:

  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.

  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia is posted for laser ablation surgery. Which of the following lasers is commonly used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Holmium YAG laser is commonly used for laser ablative surgery of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which involves electrocautery. Laser ablative techniques use holmium YAG commonly. Laser treatment post-surgery is useful in maintaining the hemostasis of small vessels. KTP laser is used to vaporize prostatic tissue. 

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Recurrent gross hematuria
  • Recurrent bladder stones
  • Bilateral hydronephrosis with renal functional impairment

questions.text: While karyotyping a sample of cells to look for the presence of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the dividing cells are arrested in which phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
For karyotyping, dividing cells are arrested in the metaphase in the M-phase of the cell cycle.

Chromosomes isolated from cells during the metaphase stage of mitosis are chosen for karyotyping because, it is during metaphase that the chromosomes assume their characteristic condensed, discrete shape.

The cell cycle refers to the events surrounding eukaryotic DNA replication and cell division (mitosis). The period preceding DNA replication is called the Gap 1 phase (G1). DNA replication occurs during the synthesis (S) phase. Following DNA synthesis, there is the Gap 2 phase (G2) before mitosis occurs (M). Cells that have stopped dividing, for example, T lymphocytes, have gone out of the cell cycle into the G0 phase.

There are five stages in mitosis namely prophase, prometaphase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. These occur in strictly sequential order. In metaphase, the individual chromosomes take the form of two chromatids connected at the centromere. Hence, in metaphase chromosomes can be visualized clearly during karyotyping.

The image given below shows different phases of the cell cycle:


Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukemias for exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment.

questions.text: A patient with bronchial asthma was treated with regular inhaled corticosteroids. He is now commenced on theophylline as an add-on therapy. By which of the following mechanism does this drug enhance the effect of corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Theophylline enhances the effect of corticosteroids by activation of histone deacetylase.

Theophylline activates histone deacetylase-2. The recruitment of histone deacetylase-2 by glucocorticoid receptors (GRs) switches off inflammatory genes. Through this mechanism, theophylline enhances the anti-inflammatory effects of corticosteroids.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug used in the management of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Its other mechanisms of action are as follows:

  • Inhibits phosphodiesterase non-selectively, (PDE3, PDE4, and PDE5) thereby, increasing cellular cAMP and cGMP, causing bronchodilation
  • Adenosine causes bronchoconstriction by releasing histamine and leukotrienes. Theophylline antagonizes adenosine receptors causing bronchodilation
  • Increases IL-10 release, which has an anti-inflammatory effect
  • Decreases gene transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines
  • Promotes apoptosis of granulocytes, reducing the inflammatory load in the airways

Theophylline is mainly metabolized by the enzyme CYP1A2 enzyme. Various drug interactions of theophylline include:

  • Increased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme induction) by smoking, phenytoin, rifampicin, and phenobarbitone.
  • Decreased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme inhibition) by erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, oral contraceptives, and allopurinol.

Important side effects of this drug due to PDE4 antagonism are nausea, vomiting, and gastric discomfort, and those due to adenosine A1 receptor antagonism are diuresis, cardiac arrhythmias, and seizures.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female had undergone a lower segment cesarean section. She got the skin sutures removed on the seventh postoperative day. What is the maximum percent of wound strength that can be expected after complete healing?
questions.solution:
The maximum percent of wound strength that can be expected after complete wound healing is around 80%. It does not substantially improve beyond that point.

Wound healing occurs in two distinct mechanisms - first intention/ primary union, and secondary intention/ secondary union.

Primary union is seen in cases where only the epithelial layer is injured. An example of such healing is seen in a clean surgical incision approximated by sutures.

The primary union begins with an injury that causes the activation of the coagulation cascade and subsequent clot formation. This clot attracts growth factors, cytokines, chemokines, and migrating cells. Within the first 24 hours, the neutrophils migrate to the site of injury. Within 24-48 hours, even epithelial cells from both edges of the wound begin to migrate and form a thin layer of epidermis over the wound. By day 3, neutrophils are mainly replaced by macrophages and granulation tissue starts forming. This process of neovascularisation reaches its peak on day 5. Deposition of collagen and fibroblast proliferation is seen in the second week. By the end of the first month, the scar is formed, which is made of cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells but covered by an essentially normal epidermis.

Wounds heal by secondary intention when the wound is large involving a more significant loss of cells and tissues. Since the wound is large, the blood clot formed is large. This leads to increased inflammation and increased formation of granulation tissue. The provisional matrix has fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen. In two weeks, it is replaced by type I collagen. By the end of 1 month, the scar tissue, mainly made of acellular connective tissue, is formed and myofibroblasts in it cause wound contraction.

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text: A patient presented with a passage of blood instead of urine and severe abdominal pain. Laboratory examination revealed normo-macrocytic anemia.  On further evaluation, mutation of the PIGA gene was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

It is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), which is required for the synthesis of phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG).

It is a chronic hemolytic anemia that is characterized by intravascular hemolysis. Apart from hemolysis, other features like pancytopenia and venous thrombosis are also seen. Patients may present with the passage of blood instead of urine, recurrent abdominal pain, and anemia which is normo-macrocytic.

Other options:

Option A: Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by mutations that most frequently involve ankyrin, band 3, or spectrin (i.e. inherited defects in the membrane skeleton). It is characterized by jaundice, enlarged spleen, and gallstones.

Option C: Sickle cell anemia is caused by a mutation in β-globin that creates sickle hemoglobin (HbS). It is characterized by hemolytic anemia, reticulocytosis, hyperbilirubinemia, hand-foot syndrome, acute chest syndrome (fever, cough, and chest pain), and priapism.

Option D: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency results from abnormalities affecting the G6PD enzyme. This leaves red cells vulnerable to oxidative injury and hemolysis. They mainly present with hemolytic anemia and neonatal jaundice in a few cases.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with dry eyes,  dry mouth, and difficulty swallowing solid food. Examination reveals enlargement of parotid glands and dryness of buccal mucosa. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. The histopathological image of the salivary gland is given below. All are true about this condition, except ______.

choices.text: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
Lacrimal and salivary glands are mainly involved

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is a 55-year-old female patient with dry eyes, dry mouth, difficulty swallowing solid food, and the findings such as enlarged parotid gland, dry buccal mucosa, and antibodies positive for SS-A and SS-B is Sjogren's syndrome.  The histopathology shows the focal lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the minor salivary gland. Glomerular lesions are extremely rare in Sjögren syndrome.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein the lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can manifest as primary or secondary. Primary is an isolated form known as sicca syndrome. It is characterized by decreased tears and saliva. The salivary glands and lacrimal glands get infiltrated with lymphocytes and undergo fibrosis. The secondary form is associated with other autoimmune disorders. 

Clinically, it is more common in women between 50-60 years. They present with a blurring of vision, burning, itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens- SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome. Rheumatoid factor is seen in about 75% of the patients. ANA is also often detected on immunofluorescence assay. A labial biopsy is useful and histology of salivary glands shows lymphocytic infiltration. 

Patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for tularemia?
questions.solution:
Streptomycin is the drug of choice for tularemia, a tick-borne disease caused by Francisella tularensis (aerobic gram-negative bacteria).

Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside. It may be administered by deep intramuscular injection or intravenously. Its uses include:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Plague: rapid cure in 7–12 days
  • Tularemia: tetracyclines are the alternative drugs, especially in milder cases

Aminoglycosides are used to treat infections caused by aerobic gram-negative bacteria. These are bactericidal drugs and show rapid concentration-dependent killing. The inhibitory effect persists even after the serum concentration has fallen below the minimum inhibitory concentration (postantibiotic effect). High-dose, extended-interval dosing is hence effective. They inhibit protein synthesis by acting on multiple sites on the 30s and 50s ribosomal subunits. 

Aminoglycosides need therapeutic dose monitoring because of their narrow therapeutic index. These drugs are nephrotoxic and ototoxic. The dose has to be reduced in patients with impaired renal function. 

The uses of various aminoglycoside drugs are as follows:

  • Gentamicin is used for Pseudomonas infection (in combination with 3rd generation cephalosporin) and urinary tract infection
  • Streptomycin is used as a 2nd line agent for tuberculosis and amikacin for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis 
  • Oral neomycin is used for bowel preparation before surgery

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility and underwent an endometrial biopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the secretory phase of the endometrium.

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below:

 Features in secretory phase/ luteal phase:

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day of the menstrual cycle and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • The epithelium shows subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity).
  • Characteristic corkscrew-shaped glands and edematous stroma.

The image below shows secretory endometrium

 

 Features in proliferative phase/ follicular phase:

  • It begins when the regeneration of menstruating endometrium is complete and lasts until the 14th day of the menstrual cycle.
  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.
  • The basal layer of the endometrium and functional layer become more defined.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiraled and extend through the endometrium.

The image below shows proliferative endometrium

 

Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with features mimicking appendicitis. Upon removal, the appendix is found to be grossly and histologically normal. A stool examination revealed motile gram-negative rods with a safety pin appearance. What is the etiology of this infection?
questions.solution:
It is a case of pseudo-appendicitis (appendicitis-like syndrome), caused by Yersinia enterocolitica. The picture showing bipolar staining or safety pin appearance is suggestive of Yersinia species on Wayson stain.

Yersinia enterocolitica is a gram-negative bacillus with a safety pin appearance. It causes gastroenteritis or mesenteric lymphadenitis after ingestion of contaminated food or water. 

In young children, it causes a self-limiting diarrheal illness. Patients with HLA-B27 who were infected with Y. enterocolitica develop arthralgia, arthritis, and erythema nodosum. 

Yersinia can be recovered from the stool of infected patients using selective media called CIN (Cefsulodin-Irgasan-Novobiocin) agar incubated at room temperature. Their colonies have a bull's eye appearance with a red center on CIN agar. Yersinia enterocolitica is motile at 25 °C, which differentiates it from Y. pestis which is non-motile.

Treatment for gastroenteritis caused by Y. enterocolitica consists of ciprofloxacin or a third-generation cephalosporin.

Other options : 

Option A: Clostridium difficile is a long slender gram-positive bacillus. It has large spores which are oval and subterminal. It is an opportunistic organism that rarely causes disease and does so only when normal flora is lost. It causes acute colitis with bloody or watery diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis. 

Option B: Salmonella typhi are gram-negative rods that are motile with peritrichous flagella. It causes enteric fever or typhoid fever. 

Option C: Vibrio parahaemolyticus resembles V. cholera in its morphology except that it is capsulated shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. Strains isolated from humans are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar (special high salt blood agar). This is known as the Kanagawa phenomenon. It causes food poisoning associated with marine food intake. Abdominal pain, vomiting diarrhea, and fever are the usual signs.

questions.text:
As a member of the RNTCP, you recruit a few laboratory technicians for the IRL. Which level of the RNTCP does the IRL belong to?

RNTCP: Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program
IRL: Intermediate reference laboratories
questions.solution:
The IRL belong to the level of state tuberculosis (TB) cell.

IRL is designated in either the state tuberculosis training and demonstration centres (STDC), public health laboratory, or medical college of the respective state. The functions are: 

  • Supervision and monitoring of quality assessment activities, mycobacterial culture and DST, and drug resistance surveillance (DRS).
  • Ensures the ability of staff in performing smear microscopy and provides technical training to laboratory technicians and laboratory supervisors.
  • On-site evaluation and panel testing once a year of all districts in the state.

The RNTCP was formed as the most cost-effective and systematic approach to strengthen the TB control programme in India. It adopted the internationally recommended directly observed treatment short-course (DOTS) strategy. 

The organogram of RNTCP is shown below:

Newer initiatives taken by RNTCP are: 

  • Nikshay - web-based application developed for TB surveillance
  • TB notification - it has been made mandatory that all health care workers should notify every TB case to the local authority
  • Ban on TB serology - the serological tests that have poor specificity are banned to use for the diagnosis of TB
  • Direct benefit transfer schemes - linking patients registered in Nikshay with AADHAAR for delivering benefits effectively to TB patients

RNTCP has been revised by the government of India as NTEP (national tuberculosis elimination program). The vision and goals of the NTEP program are:

  • Tuberculosis-free India with zero deaths, diseases, and poverty due to tuberculosis
  • To achieve a rapid decline in morbidity and mortality of TB cases while working towards the elimination of TB in India by 2025

NTEP has categorized and prioritized the districts in the country based on the following criteria to intensify tuberculosis control.

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with a hernia which is palpable below the inguinal ligament lateral to the pubic tubercle.  According to the NYHUS classification system, to which type does this hernia belong?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a femoral hernia. According to the NYHUS classification system, femoral hernia belongs to type III.  

Femoral hernia is distinguished from inguinal hernia by the pubic tubercle. Femoral hernia is palpable below the inguinal ligament and lateral to pubic tubercle while inguinal hernia is palpable above the inguinal ligament and medial to the pubic tubercle. They occur through a defect in the femoral ring.

A femoral hernia will pass through the femoral ring proximally. The posterior border of the femoral ring is formed by the pectineal ligament.

Relations of the femoral ring:

  • Anterior border by the inguinal ligament
  • Posterior border by the
    • Pectineal ligament
    • Superior ramus of the pubic bone
    • Pectineus muscle
  • Medial border by the lacunar ligament
  • Lateral border by the femoral vein  

The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high because of the narrowness of the neck of the sac and rigidity of the femoral ring. Diagnosis is usually made by physical examination and clinical assessment. However, in doubtful cases, Ultrasound abdomen, CT abdomen, or MRI can be done. 

Related Pearl: Nyhus classification of groin hernia

  • Type I - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring normal (e.g., pediatric hernia)
  • Type II - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated but posterior inguinal wall intact; inferior deep epigastric vessels not displaced
  • Type III - Posterior wall defect
    • A- Direct inguinal hernia
    • B - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the transversalis fascia of Hesselbach triangle (e.g., scrotal, sliding, or pantaloon hernia)
    • C - Femoral hernia
  • Type IV - Recurrent hernia
    • A - Direct
    • B - Indirect
    • C - Femoral
    • D - Combined

questions.text: A female patient with no relevant past or medication history presents to you with a rash on the cheeks and nose, oral ulcers, and multiple joint pains. Investigations showed low serum complement level. Antibody testing for which of the following is least likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The antibody test least likely to be positive in this scenario is the anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA). 

ANCAs are a group of autoantibodies involved in noninfectious vasculitis, such as microscopic polyangiitis, Churg-Strauss syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. They are useful diagnostic markers and can also be used to predict disease recurrence. The two most important ANCAs are anti-proteinase 3 and anti-myeloperoxidase.

SLE is an autoimmune disease that is seen more commonly in women. The abnormal immune response leads to the production of various forms of nucleic acids, proteins, and self-antigens. This, in turn, leads to the production of autoantibodies. In most cases, autoantibodies can be detected years before the start of clinical symptoms. The antibody deposition is then followed by complement-mediated destruction, resulting in tissue damage.

The most common rash seen in SLE is a slightly elevated, photosensitive rash seen around the cheeks and nose (butterfly rash). A few other clinical features include oral ulcers, non-scarring alopecia, and synovitis involving more than two joints. Some immunological features include ANA values more than reference negative values, the presence of Anti-Smith antibodies, low serum complement level, and positive direct Coombs test. 

The presence of at least four criteria with one from each category is a must for diagnosis of SLE, according to the 2012 Systemic Lupus International Collaborating Clinics (SLICC) classification system. 

Other options: 

Option A: The presence of anti-nuclear antibodies is the best screening test for SLE. It is seen in 98% of the cases. Repeated negative tests help to rule out the diagnosis. It has high sensitivity but poor specificity for SLE. 

Option B: Anti-ds DNA antibodies are seen in 70% of the cases. High titers are SLE specific. In a few patients, it indicates disease activity, nephritis, and vasculitis.

Option C: Anti-Smith antibodies are specific for SLE. It is seen more commonly in blacks and Asians than in whites.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has had a degenerative high axial myopia since childhood. Which of the following marked areas of the eyeball is likely to show an ectatic portion in a B-mode ultrasound scan?
questions.solution:
A degenerative high axial myopia is likely to be associated with a posterior staphyloma which is marked as point D in the above image.

Staphyloma refers to ectasia of the outer coats of the eye i.e. cornea or sclera or both, as a result of the weakening of the eyewall due to inflammation or degenerative diseases. The staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

Depending on the site affected, a staphyloma can be classified into anterior, posterior, intercalary, ciliary and equatorial staphyloma.

Posterior staphyloma refers to ectasia of the posterior pole of the eye lined by the choroid and is detected by fundoscopy and B-scan ultrasonography. The most common cause is degenerative high axial myopia. Indirect ophthalmoscopy shows a posterior outward curvature of the globe seen as a crescentic shadow in the macular region. The retinal vessels dip down into the region. The staphylomatous area appears pale due to degeneration of the retina, pigment epithelium, and occasionally the choroid. 

Anterior staphyloma is characterised by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is internally lined by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium. The most common cause is a sloughing corneal ulcer.

Equatorial staphyloma (point C) occurs in the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye due to scleritis, degenerative myopia and chronic uncontrolled glaucoma.

Intercalary staphyloma (point A) is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anteriormost part of the ciliary body. It may occur due to perforating injuries and ulcers of the peripheral cornea, anterior scleritis, scleromalacia perforans and secondary glaucoma.
 
Ciliary staphyloma (point B) is characterised by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus. It may occur due to developmental glaucoma, end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma, scleritis and ciliary trauma.

questions.text: A young female patient came with complaints of joint pain, butterfly-shaped rash on face, fever, and weight loss. Which type of hypersensitivity is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young female patient with joint pain, butterfly rash on the face, fever, and weight loss is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

The mechanism in type III hypersensitivity is as follows. Antigen-antibody complexes get deposited, which leads to activation of complements. The complements and Fc receptors recruit the leukocytes. Finally, the enzymes and molecules are released.

Histopathologically, inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis, or fibrinoid necrosis are seen in the case of type III hypersensitivity. 

This results in various manifestations like vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and arthritis in SLE.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

The image given below shows the mechanism of type III hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A patient with Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection was prescribed a parenteral cephalosporin. Within 2 hours of administering the drug, he developed an allergic reaction. The drug was stopped and later aztreonam was administered. The allergic reaction aggravated after aztreonam administration. Which cephalosporin was likely administered at first?
questions.solution:
Ceftazidime was the cephalosporin that was likely to be administered at first. Aztreonam is generally safe for penicillin-allergic patients as there is no allergic cross-reactivity with beta-lactam antibiotics, except when it comes to ceftazidime due to its structural similarities.

Other exceptions also include ceftolozane and cefiderocol, with which aztreonam is structurally similar.

Cephalosporins and cephamycins inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis. They are classified as:

  • Serious infections due to MSSA
  • Perioperative surgical prophylaxis

  • Cefoxitin/cefotetan: Gynecologic infections, perioperative surgical prophylaxis

  • Community-acquired pneumonia, meningitis, urinary tract infections
  • Streptococcal endocarditis
  • Gonorrhea

  • Nosocomial infections: Pneumonia, meningitis, urinary tract infections, intra-abdominal infections (with metronidazole)

Adverse effects include hypersensitivity, cross-resistance with beta-lactams, nephrotoxicity (cephaloridine), diarrhea (cefoperazone), hyperbilirubinemia (ceftriaxone), and significant bleeding (cefotetan, cefoperazone).

questions.text: The pinna develops from:
questions.solution:
Pinna develops both from the 1st and 2nd branchial arch. 

The development of the pinna begins from 6 weeks of embryonic life. A series of 6 tubercles are formed from the branchial arches which fuse to form the pinna. The tragus develops from the tubercle of the first arch while the rest of the pinna develops from the remaining five tubercles of the second arch. The external auditory canal develops from the first branchial cleft. 

Around 20 weeks of fetal life, the pinna attains adult shape. Initially, the pinna lies at the side of the neck but later attains a cranial position. Faulty fusion in the tubercles of two arches causes a preauricular cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in benign hypertension?
questions.solution:
Hyaline arteriosclerosis is the morphological picture seen in benign hypertension.

It is characterized by arterioles that are homogenous and show pink hyaline thickening with associated luminal narrowing. It is due to the leakage of plasma proteins in response to the chronic hemodynamic pressures of hypertension.

Malignant hypertension shows the following changes: hyperplastic arteriosclerosis (option A), onion skin appearance due to the concentric and laminated arrangement of the vessels, fibrinoid deposits (option D), and vessel wall necrosis, which are referred to as necrotizing arteriolitis.

Note: The histologic feature seen in pulmonary hypertension ranges from thickening of fibrotic intima to hyperplasia of media. These changes are appreciable in the arterioles of the affected lungs.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man underwent endoscopic aortic aneurysm repair (EVAR) 6 months back. A follow-up angiography done revealed retrograde filling of the aneurysmal sac. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type 2 endoleak. Endoleak is a complication seen in patients undergoing endovascular aortic aneurysm repair (EVAR). It is an extravasation of contrast outside the stent graft and within the aneurysm sac.

Type II endoleak refers to retrograde flow originating from a lumbar, inferior mesenteric, accessory renal, or hypogastric artery. They are the most common type of endoleak, and about half resolve spontaneously. On angiography, they are seen as a late filing of the aneurysm sac from branch vessels. Type II endoleaks are relatively benign and do not require intervention unless associated with aneurysm growth

Endoleaks are classified into 5 types:

Classification Description
Type l Leak at the site of attachment due to improper seal.
Type ll A retrograde leak from the lumbar or inferior mesenteric artery.
Type lll Junctional leak and graft fabric defect
Type lV Graft porosity leak
Type V Leak due to endotension

Endoleaks can be detected using conventional angiography, contrast CT, MRA, and color-flow duplex ultrasound. Angiography is considered the most specific for characterizing the source of the endoleak.

Patients undergoing EVAR require life-long surveillance with duplex or CT to detect endoleak and migration. High-pressure endoleaks may require repeat ballooning or a proximal cuff or distal limb extension to reseal the endograft. Complications unique to EVAR are endoleaks, migration of graft, metal strut fracture, and graft limb occlusion.

questions.text: A woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe pruritus and yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Her total bilirubin level was 3.8 mg/dL and serum transaminase levels were mildly elevated. Which of the following is not a possible complication of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. Antepartum hemorrhage is not a complication of obstetric cholestasis.

Complications of obstetric cholestasis are-

  • Spontaneous preterm births 
  • Respiratory distress syndrome in the infant
  • Sudden fetal death/ stillbirths
  • Passage of meconium and fetal distress
  • Rarely, fetal coagulopathy with intracranial hemorrhage (Can be prevented by giving Vitamin K to the mother)

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a reversible cholestatic disease that may occur later in pregnancy. It is characterized by intense pruritus, which is worse on palms and soles, and icterus. The key laboratory findings include increased serum bile acid levels, elevated transaminases, and elevated direct and total bilirubin serum concentrations.

Management:

  • Antihistamines and topical emollients 
  • Cholestyramine
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid

Ursodeoxycholic acid is the drug of choice in obstetric cholestasis. Cholestyramine causes decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, which leads to vitamin K deficiency. Fetal coagulopathy may develop, which may lead to intracranial hemorrhage and stillbirth, and therefore it is not preferred.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male asthmatic patient came to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and palpitation. The patient's vitals were stable and the ECG was performed, which is shown in the image below. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) and the drug that can be used for the termination of PSVT in this patient with bronchial asthma is verapamil. 

The mechanism of action of verapamil is by slowing SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity and it is used in both, acute treatment and prophylaxis of PSVT. Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker, which is used in exertional, variant angina, acute coronary syndrome, and heart failure.

Adverse effects include constipation, hypotension, and bradycardia with AV block with concurrent use of beta-blockers. 

Other options:

Option A: Termination of PSVT is done using adenosine, but is avoided in bronchial asthma since adenosine can cause bronchoconstriction.

Option B: Labetalol is a beta-blocker with both alpha and beta-blocking properties used in severe hypertensive crises and generally not used in PSVT.
 
Option C: QRS synchronous direct cardioversion is warranted in cases of PSVT if there is the presence of hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress.

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden onset of nausea and pain in his right eye associated with blurring of vision and halos. On examination, ciliary congestion, corneal oedema, and a mid-dilated pupil are observed. Gonioscopy reveals a closed angle of the anterior chamber. All of the following are sequelae to this episode except _____.
questions.solution:
All of the above are sequelae to this episode, except iris bombe as it is implicated in the pathogenesis of angle closure glaucoma, not a sequel.

The clinical vignette of acute onset ocular pain with nausea or vomiting, blurring of vision with halos with ciliary congestion, corneal edema, and a mid-dilated pupil on examination are all indicative of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

It is an ocular emergency that causes acute red-eye and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms: acute onset ocular pain with nausea or vomiting, intermittent blurring of vision with halos, photophobia, or loss of vision.

It is also associated with three of the following signs: ciliary congestion, corneal edema and subsequent haziness, fixed and mid-dilated, usually oval pupil, a shallow anterior chamber, and intraocular pressure elevated above 40 mmHg.

The clinical status of the eye subsequent to an attack of acute angle-closure glaucoma is considered as the sequelae of the attack, regardless of whether the patient has been treated or not. These include:

  1. Post-surgical acute primary angle-closure
  2. Spontaneous angle reopening
  3. Ciliary body shut down
  4. Vogt's triad, which includes glaukomflecken i.e anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity, patches of iris atrophy, and slightly dilated non-reacting pupil.

Iris bombe is not a part of the sequelae of acute angle-closure glaucoma. It refers to the collection of aqueous in the posterior chamber pushing the peripheral flaccid iris anteriorly resulting in appositional angle closure.

The below image shows features of angle closure glaucoma.

The management of acute angle-closure glaucoma includes:

  • Immediate medical management to lower IOP- oral acetazolamide or intravenous mannitol is used first. Tricyclic antidepressants, drugs having significant anticholinergic action should be avoided or used with extreme caution in patients prone to developing acute angle-closure glaucoma.

  • Prophylaxis of the fellow eye followed by long-term glaucoma surveillance and management of intraocular pressure of both eyes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about tramadol?

choices.text: Maximum recommended daily dose is 400 mg
Tramadol-induced respiratory depression is reversed by naloxone
For mild-to-moderate pain, morphine is more effective than tramadol
Peak action is seen within 2-3 hours and lasts for about 6 hours

questions.solution:
For the treatment of mild-to-moderate pain, tramadol is as effective as morphine or meperidine. However, for the treatment of severe or chronic pain, tramadol is less effective.

Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog that acts as a mu-opioid receptor agonist. It also acts by inhibiting the uptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. The action peaks within 2–3 hours of oral dosing. The duration of analgesia is about 6 hours.

The maximum recommended daily dose is:

  • 400 mg for adults
  • 300 mg in patients >75 years old
  • 200 mg for patients with low creatinine clearance

Adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, dizziness, dry mouth, sedation, headache and respiratory depression. Tramadol-induced respiratory depression is reversed by naloxone. Tramadol can exacerbate seizures in patients with predisposing factors. Tramadol should be avoided in patients taking MAO inhibitors, SSRIs, or other drugs that lower the seizure threshold.

Clinical relevance: Precipitation of withdrawal necessitates that tramadol is tapered prior to discontinuation.

questions.text: On examination of a dead body, the forensic medical officer-in-charge notices the following finding. What will be his inference in this case?
questions.solution:
The image shows postmortem hypostasis.

Postmortem hypostasis/ postmortem staining/ postmortem lividity/ livor mortis/ Suggillation refers to purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependent parts of the body. The margins are clearly defined and there is no swelling or abrasion.

Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6-12 hours after death. It occurs earlier in summer and is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.  

The timeline for development of postmortem staining:

  • Mottled patches– 1-3 hours following the death
  • Uniform area of staining– 3-6 hours following the death
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis– 6-12 hours following the death

Other options:

Option A: The image below shows postmortem lividity with bright cherry red discoloration seen in carbon monoxide poisoning.

Option C: Postmortem marbling occurs due to the hemolysis of the blood in the vessels, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Option D: Adipocere, also called corpse wax, grave wax, or mortuary wax, is a wax-like organic substance formed by the anaerobic hydrolysis of fat in tissue by bacteria. It forms under warm and humid weather due to the hydrolysis of lipids. It has a whitish or yellowish appearance and has a distinctive offensive or sweetish smell.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman was evaluated for uterine bleeding. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a swiss-cheese pattern. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Swiss-cheese pattern in histopathological examination of endometrium in a premenopausal woman is suggestive of metropathia haemorrhagica. It is characterized by massive painless vaginal bleeding.

Metropathia haemorrhagica/ Cystic glandular hyperplasia/ Schroeder's disease: It is a specialized type of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding, usually seen in premenopausal women (40 to 45 years). Typically patients complain of continuous painless vaginal bleeding. It can occur after 6-8 weeks of amenorrhea or can be preceded by a period of menorrhagia.

The uterus becomes bulky due to symmetrical enlargement. The endometrium is thickened, and thin polypi project into the uterine cavity. There is also mild degree of myohyperplasia of the uterine wall. Ovaries may contain cysts, but the corpus luteum is absent.

Microscopy reveals:

  • Swiss cheese pattern of cystic glandular hyperplasia.
  • Absence of secretory endometrium- since the bleeding is anovulatory, there is no progesterone and hence no secretory changes in the endometrium. so the cork-screw glands are not seen.
  • Endometrium shows superficial necrosis resembling that of the first day of menstruation.

If the patient has a preceding history of amenorrhea, it can be confused with ectopic pregnancy or abortion. However, painless vaginal bleeding is the clue to differentiation.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with pain in his knee for the past month. He is an avid basketball player. The pain increases during activity, but is not seen at rest. On examination, there is a swelling anterior and distal to the knee joint line. There is pain on extension against resistance. X-ray of the knee shows the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiographic image shows traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter disease.

Osgood-Schlatter disease refers to apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity that occurs due to persistent traction on the tibial tuberosity. The condition is associated with overuse and is often seen in those playing basketball and volleyball frequently. The common age group is 12-15 years in boys, while 9-13 years in girls. They present with pain and swelling over the tibial tubercle. 

Radiographic findings include

  • Widening of the physis between the apophysis and proximal tibia
  • The tibial tubercle apophysis is irregular
  • Apophysis gets fragmented

Other options:

Option A: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is a similar clinical condition to Osgood-Schlatter disease, but it affects the inferior portion of the patella. It is characterized by pain in the superior portion of the patellar tendon. Early radiographic findings are subtle or absent. Thickening of the proximal patellar tendon may be seen.

Option C: Hoffa’s disease is the impingement and inflammation of the infrapatellar fat pad. It is characterized by anterior knee pain. The radiographic image shows increased density in the infrapatellar pad of fat or Hoffa's fat pad.

Option D: Osteochondritis dissecans is a condition characterized by an area of subchondral bone that becomes necrotic and the cartilage overlying it undergoes degenerative changes. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies. On a radiograph, they appear as oval lucent areas adjacent to the articular margin.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with seizures, atresia of the ear canal, and blindness. His history is significant for buphthalmos for which surgical correction was attempted. Motor examination reveals cerebellar dysfunction. His MRI image is given below. The child is deficient in which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with MRI showing corpus callosum agenesis is suggestive of Walker-Warburg syndrome. It is associated with a deficiency in α-dystroglycan.

Walker-Walburg syndrome is a rare inherited disorder occurring due to a deficiency in α-dystroglycan, a glycoprotein. Several gene mutations are involved in this condition. A few include B3GALNT2, B4GAT1, DAG1, and FKRP. 

The clinical features manifest mainly in the eyes, brain, and muscles. These include blindness, buphthalmos, cerebellar dysplasia, cleft lip, hydrocephalus, lissencephaly (type-II radiologically), and muscular dystrophy resulting in a significant delay in reaching developmental milestones.

Clinical suspicion after ruling out other disorders is important. CT/ MRI brain can show enlarged ventricles, agenesis of the corpus callosum, and creatine kinase (CK) levels are raised. Muscle biopsy reveals muscle damage. The diagnosis can be confirmed with genetic testing. 

The image given below shows MRI showing agenesis of the corpus callosum seen in Walker-Walburg syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with leukemia presents with complaints of painful penile erection. The doppler findings revealed absent blood flow in the penis. Which of the following is the first step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of low flow/ ischaemic priapism. The first step of management is the aspiration of sludged blood in the corpora cavernosa.

Persistent erection of the penis lasting more than 4 hours is defined as priapism. Ischemic priapism is an emergency. Low flow priapism or ischemic priapism is characterized by painful erection of the penis due to decreased supply of oxygen to the penis resulting in ischemia. This can be confirmed with doppler findings which reveal absent blood flow in the penis.

The first step of management involves aspiration of sludged blood in the corpora cavernosa. If the symptoms do not get relieved, intracavernosal injection of phenylepinephrine is given. If this modality also fails, then a shunt is placed surgically between either the glans (Winter shunt) or the corpus spongiosum (Quackel's shunt).

A 52-year-old female presents with complaints of fatigue and severe itching throughout her body. On investigation, serum GGT and ALP levels were found to be elevated with a mild elevation in AST and ALT levels. The histopathological image of her liver biopsy is given below. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be present in this patient?

GGT- Gamma glutamyl transferase
ALP- Alkaline phosphatase
AST- Aspartate aminotransferase
ALT- Alanine aminotransferase

choices.text: Antibodies to Liver Kidney microsomes type 1

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with the presence of florid duct lesions on histopathology is indicative of primary biliary cholangitis. The antibodies most likely to be present in PBC are anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA).

Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by portal inflammation and necrosis of cholangiocytes in small and medium-sized bile ducts. It has a strong female preponderance with a median age of 50 years.

The most common symptoms include fatigue that is out of proportion to the severity of the liver disease or the patient's age and pruritus, which is usually most bothersome in the evening. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease, including hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites, and edema are found to be present.

Amond the liver enzymes, GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. The majority of the patients show anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA) positive. A liver biopsy shows a florid duct lesion. This occurs due to the destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation.

Liver transplantation is indicated in patients with decompensated cirrhosis due to PBC. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line drug that helps to slow down the rate of progression of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Anti Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibody (ANCA) is seen in autoimmune vasculitis.

Option B: Antibodies to Liver Kidney microsomes type 1 (anti-LKM1) are characteristic of autoimmune hepatitis.

Option D: Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) may be seen in PBC, but the most common is an Anti-Mitochondrial Antibody (A). AМΑ is the serologic hallmark of PBC. It is present in approximately 95 percent of patients with ΡBС. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are found in up to 70 percent of patients with РBC.
