questions.text: The ECG of a patient with systemic hypothermia is given below. The findings marked in the image are described as:
questions.solution:
The Osborn wave (J wave) is a positive deflection seen at the J point in precordial and true limb leads as seen in the given electrocardiogram. It is most commonly associated with hypothermia.

Osborn waves may be seen in the ECG of patients with systemic hypothermia. They are observed as a hump-like elevation at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment. An alteration in the ventricular transmural action potential is attributed to their appearance on an ECG.

The J wave can be accentuated in hypothermia and hypercalcemia. Spontaneous accentuation of the J wave may predispose to ventricular arrhythmias (polymorphic VT and VF).

Other options:

Option A: Delta wave is the slurred upstroke of the QRS complex as seen during ventricular pre-excitation, a feature of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. 

 

Option C: Epsilon wave is representative of T wave inversion and delayed ventricular activation as seen in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC).

 

Option D: Saw-tooth wave is seen in atrial flutter. It is caused due to repetitive atrial excitation caused by large re-entry impulses circulating within the atrial myocardium.

questions.text: A young American is planning an international trip to India. He asks his family doctor about the yellow fever vaccination for his infant. From what age is the yellow fever vaccination certificate mandatory?
questions.solution:
The yellow fever vaccination certificate is mandatory for infants ≥9 months.

A yellow fever vaccination certificate is mandatory for travellers coming from endemic areas like America and African countries to India. A live attenuated, 17D strain vaccine is administered subcutaneously to the populations at risk. 

The vaccination must be given at an officially designated centre, and the certificate must be validated with the official stamp of the Indian Ministry of Health. Its validity begins after 10 days from the date of vaccination. It is valid only if it is met with the standards of the model prescribed under international health regulations.

The validity was for 10 years before, but now it is extended to lifelong after the introduction of the amendment in the World Health Assembly. If there is no certificate available, the traveller is advised to quarantine for 6 days starting from the day they left the infected area. 

Yellow fever is a zoonotic disease caused by an Arbovirus called Flavivirus fibricus. It is transmitted to man through the Aedes mosquito. The incubation period is 6 days. Clinical features are similar to hemorrhagic fevers which include jaundice, epistaxis, and melena with severe hepatic and renal involvement. 

India is a yellow fever receptive area. It is called so because we do not have yellow fever in India but conditions will allow its development if it is introduced. The virus reaches India through travellers from the infected areas and from mosquitoes that arrive through ships and aircraft from infected areas.

questions.text: A young boy presents with a diminution of vision. He is fair, has elongated limbs, and is tall for his age. A slit-lamp examination revealed bilateral inferonasal dislocation of the lens. Which of the following is not useful in treating this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of classic homocystinuria. Methionine is not used in treating homocystinuria.

Classic homocystinuria is a disorder of methionine metabolism. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. It occurs due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase.

Cystathionine beta-synthase is a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme that combines homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine. The absence of this enzyme results in the accumulation of homocysteine which eventually gets excreted in urine causing homocystinuria.

The images given below show the synthesis of cysteine from homocysteine.

Individuals with homocystinuria present with inferonasal subluxation of the optic lens (vs supratemporal in Marfan syndrome), intellectual disability, psychiatric and behavioral disorders, and skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome,i.e, tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly (slender fingers).

Children usually have fair complexions, blue eyes, and a peculiar malar flush. A spine X-ray typically shows generalized osteoporosis. Homocysteine causes activation of Hageman’s factor (factor 12). This results in increased platelet adhesiveness causing thromboembolic events.

The image below shows arachnodactyly.

The cyanide nitroprusside test can be used to detect the presence of homocysteine in urine.

Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

Vitamin B6 is the co-factor for the enzyme cystathionine-β-synthase. Hence vitamin B6 should be supplemented in high doses.

Betaine lowers homocysteine levels in body fluids by remethylating homocysteine to methionine. Hence, it is used in the treatment of homocystinuria in patients who are unresponsive to vitamin B6 therapy.

Vitamin B12 is the cofactor for the enzyme methionine synthase, which catalyzes the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. Hence Vitamin B12 can be supplemented.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following type of choledochal cyst, would you advise endoscopic sphincterotomy?
questions.solution:
A type III choledochal cyst is the cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles. Patients with type III choledochal cyst are managed with endoscopic sphincterotomy. 

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the extrahepatic and/or intrahepatic biliary tree. Females are more commonly affected than males. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain.

Diagnosis is confirmed using ultrasound abdomen but ERCP or MRCP is required to analyze the anatomy of the cyst, classify the type, and plan the surgical procedure accordingly. 

Choledochal cysts are classified according to the Todani Classification, and the management for each type is summarized in the table below:

Type of choledochal cyst  Management

Type I 

 
  • Excision of the cyst with cholecystectomy
  • Reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

Type II
  • Excision of the diverticulum with cholecystectomy
  • Suturing of the CBD wall
  • Reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy can be done

Type III (choledochocele)
  • Endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is preferred
  • Cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy can be done

Type IV
  • Extrahepatic- cyst excision and Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure)
  • Intrahepatic- segmental resection of the liver by hepatectomy
  • Lily’s operation- if the cyst is adherent to the portal vein posteriorly, that part of cyst wall is left behind but mucosa of the part is removed
  • Definitive- liver transplantation

Type V (Caroli disease)
  • Liver transplantation

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child with weakness of limbs and difficulty in walking was evaluated. Serum creatinine kinase was elevated. A sex-linked recessive mode of inheritance was seen.  What is the condition the boy is suffering from?
questions.solution:
A 3-year-old male child with limb weakness, difficulty walking, elevated creatinine kinase, and sex-linked inheritance is likely to suffer from Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

It is an X-linked recessive disease and is due to a mutation in a structural protein called dystrophin. Males are commonly affected. They are normal at birth. Symptoms of weakness gradually develop and are often characterized by delayed walking, clumsiness, and inability to keep up with peers. 

Pelvic girdle muscles are affected and this is followed by shoulder girdle weakness. Muscles of the lower leg are weak but enlarged, described as pseudohypertrophy. Other features include cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, and intellectual disability.

Serum creatine kinase is markedly elevated. Supportive treatment is needed. 

Other options:

Option A: Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting multiple systems. It is associated with skeletal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrinopathy, and cardiomyopathy.

Option B: A limb-girdle dystrophy is a heterogeneous group characterized by autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant types. It is characterized by proximal muscle weakness with variable age of onset and severity

Option C: Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant type characterized by weakness of facial muscles and shoulder girdle.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation with bleeding per vagina had a miscarriage. The products of conception are sent for appropriate tests. Which of the following is not a disposal option for the same?
questions.solution:
Encapsulation is not a disposal option for human anatomical waste. It is a disposal technique used for expired and discarded medicines along with chemical wastes. 

Human anatomical waste such as an aborted fetus is put in a yellow bag and is disposed of by either incineration, plasma pyrolysis, or deep burial. 

The biomedical waste management rule is applicable to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorised and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A color coding system with 4 colors namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then disposed of by various methods. They are:

  • Incineration - this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection - chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes. 
  • Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process. 
  • Microwave irradiation - microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely. 
  • Land disposal - either municipal disposal sites or sanitary landfills are used. 
  • Inertization - waste is mixed with cement and other substances before disposal to reduce toxicity. 

Disposal by deep burial is permitted only in rural areas which lack common bio-medical treatment facilities. Permission from the concerned authority is needed and guidelines issued by the central pollution control board should be followed.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman often says that her nose is "too fat" and she looks ugly. Because of this, she has stopped going out with friends. She spends almost half a day staring at herself in the mirror despite her husband's reassuring efforts that she is beautiful. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of preoccupation about the appearance of her nose associated with performing compulsive acts, like checking in the mirror, is suggestive of body dysmorphic disorder.

Body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) is one of the obsessive-compulsive spectrum disorders as per DSM-5 (diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders). It is characterised by impairing and distressing preoccupations about an imagined defect or overemphasis on a slight defect in one’s appearance. This causes significant emotional distress and impairment in the patient's functioning.

In response to their appearance concerns, individuals with BDD may perform compulsive acts like excessive grooming, and constantly checking in the mirror. Some patients also perform mental acts such as comparing their appearance to that of other people. They may avoid social gatherings which can range up to being housebound. 

Patients with BDD can be treated with serotonin-specific drugs such as clomipramine and fluoxetine. 

Other options:

Option A: Social anxiety disorder or social phobia specifically involves the fear of social situations. Patients with this disorder are usually scared of embarrassing themselves in social situations. 

Option C: Somatic symptom disorder or hypochondriasis is characterized by the presence of general and non-delu­sional preoccupation for ≥6 months with fears of having a serious disease. This is based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. These preoccupied thoughts cause significant distress and impairment in one's life.

Option D: Factitious disorder is an intentional attempt to produce, stimulate or aggravate an illness to gain medical attention. The primary intention is not financial gains or avoidance of duties here.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented to the casualty with the following injury. Identify the type of wound.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a spindle-shaped incised wound. 

An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument, through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width.

The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is more at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

Other options:

Option B: A laceration is a tear or a split in the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ produced by blunt force. They are also termed tears or ruptures. Margins are irregular and ragged. Tears that are seen at the ends, diverging away from the main laceration are called swallow-tails. Bruising is seen around the wound.

The below image shows a lacerated wound.

Option C: Incised-like lacerated wounds are seen at sites where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue. A blunt force causes linear splitting of the tissue which results in the laceration resembling an incised wound. There will be extensive tissue crushing but the margins will be clear and delineable. The common sites are the scalp, forehead, eyebrows, zygoma, lower jaw, perineum, shin, and iliac crest.

The image below shows an incised-like lacerated wound.

Option D: A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc into the depth of the body. Margins of the wound are clean cut and inverted. The internal depth is usually equal to or less than the length of the blade used to produce it. 

Below is the image showing the fish-tail appearance of stab wounds.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasms a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The microscopic image of the causative organism is shown below. Which of the following is not indicated in the treatment of infection with the following organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of generalized muscle spasms following a puncture wound with the given image showing Clostridium tetani suggests a diagnosis of tetanus. Hyperbaric oxygen is not indicated in the treatment of tetanus. 

The image shows slender, gram-positive bacilli with terminal spores that are spherical, bulging, and have a drumstick appearance, typical of Clostridium tetani. It is the causative agent of tetanus.

The treatment of tetanus involves cleaning and debridement of necrotic material in the wound. Metronidazole (400 mg rectally or 500 mg IV every 6 h for 7 days) is preferred for antibiotic therapy. Antitoxin should be given early to deactivate any circulating tetanus toxin and prevent its uptake into the nervous system. Two preparations are available- human tetanus immune globulin (TIG) and equine antitoxin. TIG is the preparation of choice, as there is a lower chance of anaphylaxis. A single IM dose (500–5000 IU) is given, with a portion injected around the wound.

Clostridium tetani secrete 2 types of toxins, namely, tetanolysin and tetanospasmin. Of these, tetanospasmin has been implicated in the pathogenesis of tetanus.

Tetanospasmin acts pre-synaptically and specifically blocks synaptic inhibition in the spinal cord, at inhibitory terminals that use glycine and GABA as neurotransmitters. This abolition of spinal inhibition causes the uncontrolled spread of impulses initiated everywhere in the central nervous system. This results in muscle rigidity and spasms due to the simultaneous contraction of agonists and antagonists, in the absence of reciprocal inhibition.

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is indicated in gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens.

questions.text: Mapleson's circuit includes types A, B, C, D, E, and F.  Which of the following is the correct order of efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation?
questions.solution:
The efficiency of  Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A. 

The performance of the Mapleson circuit is best studied in the expiratory phase of the respiratory cycle. The efficiency of the Mapleson circuit is determined by the inflow rate required to prevent rebreathing of CO2.

The DEF systems are more efficient than the BC systems. To prevent rebreathing, BC systems require a higher rate of fresh gas inflow than DEF systems. This is because of the pop-off valve present near the fresh gas inflow in BC systems. A significant amount of fresh gas gets vented out through this valve at the end of expiration. In DEF systems, fresh gas flow pushes the exhaled alveolar gas away from the patient and thus reduces rebreathing of CO2.

For Mapleson A circuits, in controlled ventilation, significant rebreathing of CO2 occurs. To prevent this, a very high fresh gas inflow (>20 L/min) is required for Mapleson A. The pop-off valve vents out a significant amount of fresh gas during the inspiratory phase. Thus, Mapleson A has the worst efficiency in controlled ventilation.

During spontaneous breathing, Mapleson A has the best efficiency. During spontaneous ventilation, exhaled alveolar gas is vented through the pop-off during expiration. When the patient inspires, fresh gas is mainly taken in. 

The efficiency of  Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB.

Remember:

A > DFE > CB : A Dog Can Bite (Usually a spontaneous event)

DFE > BC > A : Dancing Babies can't assist (controlled)

questions.text: A baby is brought to the OPD with a deformity in the hip and lower limbs. On examination, there is an asymmetry of the groin crease and a click sound is heard on moving the left hip.  The following test is done and found to be positive. Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and a positive Galeazzi's test as shown in the above image are suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The female sex of the baby is a risk factor for developing this condition.

Galeazzi's test is done between 3 to 8-month-aged children in unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). To perform this test, the child is in the supine position with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both knee joints is noted with respect to a horizontal line. Normally both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen at a lower level indicating femoral shortening.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. Risk factors for DDH include:

  • Sex of the baby- females are more susceptible to DDH due to the action of maternal relaxin on the fetal joints in-utero predisposing it to dislocation. It is 3-5 times more common in females.
  • Intrauterine positioning- breech position is associated with a higher incidence of DDH
  • Genetic predisposition- DDH is more common in children of parents who had DDH themselves.
  • First born child

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip:

1) Newborn to 3 months of age. Tests to check instability of the hip:

  • Asymmetrical skin creases in the inguinal, gluteal, and thigh regions.
  • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk". 
  • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk".

2) At 3-6 months of age:

  • Galeazzi's test 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.

3) In children of walking age:

  • Trendelenburg gait
  • Positive tredelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

questions.text: The CT of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a lesion of 6 cm, extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of cervical carcinoma is II B as it involves the upper part of the vagina and parametrium.

questions.text:
A medical officer working at a PHC refers complicated cases to a secondary or tertiary hospital. This way of development of referral services was established by which committee?

PHC: Primary health center
questions.solution:
The development of referral services from the PHC to the secondary or tertiary hospitals was established by the Shrivastav committee. 

The Shrivastav committee was started by the ministry of health and family planning. Its goals were to provide training to health assistants that can be the link between the medical practitioners and multipurpose workers to form an effective health care team. It also suggested steps to improve the medical educational process based on the national requirements. 

The committee recommended that at least one male and female health care worker should be available for every 5000 population. For every two male and two female health care workers, one male and one female health assistant should be available at the sub-centre level.

As part of this committee, bands of para-professional and semi-professional health workers were formed. These individuals were part of the community already as postmasters and school teachers. They were trained to provide simple preventive and curative services to the community.  

Other options: 

Option A: The Chadah committee outlined the responsibility of block-level PHCs in the national malaria eradication program. They recommended one basic health worker for every 10,000 population. 

Option C: The Jungalwalla committee recommended the integration of health services from the highest to the lowest level and the elimination of private practice by government doctors. 

Option D: The Mudaliar committee recommended that district hospitals be strengthened by adding specialist services. They also added regional deputy and assistant directors to supervise district medical and health officers. They limited the population served by each primary health centre to 40,000.

questions.text: An elderly obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of severe chest pain for the last two hours. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left arm, nausea, and one episode of vomiting.  On examination, pulse rate is 58/min and BP is 90/60 mmHg. His ECG is shown below. Cardiac biomarkers showed elevated troponin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is inferior wall MI based on the given presentation of chest pain, bradycardia (pulse rate 58/min), hypotension (BP 90/60 mm Hg), elevated cardiac biomarkers, and ECG changes (ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, aVF, with reciprocal change in lead aVL). 

Inferior wall MI mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. questions.text:
A 25-year-old man with HIV infection was started on the anti-retroviral drug abacavir. Which of the following side effect should be specifically anticipated in this patient?

HIV: Human immunodeficiency virus
questions.solution:
Fatal hypersensitivity syndrome is a side effect specifically anticipated while using the antiretroviral agent abacavir.

Abacavir-associated hypersensitivity syndrome is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal upset, maculopapular rash, and malaise. The presence of these symptoms within 6 weeks of starting abacavir is diagnostic and necessitates immediate discontinuation of the drug.

Abacavir is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) approved for the treatment of HIV-1 infection. It acts as a guanosine analog, which terminates the elongation of proviral DNA.

The adverse effects of some other antiretroviral agents are as follows:

  • Didanosine and stavudine (NRTIs) - peripheral neuropathy, pancreatitis, and hepatic steatosis
  • Zidovudine (NRTI)- anemia, hepatic steatosis, myopathy, nail hyperpigmentation
  • Lamivudine (NRTI) - least toxic; neutropenia at higher than recommended doses
  • Tenofovir (nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor) - well tolerated; rarely acute renal failure, Fanconi syndrome
  • Indinavir (protease inhibitor) - nephrolithiasis, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and insulin resistance
  • Ritonavir (protease inhibitor) - lipodystrophy

Other options:

Option A: Nephrolithiasis is a side effect of indinavir due to poor solubility of the drug resulting in crystalluria.

Options B: Fanconi syndrome is a rare side effect of the antiretroviral drug, tenofovir.

Option C: Pancreatitis is the side of the antiretroviral drugs didanosine and stavudine.

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir

  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz

  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir

  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

questions.text: A 3-month-old female child was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. On examination,  generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. A muscle biopsy is performed and the findings are attached in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme that is involved in the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
The muscle biopsy shows the presence of large vacuoles. This along with the clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of Pompe's disease or type II glycogen storage disease. It is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase.

Clinically, the child presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The affected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure.

Investigations include chest X-ray imaging which shows cardiomegaly. The muscle biopsy showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis. 

Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa (Myozyme).

questions.text: A young woman with 10 weeks of amenorrhea, presents with complaints of heavy vaginal bleeding. On examination, an open cervical os with tissue protruding is seen. Ultrasonography reveals echogenic material in the uterine cavity, no adnexal masses, no free fluid, and no viable pregnancy. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient has an incomplete abortion and the most appropriate management would be to evacuate the contents of the uterus with dilatation and curettage.

The patient can present with complaints of the expulsion of fleshy mass per vagina, continuous vaginal bleeding, and abdominal cramps. Internal examination reveals open cervical os, and products of conception protruding out of the cervix. Ultrasonography reveals echogenic material (retained products of conception) within the cavity and no viable pregnancy. There are no adnexal masses, and no free fluid found on ultrasonography, ruling out ectopic pregnancy. All this confirms the diagnosis of incomplete abortion. 

Incomplete abortion can be managed surgically, or medically. The surgical method is by dilatation and curettage, it has the least failure rate and gives a quick resolution. For medical management of incomplete abortion at <13 weeks gestation, use of 600 μg misoprostol administered orally or use of 400 μg misoprostol administered sublingually, is recommended.

Note- For medical management of incomplete miscarriage, the use of 400–800 μg vaginal misoprostol has been removed in the updated recommendation from the WHO 2012 Safe abortion guidance (6).

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Takayasu arteritis?

choices.text: Predominantly a disease of small vessel
Coronary arteries are more commonly involved
Panarteritis with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates

questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis is a panarteritis (inflammation involving all layers of the vessel wall) with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasional giant cells.

Takayasu arteritis (or pulseless disease) is a granulomatous vasculitis of medium- and large-sized arteries predominantly affecting the aortic arch and its branches. The pulmonary artery may also be involved.

It is most prevalent in Asians and young women, usually below 50 years of age. It is a systemic disease and may present with generalized and vascular symptoms. Generalized symptoms like fever, night sweats, weight loss, malaise, arthralgias, and anorexia, may occur long before vascular symptoms.

The order of arteries affected in Takayasu arteritis is subclavian artery > common carotid artery > abdominal aorta > renal artery > aortic arch = vertebral > coeliac axis > iliac > pulmonary > coronary artery. Vascular symptoms depend on the vessel involved: 

Subclavian artery (most commonly affected)

 Weak pulses in the upper extremities. Hence it is also known as pulseless disease. May also lead to Raynaud’s phenomenon

Carotid arteries

  Weak pulses, blindness,   and neurological deficits

Aortic arch

  Congestive heart failure
Abdominal aorta, coeliac axis, and superior mesenteric artery  Abdominal pain, nausea,   and vomiting
Iliac vessels  Claudication of the legs
Renal arteries  Systemic hypertension
Pulmonary artery  Pulmonary hypertension
Coronary arteries (least commonly affected)  Myocardial infarction

Histopathology shows irregular vessel wall thickening with associated intimal hyperplasia with granulomatous inflammation, giant cells, and patchy medial necrosis. The disease progresses with collagenous scarring and chronic inflammatory infiltration across all layers of the vessel wall.

The diagnosis is made by a strong clinical suspicion and confirmed with arteriography which shows irregular vessel walls, stenosis, post stenotic dilation, aneurysms, and increased collateral circulations. Differential diagnoses include Giant cell arteritis (age >50 years) and IGG4-related disease (dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate rich in IgG4-positive plasma cells, a storiform pattern of fibrosis, and obliterative phlebitis).

The combination of glucocorticoid therapy and surgical and/or arterioplastic approach to stenosed vessels has decreased morbidity. Treatment-refractory patients are managed with methotrexate, tocilizumab, and cyclophosphamide.

questions.text: What is the best position for the patient to be in while inserting the given tube for enteral feeds?
questions.solution:
The given image is Ryle's tube. The best position for this patient during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

Nasogastric tube/ Ryle's tube is used to provide enteral feeds. It is also used to diagnose the patency of the esophagus in conditions like tracheoesophageal fistula. If enteral feeds are continued for more than a week then a fine bore tube is used. 

It is inserted by standing perpendicular to the patient and the distance is calculated using the NEX method.

NEX method:
  • The tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum.
  • The tube length should be estimated before insertion.
  • Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend tube to the earlobe, and then to xiphisternum.

Confirmation of the correct position is done by auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air and X-ray chest. 

Approximate length: 120-125 cm

Markings indicating traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach:

1) 40 cm - Traversed cardia of the stomach

2) 50 cm - Traversed body of stomach

3) 60 cm - Traversed pylorus

4) 70 cm - Tube has traversed Duodenum

Indications for NG tube:

  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression in cases of intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in acid-induced diarrhea that is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions 
  • Feeding
  • Administration of medication
  • Bowel irrigation

Contraindications for NG tube:

  • Absolute:
    • Severe midface trauma
    • Recent nasal surgery
    • Basilar skull fractures
  • Relative:
    • Coagulation abnormality
    • Caustic ingestion
    • Esophageal trauma/ obstruction
    • Esophageal varices
    • Recent banding of esophageal varices
    • Anastomoses in the stomach and esophagus

questions.text: A child with progressive cyanosis was brought to the hospital. The chest radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a cyanotic heart disease and the chest X-ray shows a box-shaped heart with oligemic lung fields. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Ebstein’s anomaly.

Ebstein's anomaly is a congenital anomaly of the tricuspid valve wherein there is downward displacement of the abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. This leads to tricuspid regurgitation and atrialization of the right ventricle.

It is usually associated with an atrial septal defect. In severe cases, there is right-to-left shunting at the atrial level with subsequent cyanosis. In newborns marked cyanosis, massive cardiomegaly and holosystolic murmurs are seen. 

On the chest radiograph, Ebstein’s anomaly leads to a grossly enlarged cardiac contour and a prominent curved right atrial border, appearing as a box-shaped enlargement of the heart. In newborns with severe disease, the pulmonary fields may be totally obscured. Echocardiography is diagnostic. It provides the degree of tricuspid valve displacement, dilatation of the right atrium, and any right ventricular obstruction if present.

Other options: 

Option B: Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPV) presents with severe cyanosis and respiratory distress. The radiograph shows a snowman appearance or figure of 8 configurations of heart.

Option C: Transposition of great arteries (TGA) can present from birth to infancy with cyanosis, decreased exercise tolerance, and poor physical development. Radiography shows the egg-on-string appearance of the heart. 

Option D: Tricuspid atresia also presents also with cyanosis at birth and holosystolic murmur along the left border of the sternum. Cyanosis with left axis deviation on ECG is suggestive of tricuspid atresia. 2D Echo shows a fibromuscular membrane in place of the tricuspid valve, small right ventricle, an enlarged left ventricle, and a VSD.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not suggestive of antemortem hanging?

choices.text: Multiple bruises on neck with absence of vital reaction
Dilation of one eye and other eye being closed
Area of hypostasis limited to legs and hands with a pale face

questions.solution:
In the case of antemortem hanging, injuries are associated with the presence of a vital reaction. 

Eyes may show the following findings in antemortem hanging:

  • La facies sympathique- in case of hanging, one of the eyes may be opened with dilated pupil, while the other eye may be closed. This occurs due to the pressure of the ligature knot on the cervical sympathetic ganglia in the neck. Thus, on the side on which the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic ganglia, the eye remains open with dilatation of its pupil. It is a sign of antemortem hanging.
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhages
  • Prominent eyeballs

Other findings seen in antemortem hanging:

  • Post-mortem hypostasis- present in the legs and hands
  • Petechial hemorrhages- these are usually the exception, rather than the rule
  • In most cases the face is pale, in some cases it may be congestion due to venous occlusion
  • Ligature mark- above the thyroid cartilage and incomplete
  • Soft tissue hemorrhage may be seen.
  • Laryngeal fractures- fractures of the hyoid and thyroid may be seen
  • Amussat sign- damage to intima and media of the carotid artery
  • Simon's sign- hemorrhages on the anterior aspects of intervertebral discs
  • Dribbling of saliva- It is often found dribbling from the angle of the mouth, opposite to the side of the knot. This may be due to stimulation of salivary glands or congestive hypoxia. Salivation may not occur when the death is due to vagal inhibition or injury to the spinal cord. Evidence of dried marks of dribbling saliva is suggestive of antemortem hanging but its absence alone will not suggest that the body was suspended after the death.

questions.text: A patient presented with features suggestive of acute interstitial nephritis. A microscopy of his urinary casts is shown below. These casts are most likely those of _____.
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is having features of acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). So, the casts shown are most likely those of white blood cell casts.

AIN usually occurs as an allergic response to certain medications. The most common offending agents are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. It can also occur with proton pump inhibitors, sulfonamide derivatives and sulfasalazine. 

Individuals with AIN are usually asymptomatic and are incidentally found to have elevated creatinine.  However, in some instances, they can develop fever and rash. In severe cases, renal failure with proteinuria can occur. 

Laboratory studies may show peripheral eosinophilia and urinary eosinophilia. The urinalysis usually shows pyuria and occasionally eosinophiluria. But the most characteristic cell types are activated T lymphocytes and plasma cells, along with a few white blood cell casts. 

Other options: 

Option A: Broad casts are seen in chronic renal failure.

Option B: Hyaline casts may be seen normally and are non-specific.

Option D: Red blood cell casts are seen in acute glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek, which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are strongly suggestive of erythema infectiosum. The image is showing the classical slapped cheek appearance. It is caused by Parvoviruses. Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. 

Clinically, parvovirus B-19 infection may have several presentations:

Erythema infectiosum- Also known as the fifth disease. The incubation period after infection is typically around 1-2 weeks. The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which appears initially as erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance. Later, the rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema. The child may be febrile. 

Transient aplastic crisis- It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anaemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and paleness with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anaemia. The rash may or may not be present. 

Pure red cell aplasia- Persistent Parvovirus B19 infection in immunocompromised patients can cause chronic suppression of bone marrow and chronic anaemia, leading to pure red cell aplasia.

Maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

The diagnosis of erythema infectiosum is made clinically and does not require investigations routinely. Detection of viral DNA in the blood by PCR or nucleic acid hybridisation may be done for immunocompromised cases or prenatal diagnosis of infection.

It is self-limited and resolves on its own. IVIG may be given to immunocompromised children.

questions.text: A G2P1 woman has presented to the hospital in active labor. You conduct the delivery and now proceed to the active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). Which of the following is  recommended in active management of the third stage of labor according to WHO:

choices.text: Early cord clamping to prevent blood loss
Sustained uterine massage to prevent atony

questions.solution:
Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment is recommended according to the WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). 

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

Uterine massage is not recommended routinely.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL.

questions.text: A premature newborn is shifted to NICU with tachypnea, audible respiratory grunting, intercostal retractions, and cyanosis. An X-ray revealed ground glass opacities and air bronchograms. Which of the following cells marked in the respiratory epithelium below are involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Type II pneumocytes, which are marked as 2 in the above image, are damaged in RDS.

RDS is seen in premature infants, due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. 

The risk of developing RDS is further increased by:

  • Maternal diabetes
  • Cesarean delivery
  • Multiple births
  • Asphyxia
  • Cold stress
  • Maternal history of previously affected infants.

Clinical features of RDS include tachypnea, audible respiratory grunting, intercostal and subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, and cyanosis.

A diagnosis can be made with the presence of ground-glass opacity, low lung volumes, and air bronchograms on a chest x-ray, along with blood gas findings like hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and metabolic acidosis.

Administration of antenatal glucocorticoids can increase surfactant production and reduce the risk of RDS.

The surfactant consists of phospholipid dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine, also called lecithin, surface apoproteins, and calcium ions. This phospholipid is synthesized in type II pneumocytes in the endoplasmic reticulum, following which, it is processed in the Golgi apparatus and packed in the lamellar bodies. These surface-active agents are then released into the alveoli.

The surfactant helps to reduce the alveolar surface tension and by doing so, helps prevent their collapse. It also reduces the effort required by the respiratory muscles to expand the lungs.

However, as secretion of surfactant does not begin until the sixth and seventh months of gestation, it is very likely that in a premature infant, there is little to no surfactant present. This greatly increases the tendency of the lungs to collapse, leading to respiratory distress syndrome in the newborn.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with unintentional weight loss, sweating, and palpitations. On examination, she was found to have an enlarged thyroid gland. Radioactive iodine studies revealed the following findings. What is the definitive management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 40-year-old woman who presented with unintentional weight loss, sweating, and palpitations with an enlarged thyroid gland on examination and radioactive iodine scan showing multiple areas of high iodine uptake is suggestive of toxic multinodular goitre. The definitive management is a total or near-total thyroidectomy.

Multinodular goitre (MNG) is more commonly observed in women. It is common in iodine-deficient regions. MNG is discordant growth with functionally and structurally altered thyroid follicles presenting as multiple nodules in the thyroid. It could present as toxic or non-toxic MNG

Clinical features:

  • Multiple nodules of different sizes are formed in both lobes, also in the isthmus, which is firm, nodular, non-tender, and moves with deglutition.
  • Patients with toxic MNG have subclinical or mild hyperthyroidism.
  • The recent increase in size signifies malignant transformation or haemorrhage.
  • Positive Kocher’s test is due to compression over the trachea (tracheomalacia/scabbard trachea) in a long-standing MNG.
  • Nodule when calcified becomes harder; necrosis softens the nodule.

Investigations:

  • Thyroid function test - suggestive of subclinical or mild hyperthyroidism.
  • Ultrasound neck identifies impalpable nodules, number, nature of nodule, and vascularity of nodule.
  • Radioactive Iodine studies show high uptake in multiple sites due to over-functioning of the toxic nodules.
  • FNAC is done from the most dominant and suspicious nodule.

Complications of MNG:

  • Secondary thyrotoxicosis 
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Hemorrhage in a nodule
  • Tracheal obstruction, calcification

Treatment:

Usually, surgery is preferred after bringing the patient to a euthyroid state with the help of anti-thyroid drugs (option A). Radioactive iodine therapy (option B) is implemented for large goitres as it decreases goitre size and can ablate regions of autonomy.

Adequate thyroidectomy is essential, either total or subtotal, complete removal of diseased thyroid without retaining is considered, due to chances of high recurrence. Re-surgery for recurrent MNG is difficult due to loss of anatomical plane and fibrosis; hence total thyroidectomy is often advised. Postoperative L-thyroxine is often given to prevent any fluctuation in TSH level which may cause recurrent nodule formation.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Surgeries

  • Lobectomy - One entire thyroid lobe is removed.
  • Hemithyroidectomy - Total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy - 2 x subtotal lobectomy (Leaving greater than 1 g of thyroid tissue on each lobe)+ isthmusectomy
  • Near total thyroidectomy - Total lobectomy but leaving less than 1 g of tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (also known as Hartley-Dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy - 2 x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

questions.text: A person is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was placed in a surgical position as shown in the image below. Identify the position.
questions.solution:
The above image shows the reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15-30 degrees higher than the feet.  

It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level. In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the patient is placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position slightly turned to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

The below image shows the various surgical positions and the procedure they are used in:

  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A study conducted in a government school found that the mean weight of children aged 4-6 years is 17 kg and the standard deviation is 3 kg. A child whose z-score is +1.0 would weigh how much?
questions.solution:
A child whose z score is +1.0 will weigh 20 kg.

z = (X- µ)/σ, where X is the element’s value, µ is the mean, and σ is the standard deviation. In this case, the z score = 1, µ=17 and σ = 3. We need to find X. Applying these in the formula, we get: 

1=(X-17)/3

3=x-17

x=3+17=20.

The z score is the location of an element in the normal distribution and is denoted by how many standard deviations (SD) it lies above or below the mean of that distribution. So, if a value is 1 SD above the mean, the z score will be +1.0. So, an alternative method to arrive at the answer, in this case, is: A z score of +1 means the value is 1 SD above the mean = 17+3 = 20 kg.

Other Options:

Option A: A child weighing 23 kg will have a z score of +2.0.

Option B: A child weighing 11 kg will have a z score of -2.0.

Option D: A child weighing 14 kg will have a z score of -1.0.

Related Pearl: Z Scores

  • Z score indicates the position of any element in a distribution in terms of how many standard deviations it lies from the mean of the distribution.
  • It is also called the standard score.
  • If it lies above the mean, its z score will be positive and if it lies below it, the z score will be negative.
  • For example, if an element lies 1.5 standard deviations below the mean, its z score will be -1.5 and if it lies 0.5 standard deviations above the mean, its z score will be +0.5.
  • The formula for calculating z scores is z = (X- µ)/σ, where x is the element’s value, µ is the mean and σ is the standard deviation. From this, we can also calculate the actual value of the element.

questions.text: The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis is:

choices.text: Normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
Normal anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. 

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which acidosis occurs because of the inability of the tubules of the kidney to perform normal functions required to maintain acid-base balance. In this disorder, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is relatively well-preserved.

The defect is either inability to excrete hydrogen ions (inadequate generation of new bicarbonate ions) or inadequate reabsorption of bicarbonate ions. 

Types of RTA:

  • Type I - distal RTA or classical RTA is characterised by the inability to excrete H+ ions by the distal nephron. The urinary pH is >5.5, as the urine cannot be fully acidified, despite systemic acidosis. 
  • Type II - proximal RTA is characterised by the inability to reabsorb filtered bicarbonate by the proximal tubule.
  • Type III - mixed type, similar to both type I and II.
  • Type IV - is the most common type of RTA in clinical practice. This is a disorder of hyperkalemia, that occurs due to decreased aldosterone, which inhibits ammonium production.

The anion gap is the difference between readily measured anions and cations. The normal anion gap is 12 ± 4 mEq/L. The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types of RTA is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal. This kind of metabolic abnormality is also seen in gastrointestinal losses.

questions.text: Screening for inborn errors of metabolism in a newborn revealed the presence of severe hyperammonemia with respiratory alkalosis. Plasma levels of orotic acid were normal. Where is the deficient enzyme located in the cell?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, hyperammonemia and normal orotic acid suggest a carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 enzyme deficiency. It is an enzyme located in the mitochondria of the cell. 

The urea cycle begins in the mitochondria and ends in the cytoplasm. During the metabolism of amino acids through the process of transamination, the amino acids are then cleaved into a carbon skeleton and an amino group that gets removed as ammonia. Ammonia later enters the urea cycle and gets converted into urea which is excreted in the urine.

The urea cycle begins with one molecule of ammonia combined with CO2 in the presence of two molecules of ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate. The reaction is catalyzed by the mitochondrial enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-I (CPS-I).

CPS-I reaction is the rate-limiting step in urea formation which is irreversible and allosterically regulated.

questions.text: While assessing a 33-year-old lady who had been in a road traffic accident, you note watery discharge from her nose mixed with the blood. The following sign is seen on filter paper.  Which structures produce the majority of this fluid?
questions.solution:
The case suggests CSF rhinorrhea and the image shows the double-ring sign. CSF mainly forms in the choroid plexus. It is absorbed back by the arachnoid villi. 

Formation of CSF:

  • Major contributor - Choroid plexuses
  • Minor contributors - Ependymal cells lining the ventricles, brain substance through the perivascular spaces

CSF is produced at a rate of 550 ml/day. The normal adult volume of CSF is 150ml, and it is cycled about 3.7 times a day. The normal CSF pressure is 70-180 mm H2O.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was admitted for treatment of his alcohol dependency. He has a history of major depressive disorder and multiple suicide attempts. Which of the following drugs cannot be given to him?
questions.solution:
Acamprosate is a drug that cannot be given during the treatment of alcohol dependency in a patient with a known depressive disorder and multiple suicidal attempts in the past.

Acamprosate is an NMDA antagonist and GABA analogue that is used in the management of alcohol dependence and maintenance of alcohol abstinence. It acts to mitigate the effects of alcohol withdrawal, less effective if not yet abstained from alcohol or in a relapse.

It is given as a dose of 666 mg twice or thrice daily depending on the weight. Treatment should be initiated as soon as after achieving abstinence. Augmentation with naltrexone and behavioral and supportive therapies may be more effective than monotherapy.

Side effects of the drug include depressed mood, suicidal ideation and gastrointestinal side effects like diarrhea and nausea. Contraindications to acamprosate include severe renal impairment, previous allergy to acamprosate, pregnancy and breastfeeding.

Other options:

Option A: Buspi­rone is a non-benzodiazepine drug that can be used for alcohol dependence treatment. It should not be used within 14 days of using monoamine oxidase inhibitors due to the risk of serotonin syndrome.

Option B: Nal­trexone is an opioid antagonist that decreases the craving for alcohol or blunts the rewarding effects of drinking. It aggravates severe withdrawal if the patient is dependent on opioids.

Option D: Disulfiram is an alcohol-sensitizing agent. Interaction with alcohol causes disulfiram reaction involving nausea, vomiting, and a burning sensation in the face and stomach. Patients with preexisting heart disease, cerebral thrombosis and diabetes may have a fatal reaction to the disulfiram even in case of accidental exposure to alcohol.

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever and cough. On blood culture, the causative organism was found to be Haemophilus influenzae. Which of the following is not true regarding the bacteria?

choices.text: It requires growth factors V and X
It is a spore forming bacillus

questions.solution:
Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that is non-motile and non-spore-forming. 

When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus. 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X (Option A) that are present in the blood.

  • Factor V  is a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a coenzyme, and is heat labile.
  • Factor X is hemin. It is required for cytochrome synthesis and the function of enzymes like catalase and peroxidase. It is heat stable.

When H. influenzae is cultured on the same plate as Staphylococcus aureus. The closer the colonies of H. influenzae are to S. aureus, the larger the growth. This is termed satellitism (Option B). This occurs because factor V is released by the hemolytic action of S. aureus. 

The image below shows satellitism.

Hemophilus influenzae has a capsular polysaccharide (Option D) which is a major antigenic determinant. Capsular typing is done to identify strains. Importantly, the type b capsular polysaccharide has a polyribosyl ribitol phosphate antigen (PRP). PRP is targeted during immunization. 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, laryngo-epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis. 

Cefotaxime or ceftazidime is the drug of choice for the treatment of Haemophilus meningitis. H.influenzae produces beta-lactamase, hence resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics like ampicillin.

H. influenza can be prevented by immunization with the Hib vaccine. The vaccine is produced based on the type b capsular polysaccharide. The capsule is composed of polyribosyl ribitol phosphate which can induce IgG, IgM, and IgA antibodies. Those that do not have a capsule are not candidates for vaccine prevention. Apart from H. influenza type b, the non-typeable strains are those that produce the clinical infections presently.

questions.text: A 15-year-old child was brought with visible burns on his chest, upper limbs, and lower limbs. He complained of nausea, headache, and a change in voice. SpO2 is 84% and ABG revealed PaO2 of 50 mmHg. He was started on I.V. fluids. What is the next best step in his management?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of a possible scald injury to the airways. The next best step would be to secure the airway using an endotracheal tube.

Prompt intubation should be done before the features of laryngeal edema, such as a change in voice, stridor, anxiety, and respiratory difficulty, develop. A cricothyroidotomy might be needed if intubation fails. Because of this, early intubation of suspected airway burns is the treatment of choice in such patients.

The time frame from burn to airway occlusion is usually between 4 to 24 hours.

Recognition of the potentially burned airway:

  • A history of being trapped in the presence of smoke or hot gases
  • Burns on the palate or nasal mucosa, or loss of all the hairs in the nose
  • Deep burns around the mouth and neck

questions.text: A child with severe mental retardation was found to have a total absence of myelin in the central nervous system. Laboratory investigations reveal the accumulation of galactosylceramide. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Krabbe’s disease and the enzyme deficient in this disease is β-galactosidase. 

Sphingolipidoses are a group of lysosomal storage disorders characterized by the accumulation of sphingolipids. Krabbe’s disease is an autosomal-recessive sphingolipidosis. It is a neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to a deficiency in β-galactosidase.

Galactosylceramide is the main content in a myelin sheath. It is synthesized by oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells by galactosylation of ceramide. It is broken down by the enzyme β-galactosidase, a lysosomal hydrolase.

In Krabbe’s disease due to deficiency of the enzyme β-galactosidase, galactosylceramide accumulates in oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. This accumulation causes the formation of globoid cells (hematogenous often-multinucleated macrophages containing undigested galactosylceramide). This results in the destruction of oligodendroglia and hence total loss of myelin in the central nervous system.

The image given below shows globoid cells seen in Krabbe's disease.

It is characterized by mental retardation, irritability, tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation, seizures, hypertonia, and later flaccidity. Optic atrophy is also present. Investigations reveal increased protein in the CSF.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been found to be effective as a treatment modality for Krabbe's disease.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He is found to be in hemorrhagic shock. As a part of the ATLS protocol, which of the following cannula should be preferred for fluid resuscitation in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to ATLS guidelines, a minimum of 2 large bore IV lines preferably of 18 gauge (green) marked as "1" should be used for fluid resuscitation of trauma patients with large volume loss.

For trauma patients who necessitate a high volume of fluid replacement and multiple blood transfers large-sized, wide-bored cannulas are preferred.

The rate of flow is proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the cannula and inversely related to its length, as described in Poiseuille’s law. Hence, short, large-caliber peripheral intravenous lines are preferred for the rapid infusion of fluid, rather than longer, thinner catheters. Higher the gauge of the cannula, lower the caliber of the cannula.

questions.text: A micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) in a child who presented with recurrent UTI showed the following. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Micturating cystourethrogram shows the keyhole sign
Valve is usually distal to verumontanum

questions.solution:
The given image of a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) shows dilated prostatic urethra and transverse filling defects corresponding with the posterior urethral valves. This is suggestive of a posterior urethral valve. The pathological valve is usually distal to the verumontanum.

Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children. The pathological valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit within them, which typically lie just distal to the verumontanum. They act as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow. 

Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. Antenatal USG would also demonstrate oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then babies typically present with urinary infections in the neonatal period or with uremia and renal failure. Clinically a poor urinary stream, dribbling, and palpable bladder (due to diverticula) can be present. The investigation of choice is micturating cystourethrography

Treatment is initially supportive by inserting a urinary catheter to relieve symptoms of obstruction. Definitive treatment involves the destruction of valves and symptomatic management of urinary tract infections. 

The below image shows the micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) with dilated prostatic urethra and transverse filling defects(constriction) corresponding with the posterior urethral valves.

The ultrasound shows the typical 'key-hole' sign in which the bladder and the proximal urethra are dilated.

questions.text: Pseudopapillitis is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Pseudopapillitis is seen in hypermetropia.

In hypermetropia, fundus examination shows an optic disc that is small, has ill-defined margins, appears highly vascular, and simulates papillitis. However, as the optic disc is not swollen, as seen in papillitis, it is also called pseudopapillitis. A shiny retina is seen due to the greater brilliance of light reflections known as shot silk appearance.

A fundus image showing the same is given below.

In hypermetropia or long-sightedness, incident parallel rays of light come to a focus behind the light-sensitive retina, with the accommodation at rest. It may be axial, curvatural, index, positional and due to the absence of a crystalline lens.

Patients can be asymptomatic when the refractive error is small and corrected by the use of accommodation. Sustained accommodative efforts can give rise to symptoms such as tiredness of the eyes, headache, watering and mild photophobia. It may also lead to esotropic (convergent) squint in children. When the hypermetropia is high enough to not be corrected by accommodative efforts, patients experience defective vision.

On examination, the size of the eyeball may appear small and the cornea is slightly smaller. The anterior chamber is comparatively shallow. Other features on fundus examination include a shot silk appearance, where the entire retina may shine due to reflected light. It is usually treated by using convex lenses, which help focus the light rays on the retina.

Other options:

Option A: Myopia or short-sightedness is a condition where parallel rays of light come to a focus in front of the retina. Fundus examination shows an optic disc that is large, pale and has a crescent at the temporal edge, degenerative changes in retina, choroid, vitreous and presence of posterior staphyloma.

Option C: Aphakia refers to the absence of a crystalline lens. Fundus examination only shows a hypermetropic, small disc.

Option D: Presbyopia is a condition of physiological insufficiency of accommodation, leading to a progressive fall in near vision.

Related Pearl: Grading of Hypermetropia

American Optometric Association (AOA) has defined three grades of hypermetropia:

  • Low hypermetropia: error of + 2D or less
  • Moderate hypermetropia: error from +2.25D to + 5D 
  • High hypermetropia: error is > + 5D

questions.text: You are educating a patient about performing peritoneal dialysis at home. During this process, how much fluid is infused into the peritoneum?
questions.solution:
In peritoneal dialysis, 1.5–3 L of dialysis fluid is infused into the peritoneal cavity. 

In this process, the peritoneum itself acts as a semipermeable membrane. A peritoneal catheter is used to infuse the fluid into the cavity. It is allowed to dwell for a set period of time usually 2–4 hours to allow for the removal of metabolic waste products. The dialysis fluid contains osmotically active agents such as glucose or icodextrin.

The following image shows the process of peritoneal dialysis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man met with an accident and fell with his hand in dorsiflexion. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness around the wrist joint. The X-ray shown below confirmed the diagnosis, following which Tavernier's maneuver successfully corrected the condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and treatment with Tavernier's maneuver point to a perilunate dislocation.

The X-ray of perilunate dislocation shows the lunate maintaining its normal articulation with the radius, whereas other carpal bones have dislocated from the lunate dorsally. It is frequently associated with compression of the median nerve. 

Prompt reduction reduces swelling and potential damage to the median nerve. The most commonly used method of closed reduction is the Tavernier maneuver. It consists of locking the capitate into the distal concavity of the lunate. When the injury cannot be reduced this way, urgent reduction in theatre should be done.

In lunate dislocation, the lunate dislocates anteriorly and the rest of the carpal bones remain in place.

In scapholunate dissociation (SLD), a large gap may be present between the scaphoid and lunate on X-ray which is known as the Terry Thomas sign. It was named after Terry Thomas, a comedian who had a gap-toothed smile.

An X-ray showing scapholunate dislocation is shown below.

In lunotriquetral dislocation, the X-ray changes are usually subtle. But sometimes the X-ray shows a gap between lunate and triquetrum, and forward titling of lunate and scaphoid in the lateral view.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical tests is not useful to evaluate a patient with suspected rotator cuff disruption?
questions.solution:
The Roo's test is used to reproduce the symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Usually, following a trauma to the rotator cuff, there is a vascular reaction that causes swelling and subsequent rotator cuff impingement.

Rotator cuff disruption is an advanced stage of impingement. There is progressive fibrosis and disruption of the rotator cuff, leading to a partial or full-thickness tear. The patient is usually more than 45 years of age and has a history of refractory shoulder pain with weakness and stiffness.

The muscles forming the rotator cuff are shown below.

Important tests for cuff impingement are:

  • Painful arc test- on active abduction of the arm between 60 and 120 degrees, pain is aggravated.
  • Neer’s impingement sign- the examiner stabilizes the scapula with one hand, and with the other hand, the affected arm is raised fully in passive flexion, abduction, and internal rotation. The test is positive when pain in the subacromial space or anterior part acromion on performing this maneuver. 
  • Neer’s test for impingement- disappearance or significant reduction in pain when the previous maneuver is repeated after injecting 10 mL of 1% lignocaine into the subacromial space. It helps in the confirmation of the diagnosis.
  • Hawkins–Kennedy test- the patient’s arm is elevated 90 degrees in the scapular plane with the elbow in 90 degrees flexion. The upper arm is then stabilized and rotated internally. The test is positive when pain is felt in the anterolateral part of the shoulder. This test is also highly sensitive but weakly specific.
  • Jobe’s test- the patient's arm is elevated in the scapular plane, and the elbow is extended with the thumb pointing to the floor. The patient is then asked to hold this position, while the examiner applies downward pressure. Pain indicates irritation of the supraspinatus tendon.

 The images below summarize the various tests for cuff impingement.

Roo's test- the patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is then asked to open and close the hand slowly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, or numbness, on the affected side. It is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome.

The GIF below demonstrates Roo's test.
