questions.text: In a postoperative ward, 4 out of 10 patients developed wound discharge, which on culture and antibiotic susceptibility was found to be positive for coagulase-positive, gram-positive cocci, resistant to Methicillin. Which of the following is true regarding the causative agent?

choices.text: Major route of spread  is air borne
Alteration in its penicillin binding proteins is found
Sensitive to amoxicillin + clavulanic acid combination

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of infections occurring in the post-operative ward and the culture and antibiotic susceptibility report suggest methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. Alteration in its penicillin-binding proteins is found in MRSA.

Staphylococci are gram-positive cocci arranged characteristically in grape-like clusters. They are uniformly resistant to lysozymes. 

They exhibit various types of resistance to antibiotics by beta-lactamase production and alteration in penicillin-binding protein PBP2a. 

Beta-lactamase or penicillinase-producing strains inactivate penicillin by splitting the beta-lactam ring. The beta-lactamase enzyme is plasmid-mediated. However, they are susceptible to penicillinase-resistant penicillins such as methicillin and cloxacillin. This can be transmitted by transduction or conjugation. 

Alteration of PBP2a leads to changes in surface binding of beta-lactam antibiotics on bacteria resulting in resistance to all beta-lactam antibiotics and is termed methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The mechanism of resistance of MRSA is due to chromosomally mediated Mec A gene which codes for altered PBP2a (Penicillin Binding Protein or receptor 2a) which has less affinity for beta-lactam drugs.

Other options:

Option A: The major route of spread causing the outbreak is direct contact through the contaminated hands of hospital staff or direct contact with an infected wound.

Option B: The resistance to Methicillin is chromosomally mediated.

Option D: Since MRSA-coded altered PBP 2a (Penicillin Binding protein 2a) has less affinity for lactam drugs, MRSA strains are resistant to all beta-lactam drugs. Even a combination of β lactam and β lactamase inhibitor will not work.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text:
Which of the following tumors are wrongly matched with their response to radiotherapy?

RCC-Renal cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Dysgerminoma is highly radiosensitive. All other options are correctly matched.

Dysgerminoma is the counterpart of testicular seminoma. It may occur in childhood, but 75% occur in the second and third decades. 80 to 90% of tumors are unilateral. Some appear in patients with gonadal dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. 

Mostly dysgerminomas are malignant with variable degrees of histologic atypia and one-third of lesions are aggressive. 

Radiotherapy is not preferred despite the fact that they are radiosensitive due to the risk of radiation injury to the bowel. These neoplasms are responsive to chemotherapy, which is preferred over radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: Seminomas are radiosensitive tumors and adjuvant radiotherapy was the mainstay of treatment in Stage 1 tumors previously.

Option C: Spinal metastasis from renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is radioresistant. Spinal metastasis from gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma, metastatic melanoma, and thyroid are also radioresistant. Lymphoma, lung, breast, and prostate metastasis are radiosensitive.

Option D: Ewing sarcoma is a radiosensitive tumor.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient with increased blood pressure has come to the outpatient department. He asks about lifestyle modifications and a DASH diet was suggested. How much does the systolic blood pressure drop by adopting the DASH diet?

DASH: Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension
questions.solution:
The systolic blood pressure drops by 8-14 mmHg by adopting the DASH diet.

DASH is a diet plan which involves consuming a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced fat content. 

Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension and the reduction in blood pressure are shown below.

Modification Impact on SBP
Weight reduction to maintain a normal body mass index 5–20 mmHg per 10kg weight loss
DASH diet 8–14 mmHg
Sodium intake reduction (< 6 grams of sodium chloride) 2–8 mmHg
Physical activity: 30 minutes of a brisk walk per day  4–9 mmHg

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

Hypertension is a preventable disease. There are two approaches:

  • Primary prevention - includes measures that are taken to reduce the incidence by reducing the risk of onset. Population strategies are dietary modification, weight reduction, and exercise. A high-risk strategy prevents the shooting of blood pressure which might need institutional treatment.
  • Secondary prevention - includes the detection and usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals.

questions.text: An abdominal X-ray of a baby who presented with abdominal distension and hematochezia showed air in the bowel wall. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a baby presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia, with X-ray findings of pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Prematurity is the greatest risk factor for developing NEC.

NEC is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in newborns. It is characterized by mucosal or transmural inflammation resulting in necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. Three major risk factors implicated are prematurity (the greatest risk factor), formula feeding, and bacterial colonization of the intestine.

Babies usually present within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall), portal vein gas, and pneumoperitoneum (indicates perforation).

The given X-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows).


Management of NEC includes supportive measures like keeping the baby nil per oral (NPO), nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication for surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk.

questions.text: A female patient with mitral valve prolapse was admitted to the labor room at 38 weeks of gestation. She insists on a normal delivery of the baby. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Vaginal delivery is preferred to Cesarean section
Delay second stage of labor  to prevent cardiac stress
Facilitate delivery by forceps or vacuum extraction
The left decubitus position is preferred to lithotomy

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding the management of this patient is option B. In a cardiac patient, such as a patient with mitral valve prolapse, it is better to cut short the second stage by facilitating the delivery by forceps or vacuum extraction

For most cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred. A cesarean section is reserved for obstetric indications. If vaginal delivery is selected as the mode of choice, it will be conducted with the laboring woman in the left decubitus position. This minimizes aortocaval compression.

Active pushing during the second stage may also be limited, depending on the degree of cardiac compromise. Suppose the cardiac disease is moderate to severe, it is better to avoid the active second stage by using regional anesthesia. It allows the fetal head to descend to the perineum without active pushing and then facilitate delivery by forceps or vacuum extraction.

Management of labor in patients with heart disease:

First stage:

  • Lateral recumbent or propped up position
  • Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)
  • Analgesia by epidural
  • Fluids infused should not be more than 75 ml/hr
  • Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labor and 48 hours after delivery
  • Pulse oximetry and cardiac monitoring

Second stage:

  • No maternal pushing
  • Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse extraction.

The benefit of avoiding hemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighed against an increased risk of perineal trauma, hemorrhage, and fetal head injury with forceps or vacuum delivery.

Third stage:

  • Oxytocin by infusion
  • IV frusemide if needed

Oxytocin is preferred over ergometrine in all heart disease patients in the third stage of labor.

questions.text: A woman presents with cyclical hematuria 8 months after an emergency cesarean section was done for non-progress of labor. There is no urinary incontinence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vesicouterine fistula.

Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Other causes of cyclical hematuria can be intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) perforation into the bladder or bladder endometriosis. True pathology can be confirmed by cystoscopy.

Treatment:

  • Prolonged bladder catheterization can close the fistula. 
  • Abdominal repair using omental or gracilis graft is done if the prolonged catheterization fails.

Methylene blue swab test:

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

Other options:

Option A: In a vesicovaginal fistula, the main complaint will be constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). It usually follows difficult childbirth. A positive methylene blue test confirms the diagnosis. 

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Option D: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section

The patient is unable to micturate

The patient is able to micturate

questions.text: A young woman with a history of prior Chlamydia infection presents with low-grade fever and lower abdominal pain. She has cervical motion tenderness and a mucopurulent vaginal discharge on pelvic examination. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?

choices.text: Injection ceftriaxone  + oral doxycycline + oral metronidazole

questions.solution:
The best treatment is a single IM injection of ceftriaxone with oral doxycycline and oral metronidazole for 14 days for pelvic inflammatory disease most likely due to Chlamydia trachomatis. 

Criteria to diagnose PID: Any one of the minimum criteria + 1 or more additional criteria are required for the clinical diagnosis of PID.

Minimum criteria

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness.

Additional criteria

  • Oral temperature >38.3oC
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
  • Presence of abundant WBC on saline microscopy of vaginal fluid
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with N. gonorrhoeae or C. trachomatis.

The definitive diagnosis of PID is through histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy. Imaging (TVS/MRI) showing evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes indicating tubo-ovarian abscess. Laparoscopic evidence of PID is confirmative.

Outpatient management of PID: Inj. ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + doxycycline 100 mg BD x 14 days + metronidazole 500 mg BD x 14 days.

Indications for hospitalization in PID 

  • Surgical emergencies like appendicitis, generalized peritonitis, etc. 
  • Tubo-ovarian abscess
  • Pregnancy
  • oral temperature >38.5°C, severe nausea and vomiting
  • Unable to follow or tolerate an outpatient oral regimen
  • No clinical response to oral antimicrobial therapy

Parenteral treatment for PID in hospitalized patients: 

  • Inj. cefotetan + oral doxycycline 
  • (or) Inj. cefoxitin + oral doxycycline
  • (or) Inj.clindamycin + inj. gentamicin 

After clinical improvement of the patient with parenteral therapy, transition to oral therapy with doxycycline and metronidazole is recommended to complete 14 days of antimicrobial therapy.

To minimize disease transmission, women should be instructed to abstain from sexual intercourse until therapy is completed, symptoms have resolved, and partners have been adequately treated.

questions.text: A child had recurrent bouts of infections. The diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease was made using the nitroblue tetrazolium test. This test assesses the functions of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The nitroblue tetrazolium test assesses the function of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN).

Nitroblue tetrazolium assay is used as a diagnostic test, particularly for chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). It tests the reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in neutrophils and monocytes.

Chronic granulomatous disease is a rare X-linked recessive disease. It is characterized by the impaired phagocytic killing of microorganisms by neutrophils and macrophages. Defects in NADPH oxidase lead to defective production of reactive oxygen species after phagocytosis.

These patients have frequent infections by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Burkholderia cepacia complex, Nocardia, Aspergillus, etc. Recurrent folliculitis may prompt early diagnosis of the condition. Following these infections, there is extensive inflammation and suppuration despite antibiotic therapy.

Other features include aphthous ulcers, inflammation of the nares, and granulomas. Granulomas can cause obstruction of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tracts. Autoimmune complications like immune thrombocytopenic purpura and juvenile idiopathic arthritis may also occur.

Management of CGD is mainly treating infections with antibiotics or antifungals depending on the cause. Granulomas are sensitive to steroids and glucocorticoids can be given. 

Other options:

Options B and C: B and T lymphocytes can be assessed by lymphocyte phenotyping. It is useful in the diagnosis of T-cell immunodeficiencies and agammaglobulinemia.

Option D: Complement can be assessed by CH50 and AP50, which are useful in diagnosing complement deficiencies.

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the deformity shown?

choices.text: Little finger is the most commonly involved
It is more common in males
Fasciectomy with skin grafting is done in cases with recurrence
May be associated with Ledderhose and Peyronie’s disease

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Dupuytren’s contracture. The ring finger is most commonly involved.

Dupuytren's contracture is due to the proliferation of previously normal subcutaneous palmar and digital tissues manifesting as nodules and cords that may affect hand function by causing finer and thumb joint flexion contractures.

The contracture begins with increased fibroblast proliferation followed by type III collagen deposition resulting in uncontrolled palmar fascia growth ultimately causing flexion contractures.

The distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) are not involved. The metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are involved. The order of involvement of fingers - ring finger > little finger > middle finger > index finger > thumb.

It is more common in males and the incidence is higher in patients with cirrhosis of the liver, diabetes, smoking, and AIDS. It is also associated with vibration exposure to the wrist and hand. The contractures are usually limited to the medial 3 fingers.

Dupuytren contractures may be associated with similar ectopic lesions in the medial plantar fascia of one or both feet (Ledderhose disease), as plastic penile induration (Peyronie disease), and knuckle pads (Garrod nodules) may present over the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints dorsally.

Treatment:

  • Observation- observation at every three months interval for mild deformities.
  • Radiotherapy- is given only during the early fibroblastic phase.
  • Surgery- is the best-known treatment and is delayed until actual contractures develop. The various procedures performed are:
    • Subcutaneous fasciotomy- preferred in elderly arthritic patients
    • Partial selective fasciotomy- indicated only when the ulnar two fingers are involved
    • Complete fasciectomy- rarely done
    • Fasciectomy with skin grafting- done in young people with epilepsy, alcoholism, and in cases of recurrence after excision
    • Amputation- considered if flexion contractures of PIP joint are very severe
    • Resection and arthrodesis- done for severe contractures of the PIP joint. It is better than amputation as it prevents amputation neuroma.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool.  Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in this diarrhea?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a patient having rice gruel stools is suggestive of the diagnosis of ‘cholera’. Vibrio cholerae in addition to the cholera toxin (CT) produces some additional toxins such as, 

  • Zonula occludens toxin, which alters the intestinal permeability by acting on intestinal epithelial cell tight junctions (which are also called zonula occludens)
  • Accessory cholera enterotoxin.

Zonula occludens:

  • Also known as tight junctions
  • Characteristically surround the apical margins of the cells in epithelia such as the intestinal mucosa, the walls of the renal tubules, and the choroid plexus.
  • Also important to the endothelial barrier function and endothelium-dependent vasodilation.
  • Made up of ridges- half from one cell and a half from another cell- which adhere so strongly that there is no space between the cells.
  • Three families of transmembrane proteins are involved:
  1. Occludin
  2. Junctional adhesion molecule
  3. Claudins
  • Paracellular pathway - these tight junctions permit the passage of ions, solutes, and intracellular signaling molecules in between adjacent cells.

 

Other options:

B) Gap junctions:

  • The gap between the two cells in these types of junctions is about 4nm.
  • These junctions are formed by units called connexons, which are present in the membrane of each cell.
  • Each connexon is made up of six protein subunits called connexins. 
  • They permit substances to pass between the cells, without entering the ECF.
  • The pore diameter is around 0.8 to 1.4  nm, which permits the passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, and other solutes which weigh up to 1000 Da.
  • They also permit rapid propagation of electrical activity from cell to cell, as well as the exchange of various chemical messengers and intracellular signaling molecules.

C) Adherent junctions:

  • Adherent junctions or Zonula adherens is a continuous structure on the basal side of the zonula occludens.
  • It contains cadherins.

D) Hemidesmosomes:

  • They look like half-desmosomes.
  • They attach cells to the underlying basal lamina and are connected intracellularly to intermediate filaments.
  • They contain integrins.

questions.text: A young woman presents to the clinic with a history of easy fatiguability for the past few months. A peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic cells.  Serum ferritin was low. Which of the other findings would be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a young woman presenting to the clinic with a history of easy fatiguability, and peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic anemia is suggestive of iron deficiency anemia. Low serum iron and serum ferritin would be seen in this condition.

Iron deficiency anemia is a type of microcytic hypochromic anemia. It mainly occurs due to inadequate diet, impaired absorption, increased requirement, and increased blood loss.

Manifestations of iron deficiency anemia depend upon the underlying cause. In general, features such as koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic changes in the tongue, gastric mucosa, malabsorption, and pica (craving for eating non-food stuff) can be present.

Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are low hemoglobin and low hematocrit. Serum iron and ferritin are low while the total iron binding capacity is increased. These changes lead to a decrease in transferrin saturation. Decreased stores of iron inhibit the hepcidin synthesis and hence it is low.

A peripheral blood smear reveals small and pale red cells typically described as microcytic hypochromic anemia. An enlarged zone of central pallor may be seen in the red blood cells. Poikilocytosis can be seen in the form of elongated red cells, known as pencil cells.

Bone marrow shows a mild to moderate raise in erythroid progenitors. The absence of iron stain in macrophages is a significant finding.

Red cell distribution width can be done to differentiate iron deficiency anemia from thalassemia. It is a quantitative measure of this variation in cell size that is calculated from MCV (mean corpuscular volume). Normal RDW is 11-14%. A high RDW denotes anisocytosis, suggestive of iron deficiency.

The below peripheral image shows microcytic hypochromic cells.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the fever clinic with a history of fever and breathlessness for the past 5 days. On examination, she is found to have a respiratory rate of 27 per minute and SpO2 of 90% on room air.  Her RT-PCR test was found to be positive for COVID-19 disease. According to the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, this patient has:

choices.text: Severe COVID-19 infection with acute respiratory distress syndrome
Severe COVID-19 infection with septic shock

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has a respiratory rate of 27 per minute (≥ 24/minute) and SpO2 of 90% (90% to ≤93%), and a positive RT-PCR test for COVID 19 disease. Thus according to the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, this patient has moderate COVID-19 infection.

According to the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, COVID-19 infection can be classified as: 

Mild COVID-19 disease includes patients with uncomplicated upper respiratory tract infection and may have mild symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, nasal congestion, malaise, and headache. There is no shortness of breath or hypoxia.

Moderate COVID-19 disease includes patients with pneumonia but no signs of severe disease. Adults with the presence of clinical features of dyspnea and or hypoxia, fever, cough, including SpO2 90 to ≤93% on room air, respiratory rate ≥ 24 breaths/minute.

Severe COVID-19 disease includes adults with clinical signs of pneumonia plus one of the following- respiratory rate >30 breaths/min, severe respiratory distress, SpO2 <90% on room air. Severe infection further can have:

  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome - patients develop new or worsening respiratory symptoms within one week of onset of the symptoms. There are opacities in the chest radiographs which are not due to effusions, lobar or lung collapse, or nodules. The patients develop respiratory failure which is not due to cardiac failure or fluid overload. The PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg (with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O)
  • Sepsis - life-threatening organ dysfunction caused due to an infection.
  • Septic shock - persisting hypotension despite fluid resuscitation. Patients require vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg and serum lactate level >2 mmol/L.

Mild cases can be home isolated. Moderate and severe cases will require hospitalisation in a dedicated COVID hospital.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man working in a factory for the past 30 years, presents with dyspnea and cough due to chronic exposure to a particular mineral agent. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows characteristic golden brown bodies with beaded and knobbed ends. All of the following are caused by exposure to this agent, except  ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing golden-brown asbestos bodies with knobbed or beaded ends is due to asbestos exposure. All of the given conditions are caused by exposure to asbestos except anthracosis. Anthracosis is a coal-induced pulmonary lesion.

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung that occurs due to asbestos exposure. The disease usually manifests after a minimum of 10 years of exposure. Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Recurrent pleural effusions
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis 
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

Clinically, dyspnea and cough are seen. They can progress to respiratory failure, cor pulmonale, and even death. Chest radiograph can show irregular linear densities in lower lobes and in late stages can show a honey-combed pattern.

Histopathology shows diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and asbestos bodies. These appear as golden brown fusiform or rod-shaped beaded structures with a translucent center that is made of asbestos fibers coated by a proteinaceous material. They arise when asbestos gets phagocytosed by macrophages. Iron-protein complexes may coat other inorganic particulate matter to form ferruginous bodies.

The below image shows asbestos bodies.

 

Anthracosis is commonly seen in coal miners, urban dwellers, and tobacco smokers. It is caused by chronic exposure to coal dust. Wheeze is a typical finding seen in anthracosis. They can present with cough and, dyspnoea as well. Black carbon deposits in the lungs may be visible grossly as well as microscopically.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started as there was no pulse and the following rhythm was noted on the monitor. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario patient has an organized, apparently normal ECG without a palpable pulse, that is, the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA). Among the given options, the next step is to give 1 mg of epinephrine.

The immediate treatment for pulseless electrical activity is to give chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest. Following that, definitive treatment for the cause of PEA should be initiated.

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest. They include:

5 H’s:

  • Hypovolemia
  • Hypoxia
  • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
  • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
  • Hypothermia

5 T’s:

  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Tamponade (cardiac)
  • Toxins
  • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
  • Thrombosis (coronary)

Other options : 

Option A: Defibrillation is done for treating shockable rhythms. An electric current is passed for a short interval to bring back sinus rhythm. 

Option B: Amiodarone 300 mg IV bolus is used in the treatment of shockable rhythms. After defibrillation CPR is continued for 2 min and then Epinephrine/ Amiodarone is administered alternatively and CPR is continued till sinus rhythm is established. 

Option D: 0.5 mg atropine is the first-line drug for acute symptomatic bradycardia.

questions.text: All of the following can be associated with hyperkalemia, except ____.
questions.solution:
Epinephrine will cause the shift of potassium back into the cell, hence cannot be associated with hyperkalemia.

Factors that shift potassium into the cells, thereby decreasing the extracellular K+ concentration, leading to hypokalemia are:

  • Increased insulin and aldosterone secretion
  • β-adrenergic stimulation (eg: epinephrine)
  • Alkalosis

Factors that shift potassium out of the cells, thereby increasing the extracellular K+ concentration, leading to hyperkalemia are:

  • Insulin deficiency
  • Aldosterone deficiency (Addison's disease)
  • β-adrenergic blockade
  • Acidosis
  • Cell lysis in severe muscle injury or red blood cell lysis
  • Strenuous exercise
  • Increased extracellular fluid osmolarity

Epinephrine is an agonist at alpha 1, beta 1, and beta 2 receptors.

The β actions are mediated through cAMP. Epinephrine binds to Gs → ATP and is broken down to cAMP by the enzyme adenylyl cyclase. This results in:

  • In the liver and muscle- hyperglycemia and hypokalaemia due to potassium uptake in muscle and liver
  • In adipose tissue- increased plasma free fatty acids
  • In the heart- an increased force of contraction reinforces the positive inotropic action
  • In pancreatic islets- increases glucagon secretion

Epinephrine is used in anaphylaxis, to prolong the action of local anesthetics, cardiac arrest, and as inhalational epinephrine in the treatment of post-intubation and infectious croup.

Epinephrine is contraindicated in anesthesia with halothane due to the risk of arrhythmias and in patients receiving beta-blockers because the marked rise in BP can occur due to unopposed alpha action.

questions.text: A patient is unable to maintain saturation on room air and intubation was found to be difficult. All of the following points noted on examination would indicate difficult intubation, except ____.
questions.solution:
Hypertelorism is an increased distance between both canthi. It is not used as a predictor of difficult laryngoscopy.

Difficult endotracheal intubation by direct laryngoscopy is primarily due to an inadequate view of the glottis. The use of external laryngeal manipulation techniques can improve the view of the glottis. BURP maneuver on the thyroid cartilage is the most commonly used. Pressure is applied to the thyroid cartilage in a backward, upward, and rightward direction.

When the endotracheal tube(ETT) cannot be passed into the trachea under direct view the following can be done. 

  1. Blind passage of the ETT (risk of airway damage)
  2. Use of an ETT introducer
  3. An alternative approach to intubation as per ASA DAA guidelines

 Predictors for difficult laryngoscopy are as given below:

  • Long upper incisors
  • Prominent overbite
  • Inability to protrude the mandible
  • Smallmouth opening
  • Mallampati classification III or IV
  • High, arched palate
  • Short thyromental distance
  • Short, thick neck
  • Limited cervical mobility

 The Cormack and Lehane grading scale describes laryngoscopic views with grades ranging from I (the best view) to IV (the most difficult view). 

Grades Structures visualized
I Entire laryngeal aperture
II Only the posterior portion of the laryngeal aperture
III Only the epiglottis
IV No visualization of the epiglottis or larynx

Other options: 

Option A: High arched palate leaves very little space for the laryngoscopy blade in the oropharynx. 

Option C: Buck teeth refer to prominent and long upper incisors with an overbite. 

Option D: Wide short neck leads to limited visualization of the glottic structure.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A young man starts profusely sweating and hyperventilating whenever he enters an elevator or closed space and tries to avoid it. He also has palpitations, dizziness, and fear. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in which the person develops anxiety symptoms and fear of entering a closed space is suggestive of claustrophobia, a type of specific phobia.

Phobia refers to excessive fear of a specific circumstance, situation, or object. A specific phobia is a strong and per­sisting fear of a particular situation or an object. To diagnose this condition, the prerequisites are the development of intense anxiety or panic, when exposed to the feared object. 

The main defense mechanisms in phobias include displacement, projection, and avoidance. The DSM-5 includes distinctive types of specific phobia:

  • Animal type - e.g. cats, dogs
  • Natural environment type - e.g. storms
  • Blood-injection­ injury type - e.g. needles
  • Situational type - e.g. cars, elevators, planes
  • Other types - for specific phobias that do not fit into the previous four types

Treatment includes behavioral therapy like exposure-based and systematic desensitization. Pharmacotherapy with benzodiazepines, psychotherapy, or combined therapy directed to the attacks may also be beneficial. 

Other options: 

Option A: Agoraphobia is a fear of open places. 

Option B: Acrophobia is a fear of heights. 

Option D: Ailurophobia is a fear of cats. 

Related Pearl: Specific phobia

Present in 10% of the population.

Clinical features:

  • Marked anxiety about a specific object or situation (the phobic stimulus) for > 6 months
  • Usually develops in childhood, can develop after a traumatic event
  • Avoidance behavior

Treatment:

  • Behavioral therapy (exposure-based, systematic desensitization) is the treatment of choice
  • Short-acting benzodiazepines may help acutely

questions.text: A young boy presents with fever and pain while swallowing. He is also noticed to have a typical hot potato voice and drooling of saliva. The following finding is seen on oral examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing congested tonsil, pillar, and soft palate on the right side with a swollen and oedematous uvula pushed to the opposite side is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess or quinsy.

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. It is a complication of tonsillitis.

The clinical features include sore throat, dysphagia, odynophagia, hot potato voice, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever. On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

It is treated with intravenous antibiotics and incision and drainage to drain the abscess. An interval tonsillectomy is done after 4-6 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Tonsillitis occurs due to bacterial infection of the faucial tonsils. Patients present with a sore throat, dysphagia, ear pain, and constitutional symptoms. Tonsils are enlarged and congested with/ without a membrane or yellowish spots over the tonsil.

The image below shows tonsillitis:

Option B: Adenoiditis refers to the infection of the nasopharyngeal tonsil that occurs due to repeated attacks of rhinitis, sinusitis, or tonsillitis in children. The patients present with nasal obstruction, and mouth breathing. The patients have characteristic adenoid facies i.e. elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, high arched hard palate, hitched up upper lip, prominent and crowded upper teeth. 

The images below show enlarged adenoids and adenoid facies respectively. 

Option D: Parotid abscess is the suppuration of the parotid space most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is seen in the postoperative period, dehydration, and debilitated patients. Patients appear toxic with swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness in the parotid gland and at the angle of the mandible. 

The image below shows a parotid abscess.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with ventricular septal defect is posted for corrective surgery. Which of the following is the inhalational agent of choice for induction in this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a child undergoing cardiac surgery, sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for induction.

Halothane and sevoflurane are non-pungent and are less likely to irritate the airway or cause breath-holding or laryngospasm during induction. Hence, halothane and sevoflurane are most suited for use in induction among pediatric patients.

Sevoflurane is less frequently associated with significant myocardial depression, bradycardia, and arrhythmias which are seen with halothane. Hence, sevoflurane is preferred over halothane, especially in all cardiovascular surgeries in the pediatric age group.

Halothane sensitizes the heart to catecholamines, therefore careful reduction in the epinephrine dose in local anesthetic solutions must be followed. 

Following induction, isoflurane and sevoflurane are the most commonly used inhalation agents for maintenance. 

Desflurane and isoflurane are pungent compounds that irritate the airway and may lead to increased airway resistance, breath-holding, and laryngospasm which make them a poor choice for induction.

questions.text: You are evaluating a 17-year-old boy for Marfan's syndrome. You notice the following appearance of the chest as shown in the image below. This finding is called:
questions.solution:
The given image shows forward protrusion of the sternum and the adjacent costal cartilages. This finding is called pectus carinatum.

Pectus carinatum is also known as pigeon chest. It is seen in conditions such as Marfan’s syndrome, rickets, and childhood asthma.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene on the long arm of chromosome 15. Skeletal manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include:

  • Tall stature and long limbs; upper segment to lower segment ratio is reduced.
  • Pectus carinatum 
  • Pectus excavatum or cobbler chest or funnel chest 
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Joint laxity 

The image given below shows the pectus excavatum, characterized by an increased hollowness in the lower part of the sternum.

 

The images below show two important signs seen in Marfan's syndrome: 

  • Image a shows positive wrist sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist
  • Image b shows positive thumb sign - the thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist.

 

Cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include mitral valve prolapse progressing to mitral regurgitation, aortic root dilation leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture. Ocular manifestations include ectopia lentis, where there is upward and temporal dislocation of the lens and myopia.

Other options: 

Option B: Harrison’s sulcus refers to the indrawing of ribs resulting in horizontal grooves along the lower border of the chest due to the pulling of the diaphragm on a weak chest wall. It occurs in chronic respiratory disease in childhood, childhood asthma, and rickets.

questions.text: Thickening of stratum spinosum is seen in?
questions.solution:
Thickening of stratum spinosum is seen in acanthosis.

Acanthosis is a term that describes an increase in the number of cells in the Malpighian or prickle cell layer of the epidermis. Acanthosis is observed in:

  • Viral warts
  • Chronic eczema
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus

Other options: 

Option A: Acantholysis refers to the loss of connections between keratinocytes, due to the breakdown of intercellular bridges formed by desmosomes. It is seen in Pemphigus and its variants, Darier disease, etc. The site of the acantholysis in Pemphigus foliaceus and Pemphigus erythematosus, is in the upper part of the epidermis, whereas in Pemphigus vulgaris, it is at a lower level in the epidermis.

Option C: Hyperkeratosis is a thickening of the stratum corneum due to the presence of abnormal quantities of keratin. It can be seen in keratodermas.

Option D: A hypertrophic scar is an excessive connective tissue response to injury. There is epidermal thickening with increased fibroblasts and mast cells.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman diagnosed with Grave's disease was started on an anti-thyroid drug that does not inhibit the conversion of T4 to T3. Which of the following drug would have been used?
questions.solution:
Methimazole would have been used as an anti-thyroid drug in this patient as it does not inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 (levothyroxine) to T3 (triiodothyronine). It acts by inhibiting the thyroid peroxidase enzyme.

Drugs inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 are propranolol, glucocorticoids, propylthiouracil, and amiodarone. These drugs are used in combination in the management of thyroid storm.

Methimazole is an anti-thyroid drug that belongs to the group of thioamides. It acts to prevent hormone synthesis by inhibiting the thyroid peroxidase catalyzed reactions - iodine organification and coupling of iodotyrosine residues. It has a long intrathyroidal t1/2 and allows once-daily dosing. The usual starting dose for methimazole is 15–40 mg per day.

It is the drug of choice for Grave's disease. It can be used in conjunction with radioactive iodine, to fasten the recovery and to bring the patient to a euthyroid state before preparation for surgery. 

It is usually avoided in the first trimester due to methimazole-associated embryopathy including fetal aplasia cutis which is shown below.

Methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for propylthiouracil-associated liver failure in pregnancy.

questions.text: A small child was rushed to the ED by his parents. He had accidentally consumed wild mushrooms while they were trekking. Examination showed features of encephalopathy and his liver function tests were deranged. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Amanita phalloides (wild mushrooms) toxicity causing acute liver failure. Hypoglycemia is seen in acute liver failure and not hyperglycemia. It occurs due to impaired gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. 

Features of acute hepatic failure are:

  • Hepatic encephalopathy and cerebral edema- There are increased levels of ammonia (neurotoxin) in the body as a result of decreased elimination by the liver.
  • Coagulopathy- There is a decrease in the synthesis of coagulation factors leading to the elevated prothrombin time and INR.
  • Increased risk of infections- It occurs as a result of decreased reticuloendothelial activity, decreased synthesis of complements, acute phase reactants, etc.
  • Renal failure- This is more commonly seen in drug/toxin-induced hepatic failure.
  • Metabolic complications like hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with difficulty in breathing. He had puffiness around the eyes, pitting edema of the lower limbs, and ascites. His 24-hour urine protein shows a protein level of 4 g/24h. CT chest shows a saddle embolus. What is the cause of this patient's CT findings?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome complicated by pulmonary embolism. Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants such as antithrombin III in the urine.

Nephrotic syndrome is a condition that occurs due to damage in the glomerular capillary walls thereby leading to increased capillary permeability to plasma proteins.

The manifestations and the mechanisms of nephrotic syndrome are:

  • Massive proteinuria (>3.5 grams) as a result of leakage in the barrier formed by glomerular basement membrane, endothelium, and visceral epithelial cells.
  • Hypoalbuminemia (albumin <3g/dL) occurs as a consequence of proteinuria. Also, increased catabolism of the kidney contributes to hypoalbuminemia. 
  • Generalized edema is seen. The edema is soft and pitting seen in periorbital and dependent portions of the body. It occurs as a result of decreased intravascular colloid osmotic pressure and other factors like sodium and water retention lead to edema. 
  • Hyperlipidemia occurs following the increased synthesis of lipoproteins, lipid particles, and decreased catabolism of lipids.
  • Lipiduria is due to leakage of lipids through the glomerular capillary wall.

Increased susceptibility to infections is another complication. It is due to the loss of immunoglobulins in the urine.

The CT image below depicts a large pulmonary embolism at the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolism).

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability. On examination, the following finding is noticed over the abdomen. His laboratory reports indicate excessive secretion of a specific adrenal hormone. This hormone is physiologically elevated in all of the following conditions, except ____.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with hypertension, moon facies, easy bruisability, and multiple purple striae over the abdomen is consistent with Cushing's syndrome. The adrenal hormone implicated is cortisol and cortisol levels are physiologically elevated around early morning while waking up.

Cushing's syndrome can be ACTH-dependent and ACTH-independent. When it is caused by an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secreting tumor of the pituitary gland, it is called Cushing's disease. 

ACTH is a hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary gland. Its secretion is controlled by corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. In turn, ACTH stimulates the adrenal cortex to produce cortisol.

The image given below shows clinical features seen in Cushing syndrome.

The rate of secretion and levels of cortisol are high in the morning but low in the evening. Specifically, its levels are the highest about an hour before waking up in the morning and lowest around midnight. This occurs due to a cyclical alteration in the signals from the hypothalamus, over 24 hours.

Additionally, during a mentally stressful state and when pain causes physical stress, there is an increase in cortisol levels in the body.

The diurnal variation of cortisol production is shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with episodes of a sudden sensation of intense heat involving the face and upper chest which rapidly spreads across the entire body. The episodes last about 2-4 minutes and are associated with profuse sweating, palpitations, and anxiety. What is the most effective treatment for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes) in a postmenopausal woman. Estrogen therapy is found to be the most effective to treat it.

Hot flushes are episodes of vasodilation affecting the face and the neck. The episode lasts for 2–5 min each. These are followed by severe sweating, palpitations, anxiety, and anginal pains may be felt. Multiple episodes occur during the day, but are more severe at night and can disturb sleep. Sometimes they can be preceded by headaches.

Hormone therapy in postmenopausal women is only indicated for the treatment of

  • vasomotor symptoms
  • osteoporosis (prevention and treatment)
  • vaginal atrophy
  • urethral syndrome
  • dyspareunia

Estrogen can be given as oral estrogen formulations, transdermal patches, topical gel, or intravaginal formulations. For Dyspareunia, urethral syndrome, and senile vaginitis local estrogen cream is preferred over oral therapy. Short-term therapy is recommended for vasomotor symptoms whereas osteoporosis requires long-term therapy. Estrogen should be given in the smallest effective dose for the shortest duration possible.

Contraindications of HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • Known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic disease
  • Liver dysfunction or gall bladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine fibroids as these may enlarge in size.

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. For women without uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.

questions.text: A  pregnant woman at term gestation presents with complaints of decreased fetal movements. A non-stress test was done and the cardiotocograph is given below. Which of the following conditions does it indicate?
questions.solution:
The above cardiotocography (CTG) image shows variable deceleration, which indicates umbilical cord compression.

Normal baseline fetal heart rate (FHR) is 110-160 bpm (beats per minute). Baseline FHR shows a beat-to-beat fluctuation in amplitude and frequency ranging from 5-25 bpm. This is called baseline variability. Whenever the fetus moves, there is a transient increase in FHR by 15 bpm lasting for 10- 15 seconds. This is called acceleration. Acceleration and normal baseline variability (5-25 bpm) is a sign of a healthy fetus.

Deceleration is the decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s. Following are the various types of decelerations seen on CTG and their clinical significance:

Feature Early deceleration Late deceleration Variable deceleration
The pattern of heart rate fall

Gradual decline and gradual recovery of heart rate.

The maximum dip of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the contraction. 

Symmetrical and gradual decline in heart rate.

Onset, maximum dip, and recovery occur after the onset, peak, and recovery of contraction respectively.

Abrupt fall in the heart rate.   

Decelerations are variable in respect of the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions.
Time taken to reach the maximum dip of deceleration  >30seconds  >30seconds  <30 seconds
Cause Fetal head compression Fetal hypoxia due to maternal hypotension, placental insufficiency, and excessive uterine activity Umbilical cord compression

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

questions.text: A 14-month-old baby was brought with complaints of continuous watering from the eyes,  present since birth. Antibiotic eye drops and frequent massaging to express the contents of the nasolacrimal duct did not show much improvement. Which of the following would be the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic dacryocystitis and the next best step in the management of this patient is the probing of the nasolacrimal duct under anesthesia.

Dacryocystitis is the inflammation of the lacrimal sac. It generally affects infants and adults, most commonly females over 40 years of age. Congenital dacryocystitis is almost always chronic, while acquired dacryocystitis may be acute or chronic.

Congenital dacryocystitis is due to incomplete canalization of the lacrimal system, most often at the valve of Hasner. In newborns, antibiotic drops and frequent massaging to express the contents of the nasolacrimal duct and sac clear out most infections. However, if the symptoms persist beyond a year without improvement, probing of the nasolacrimal duct under anesthesia is advised. Balloon dilatation of the duct or placement of a silicone tube can be done after localizing the level of obstruction.

Other options:

Option B: Antibiotic drops with repeated syringing is the first line of treatment in adults with chronic dacryocystitis.

Option C: In adults, if dacryocystitis persists after repeated syringing, anatomical assessment with digital subtraction macrodacryocystography localises the level of obstruction.

Option D: Dacryocystorhinostomy is the surgical management of chronic dacryocystitis and is advised in adults with blockage at the level of joining of the nasolacrimal duct and sac.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old male patient diagnosed with malaria was commenced on an anti-malarial drug. After two days, port wine-colored urine was noted. His lab reports are given below. What is your diagnosis?

Hemoglobin - 9.0 g/dL
Blood glucose - 100 mg/dL
Serum creatinine - 5.6 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient with malaria treated with an anti-malarial drug (likely quinine) developing hemoglobinuria (port-wine stained urine), hemolysis (reduced hemoglobin), and renal failure (increased creatinine) is suggestive of blackwater fever.

Blackwater fever (malarial hemoglobinuria) is an autoimmune process seen in Falciparum malaria, particularly in patients who have experienced repeated past infections and inadequate treatment with quinine. Clinical manifestations include fever, prostration, hemoglobinuria, and bilious vomiting, with the passage of dark red or blackish urine. 

It is due to massive intravascular hemolysis caused by anti-erythrocyte antibodies, leading to massive absorption of hemoglobin by the renal tubules (hemoglobinuric nephrosis), producing blackwater fever. Complications of blackwater fever include renal failure, acute liver failure, and circulatory collapse. 

Complications of Falciparum malaria include:

  • Cerebral malaria
  • Algid malaria
  • Septicemic malaria
  • Blackwater fever
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute renal failure
  • Hypoglycemia (glucose <40 mg/dL)
  • Severe anemia (Hb <5 g/dL, PCV <15%)
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Shock
  • Bleeding disturbances

Other options:

Option A: Septicemic malaria is characterized by high continuous fever with the dissemination of the parasite to various organs, leading to multiorgan failure.

Option B: Algid malaria is characterized by peripheral circulatory failure, rapid thready pulse with low blood pressure, and cold clammy skin. There may be severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and profound shock.

Option D: Cerebral malaria is manifested by features of diffuse symmetric encephalopathy like headache, confusion, increased muscle tone, seizures, paralysis, slowly lapsing into a coma.

questions.text: The image given below shows an H&E-stained section of a lung tumor. The immunohistochemical studies of this tumor are most likely to express which of the following tumor markers?
questions.solution:
The above H&E stained histopathological image of a lung tumor shows keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Cytokeratins are the tumor markers that are most likely to be expressed.

Cytokeratins are the intermediate filaments expressed by epithelial cells. The presence of cytokeratins on immunohistochemistry suggests a carcinoma of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial origin include squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma etc.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly seen in men and has an increased risk with smoking. The tumor appears like a cauliflower-like mass that is gray-white, firm to hard, and bulky with hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological features include keratinization in the form of squamous pearls. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. 

Option B: Calretinin serves as a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker for colon carcinoma and other malignancies including the pancreas, stomach, and heart.

questions.text: A patient who had previously been intubated while admitted to the intensive care unit was found to have tracheal stenosis during his follow-up visits. Which of the following graphs would represent the flow-volume loop in this patient?
questions.solution:
The graph representing the flow-volume loop in this patient with tracheal stenosis would be graph 3, or option C. 

When there is fixed central airway obstruction, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop, as observed in tracheal stenosis.

Other options:

Option A: Image 1 shows airflow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. It is seen in conditions responsible for variable upper airway obstruction like vocal fold paralysis, and extrathoracic tracheomalacia.

Option B: Image 2 shows airflow limitation and flattening in the expiratory limb of the loop. This is seen in conditions responsible for variable lower airway obstruction like tracheomalacia of intrathoracic airway or bronchogenic cysts.

Option D: Image 4 shows a concave upward, pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also a called "scooped-out" or "coved" pattern and is observed in cases responsible for airflow obstruction at any transmural pressure, like in asthma or chronic bronchitis.

A sawtooth pattern of the loop consists of small, rapid oscillations in airflow during both expiration and inspiration. It is seen in neuromuscular diseases, Parkinson's disease, laryngeal dyskinesia, pedunculated tumours of the upper airway, tracheobronchomalacia, and obstructive sleep apnea.

Related Pearl: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text: Antenatal ultrasound of a 40-year-old primigravida revealed nuchal translucency of 5 mm. Lab investigations showed reduced maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein and increased inhibin A. Which screening tests will not be recommended for the baby after birth?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of nuchal translucency >3 mm, reduced maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) and increased inhibin A suggests Down's syndrome. Screening for thalassemia is not done in newborns with Down's syndrome.

Screening tests are recommended in a newborn with Down's syndrome for:

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Hearing impairment or loss
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Strabismus, cataracts, nystagmus
  • Constipation (increased risk for Hirschsprung disease)
  • Hematologic disease (for neonatal polycythemia, leukemia)

Down's syndrome occurs due to the trisomy of chromosome 21.

The following antenatal tests help in the detection of Down's syndrome.

Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased
PAPPA decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased
 NT increased MSAFP decreased MSAFP decreased
    Serum inhibin A increased
 
Nuchal translucency is the maximum thickness of the translucent area between the skin and soft tissue over the fetal spine at the back of the neck. When the NT measurement is increased, there is a greater risk for fetal aneuploidy and struc­tural anomalies.

questions.text: A 2-year-old febrile child is brought to the outpatient department with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions were also found on his palms and soles. Which of the following conditions may also be caused by the organism implicated in this child's condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a young child with fever and a rash is strongly suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by Coxsackie A group of viruses. Coxsackie A group viruses are also responsible for herpangina. 

Coxsackie viruses are enteroviruses and belong to the Picornaviridae family. They are classified into groups A and B. Group A viruses are classified into 24 types and group B viruses are classified into 6 types.

Diseases caused by coxsackie A viruses include hand, foot, and mouth disease, herpangina, aseptic meningitis, and minor respiratory infections.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fevercharacterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and vesicular rashes of the palms and soles, which heal without crusting.

Herpangina is severe febrile vesicular pharyngitis which presents as acute onset fever, sore throat and odynophagia. Lesions are present on the soft palate, anterior pillars of the tonsils, and uvula. In contrast to herpes stomatitis, enteroviral herpangina is not associated with gingivitis.

Diseases caused by Coxsackie B viruses include pleurodynia, myocarditis, pericarditis, juvenile diabetes, and orchitis. 

Pleurodynia or epidemic myalgia or Bornholm disease is viral myalgia defined by the fever and abrupt onset of stabbing chest pain.

The following images show rashes in hand, foot, and mouth disease-

 

Image showing herpangina-

Other options-
 
Option B: Herpetic gingivostomatitis is an important differential diagnosis of oral ulcers. It is characterized by lesions on the hard and soft palate, gingiva, tongue, lips and facial area. It is caused by the herpes simplex virus, mostly HSV-1.
 
Option C: Pharyngoconjunctival fever is caused by adenovirus, usually serotypes 3 and 7. It tends to occur in outbreaks (swimming pool conjunctivitis) and is characterized by febrile pharyngitis and conjunctivitis.
 
Option D: Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limiting viral disease of the skin caused by a pox virus. It produces dome-shaped, pink pearly wart-like umbilicated lesions, with a dimple at the center. Lesions are found singly or in clusters, anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles. Genital lesions are seen in adults.

questions.text: A factory worker with tuberculosis was started on DOTS (directly observed treatment short course) and is advised to rest. He earns Rs 20,000/- as a monthly income and is eligible for periodic payments under the Employees State Insurance Act scheme. Which benefit does this case fall under?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is diagnosed to have tuberculosis, and thus he is eligible for the extended sickness benefit of the ESI scheme. 

Extended sickness benefit is the leave given up to a maximum period of two years. The diseases for which extended sickness benefits are applied are TB, leprosy, empyema, HIV, malignancies, plegias, etc. During this period, 80 per cent of the wages are paid.

ESI act was amended to provide cash and medical benefits to employees during sickness, maternity, and employment injury. People with monthly earnings up to 21,000 are covered under this scheme. Cash benefits are made through branches and cash offices. The medical benefits are made available through ESI dispensaries, clinics, hospitals, etc. The benefits provided to the insured persons are:

  • Medical benefits - Complete medical care is provided to the insured person and his/ her family members.
  • Sickness benefits - include a periodic cash payment for 91 days to the insured sick person. 70% of the average daily wages is given as the daily rate if the person is under medical treatment. 
  • Enhanced sickness benefit - includes 14 days of leave given for tubectomy and 7 days of leave for vasectomy. The amount payable is equal to the full wages.
  • Maternity benefits - cash payments equal to full wages are paid to the insured person for up to 26 weeks in cases of pregnancy.
  • Disablement benefit - cash payment and free medical treatment are given for temporary or permanent disablements and occupational diseases.
  • Dependant's benefit - if an employment injury causes the death of the insured person, the dependants are eligible for periodic payments.
  • Funeral expenses of Rs 15000 are payable to the dependants.
  • Rehabilitation allowance - the insured person and the family members continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement and retirement.

Note: Directly observed treatment short course (DOTS) is an effective treatment strategy used for tuberculosis. In the intensive phase of the treatment, the patient swallows the drug in the presence of a healthcare worker. During the continuation phase, medicine is issued for a week and only the first dose is swallowed in the presence of a health worker. 

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A patient presented with hypermobility of joints, skin changes, and scoliosis. On further evaluation, arthrochalasia type of Ehler Danlos syndrome was suspected. What will be the type of collagen defect seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the arthrochalasia type of Ehlers–Danlos syndrome (EDS), a defect in type 1 collagen is seen.

Arthrochalasia is an autosomal-dominant disorder. The fundamental defect is in the conversion of type I procollagen to collagen. It occurs due to mutations that affect one of the two type I collagen genes, COL1A1, and COL1A2. 

Clinical findings include severe joint hypermobility, mild skin changes, scoliosis, and bruising.

EDS is a group of disorders due to mutations in the genes that encode collagen, enzymes that modify collagen, and to a little extent proteins present in the extracellular matrix. 

The features are hyperextensible skin, hypermobile joints, extreme fatigue, easy bruising, rupture of the colon, large arteries, cornea, retinal detachment, and diaphragmatic hernia.

The various types of EDS are classic, hypermobility, vascular, kyphoscoliosis, arthrochalasia, and dermatosparaxis.

Note: Arthrochalasia (VII a, b) - Here the Roman numeral VII denotes the previous classification of EDS and not collagen VII.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have normally developed breasts and swelling in the right inguinal region and female-type external genitalia. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal the uterus or cervix. The karyotype is 46XY. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings in the question are seen in androgen insensitivity syndrome/ testicular feminizing syndrome. In this syndrome, the affected individual has testes producing the androgens, but the response of the androgen receptors to androgens is defective.

The findings of the given case can be explained as follows:

  • Primary amenorrhea - Due to the absence of uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts - Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region - Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, due to loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix - Due to the production of mullerian inhibiting substance from the sertoli cells of the testis.
  • The XY karyotype indicates that the patient is a genotypic male.

Option A - Swyer's syndrome : although the karyotype is 46XY, the testes are dysgenetic and do not produce androgens. As a result the external genitalia resemble that of a female. The Mullerian system is preserved as the dysgenetic gonads fail to produce anti Mullerian hormone.

Option C - Mullerian agenesis is another cause of primary amenorrhea characterised by absent uterus, fallopian tubes, cervix and upper vagina. The secondary sexual characteristics are preserved due to the presence of estrogen producing ovaries. However the karyotype is 46XX.

Option D - Turner's syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping reveals 45XO and the individual has streak ovaries and absent secondary sexual features.
