questions.text: Which of the following nerves provide the sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords?

questions.text: An elderly tuberculosis patient on treatment is non-compliant to initial therapy. Drug susceptibility showed resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid. He was started with the next-line drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis. Which of the following can be the newly given drug?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis is bedaquiline.

Bedaquiline targets subunit c of the ATP synthase of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This results in inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

400 mg daily for 2 weeks followed by 200 mg three times a week thereafter is the regimen for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Cycloserine inhibits the alanine racemase that converts L-alanine to D-alanine. This stops the reactions in which D-alanine is incorporated into mycobacterial bacterial cell wall synthesis. 

Option B: Ethioinamide inhibits mycobacterial growth by inhibiting the activity of the enoyl-ACP reductase of fatty acid synthase II which is an inhA gene product. Isoniazid inhibits the same enzyme. 

Option D: Pretomanid is used in extensively drug-resistant and multi-drug-resistant TB. It inhibits mycolic acids and proteins synthesis of M. tuberculosis and in non-replicating persistent bacilli.

questions.text:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?

NRR: Net reproduction rate
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with recurrent abdominal discomfort for the past 1 year with increased stool frequency. According to ROME IV criteria he was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome of the diarrhea-predominant type. Which neurotransmitter is likely to be associated with the disease process of this patient?
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter associated with irritable bowel syndrome diarrhea-predominant type (IBS-D) is serotonin (5-HT).

Serotonin-containing enterochromaffin cells in the colon are increased in a subset of patients with IBS-D compared to healthy individuals. Serotonin may contribute to the postprandial symptoms of these patients and provide a rationale for the use of serotonin antagonists in the treatment of this disorder.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine
